subsection.text: In this Division I of this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.
“Includes” or “including” means includes or including by way of illustration and not by way of limitation.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, or territory of the United States;
the District of Columbia; or
the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

subsection.text: The fiscal year for the State and its officers and units begins on July 1 of a calendar year and ends on June 30 of the next calendar year.
Each officer and unit of the State government shall use the fiscal year for:

paragraph.text: appropriating money;
authorizing expenditures;
keeping records;
balancing books and accounts; and
making reports.

subsection.text: On or before the 10th day of each regular session of the General Assembly, the Comptroller shall submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly an annual report on the fiscal operations of the State.
The report shall state:

paragraph.text: for the fiscal year in which the report is made:

subparagraph.text: the estimated State revenues; and
the estimated State expenditures; and

paragraph.text: for the preceding fiscal year:

subparagraph.text: the total State funds;
the total State revenues;
the amount of revenues that the State received from each source;
the total State expenditures;
the purposes of the expenditures;
each amount that the State claims is due from a political subdivision;
each amount that the State claims is due from an officer of a political subdivision who, by law, collects revenues for the State;
the total funds, from all State sources, that the State transferred to each political subdivision; and
the amount of those transferred funds, as calculated for each $100 of assessed value of property in a political subdivision.

section.text: After each regular session of the General Assembly, the Comptroller shall deliver to the printer who is designated to print the session laws an accurate statement of receipts and expenditures of public money for the last full fiscal year preceding that session.

subsection.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Treasurer shall submit an annual report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The report shall describe the activities and operation of the Office of the Treasurer during the preceding fiscal year.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: a statement on the management of State funds;
a statement on the interest earned on investments; and
a statement on the administration of the State Insurance Program and the State Insurance Trust Fund, including any recommendations for changes in their operation.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bond” means any evidence of debt.
“Official” includes:

subparagraph.text: a comptroller;
a chief financial officer; and
a treasurer.

paragraph.text: “Public body” means:

subparagraph.text: a unit of the State government; or
a county, municipal corporation, public corporation, special authority, or other political subdivision of the State.

subsection.text: If a public body is authorized to incur debt to be redeemed from the proceeds of any tax or levy, an authorized official of the public body shall submit to the State Treasurer:

paragraph.text: on or before January 1 of each year, a report on bonds anticipated to be issued during the next 7-month period; and
on or before July 1 of each year, a report on bonds anticipated to be issued during the next 7-month period.
A report under this section shall be in the form the State Treasurer requires.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: a statement of the amount of bonds that the public body expects to issue during the period that the report covers; and
for each issue of bonds, a statement of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the month and part of the month during which the bonds will be issued;
the term for which the bonds will be outstanding; and
whether the bonds will be sold at a public or private sale.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall prepare:

subparagraph.text: on or before January 31 of each year, a compilation of the information in the reports submitted for the current January 1 to July 31 period; and
on or before July 31 of each year, a compilation of the information in the reports submitted for the current July 1 to January 31 period.

paragraph.text: The compilation shall include any additions or corrections to the information in the reports.
The State Treasurer shall send a copy of the compilation to each official who submitted a report included in the compilation.

subsection.text: The State Treasurer shall:

paragraph.text: make the reports and compilations available for inspection during normal business hours; and
provide a copy of a report or compilation to any person who first pays to the State Treasurer a fee to cover costs.
An official is not personally liable for failure to submit a report under this section.
Failure to submit the report or to comply with other requirements of this section does not affect:

subparagraph.text: the authority of a public body to incur debt; or
the validity of any debt that the public body incurs.

subsection.text: As provided by the Comptroller by regulation, each unit of State government that imposes fees of any kind shall maintain and make available to the Comptroller up-to-date data regarding:

paragraph.text: the services or functions for which fees are imposed and the associated levels of the fees; and
a comparison of the actual revenues generated by the fees and the total costs of providing the service or performing the function for which the fees are imposed.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall prepare and submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly, on a biennial basis on or before December 1 of every other year, a report compiling the data made available to the Comptroller under subsection (a) of this section.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall adopt regulations to implement this section.
The regulations adopted by the Comptroller under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall specify:

subparagraph.text: that the data required for the Maryland Port Administration of the Department of Transportation shall be the data included in the port tariff;

that the Maryland Aviation Administration and the Maryland Port Administration shall disclose aggregate information on fees and costs, provided that such disclosure does not include information that is proprietary in nature; and

that any other department, agency, or governmental unit which collects fees or user charges that may contain privileged or proprietary information may aggregate or standardize the information submitted as needed to preserve the sensitive nature of the information.

subsection.text: In this section, “gift” has the meaning stated in Article 1, § 22 of the Code.
Except as otherwise expressly provided by law, an officer or unit of the State government may not spend any money that derives from a gift until the Governor assents to the acceptance of the gift.

If the Governor assents to the acceptance of a gift by an officer or unit, the officer or unit may use the gift in accordance with its terms. If the gift is money or generates money, the officer or unit may not spend the money until it is appropriated as provided in Title 7 of this article.
In this section, “block grant” means any federal grant-in-aid that:

paragraph.text: contains consolidated funding for 1 or more programs; and
is designated by Congress as a block grant.

subsection.text: It is the policy of the State that the General Assembly and the Governor should consult before the Executive Branch of the State government adopts State policy on block grants.

paragraph.text: This section is in addition to and not in derogation of any other power or duty of the General Assembly.
This section applies to the adoption of State policy to:

subparagraph.text: participate in a block grant;
set a date on which the State will accept responsibility for a block grant; or
transfer money between block grants.

subsection.text: The Governor shall send, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the Legislative Policy Committee each proposal for the adoption of State policy on a block grant.
Within 60 days after the Legislative Policy Committee receives the proposal or, if the Committee sets a shorter period, within that period, the Committee:

paragraph.text: may hold a public hearing on the proposal;
may refer the proposal to another committee for review; and
for the General Assembly, may send the Governor comments on the proposal.

subsection.text: The Governor may act on the proposal only after the expiration of the 60-day period or any shorter period set under subsection (e) of this section.

paragraph.text: After consultation with the Department of Budget and Management, the Secretary of Planning shall adopt regulations that require a unit of the State government to submit information, as required in this section, on federal aid, including grants, instructional contracts, loans, research contracts, or other assistance.
The regulations shall require a unit of the State government to obtain a State Application Identifier (SAI) from the Department of Planning.

Each 6 months, a unit shall submit a summary notice to the Department of Planning if, during the 6-month period that the notice covers, the unit has received an award of federal aid in the form of an instructional contract, instructional grant, research contract, or research grant.
The summary notice shall state the amount of the award.
This subsection does not apply to an instructional contract, instructional grant, research contract, or research grant.
When a unit applies for federal aid, the unit shall send to the Department of Planning a copy of the application.
Within 30 days after a unit receives an award of federal aid, the unit shall submit to the Department of Planning a summary notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the award; and
if the award is conditioned on matching funds:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount of those funds;
the source of those funds; and
the period for which those funds are required.

section.text: The Governor may designate any unit of the State government:

paragraph.text: to accept any surplus food that, under an act of Congress, is available to the State; and
to manage and dispose of the food in accordance with federal law.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Board.
“Council” means the Rural Maryland Council established under Title 13, Subtitle 4 of the Economic Development Article.
“Fund” means the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Fund.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds and declares that:

paragraph.text: many nonprofit organizations that serve the needs of the rural areas of the State experience fiscal difficulties in addressing the areas of economic and community development and agriculture and forestry education because of the inadequacy of funding resources for them;

these organizations do not have the access to private and public sources of funding that are generally more available to nonprofit groups that serve the needs of the metropolitan areas of the State; and
as a result, the rural areas of the State face a serious deficit of resources where the need, in many instances, is greatest.
There is a Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Fund that shall be administered by the Council.
The purpose of the Fund is to provide funding:

subparagraph.text: to rural regional planning and economic development organizations and rural community development programs whose missions and work have statewide implications and merit State support; and
to augment the efforts of advanced technology centers and similar programs that serve agricultural and natural resources based small businesses in rural areas through community colleges.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund which is not subject to § 7-302 of this article.
The Treasurer shall separately hold and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Treasurer may invest moneys in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.

paragraph.text: Expenditures from the Fund may only be made:

subparagraph.text: pursuant to an appropriation approved by the General Assembly in the annual State budget; or
by the budget amendment procedure provided for in § 7-209 of this article, provided that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the budget amendment and supporting information have been submitted to the budget committees for their review and comment; and
at least 45 days have elapsed from the time the budget amendment and supporting information were submitted to the budget committees.

subsection.text: The Council shall award grants on the basis of the binding recommendations of the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Board.

paragraph.text: There is a Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Board.
The Board shall consist of:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary of Agriculture or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Housing and Community Development or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Natural Resources or the Secretary’s designee; and
the Chairman of the Council or the Chairman’s designee.

paragraph.text: The agencies listed in paragraph (2)(i) through (v) of this subsection may assist the Council with administering individual grant awards.
The Board shall:

subparagraph.text: establish procedures for applications for grants;
review applications for grants; and
make binding recommendations to the Council regarding the recipients of grants and the amount of the grants.

paragraph.text: The Board shall give funding priority to organizations described in subsection (c)(2)(i) of this section that have:

subparagraph.text: obtained an equal matching amount of funding from a source other than the State in the immediate prior fiscal year; or
sufficient evidence of a commitment of a third party funding source to provide an equal matching amount of funding in the current fiscal year.

paragraph.text: A grant recipient shall submit to the Council written documentation of how the grant recipient spent or otherwise used the grant.
On or before June 30 of each year, the Council shall submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly, a written report that includes:

subparagraph.text: the number of grants made during the fiscal year;
the names of the recipients of the grants;
the specific purpose of each grant awarded; and
documentation of how the grant recipient spent or otherwise used the grant.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2020 PER CHAPTER 621 OF 2006 //

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Agriculture” means the commercial production, storage, processing, marketing, distribution, or export of an agronomic, aquacultural, equine, floricultural, horticultural, ornamental, silvicultural, or viticultural crop, including:

subparagraph.text: farm products;
livestock and livestock products;
poultry and poultry products;
milk and dairy products;
timber and forest products;
fruit and horticultural products; and
seafood and aquacultural products.

paragraph.text: “Board” means the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Board established under § 2–206(e) of this subtitle.
“Council” means the Rural Maryland Council established under Title 13, Subtitle 4 of the Economic Development Article.
“Fund” means the Rural Maryland Prosperity Investment Fund established under this section.
“Regional councils” means:

subparagraph.text: the Mid–Shore Regional Council;
the Lower Eastern Shore Regional Council;
the Tri–County Council for Southern Maryland;
the Tri–County Council for Western Maryland; and
the Upper Shore Regional Council.

paragraph.text: “Rural area” means:

subparagraph.text: the following counties:

sub-subparagraph.text: Allegany;
Calvert;
Caroline;
Carroll;
Cecil;
Charles;
Dorchester;
Frederick;
Garrett;
Harford;
Kent;
Queen Anne’s;
St. Mary’s;
Somerset;
Talbot;
Washington;
Wicomico; and
Worcester; and

subparagraph.text: portions of other counties in close proximity to agricultural activity.

paragraph.text: “Rural community” means an incorporated or unincorporated area of a county or group of counties in a rural area.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: many rural communities in the State face a host of difficult challenges relating to persistent unemployment and poverty, changing technological and economic conditions, an aging population and an out–migration of youth, inadequate access to quality housing, health care and other services, and deteriorating or inadequate transportation, communications, sanitation, and economic development infrastructure;

Maryland’s agricultural and resource–based industries continue to underpin the local economies of rural communities but are increasingly under threat from national and international market competition, urban encroachment and land development pressure, and environmental and regulatory influences;

local governments, regional organizations, educational institutions, and private sector service providers have been unable to meet all the economic development, community development, and human services needs of Maryland residents in the rural counties and municipal corporations because of a lack of adequate available capacity and resources;

the objective of the Rural Maryland Prosperity Investment Fund is to help raise the overall standard of living in rural areas to a level that meets or exceeds statewide benchmark averages by 2020, while preserving the best aspects of a pastoral heritage and rural way of life;

resources provided to the Fund are designed to facilitate significant targeted investments in important economic and community development programs and promote regional and intergovernmental cooperation;

these investments will also enable local and regional public and nonprofit organizations to leverage additional nonstate financial and human resources to facilitate the realization of sustainable rural development objectives while the program is in effect; and
the Fund will serve the interests of the entire State by:

subparagraph.text: encouraging the increase of entrepreneurial activity and commerce and a balanced economy in the State;
relieving conditions of unemployment and underemployment in rural areas;
assisting in the retention of valuable farm and forest land for productive use by present and future generations;
promoting intergovernmental cooperation and public sector/private sector partnerships in and between rural and other areas;
enhancing the deployment of housing, transportation, water, wastewater, and broadband communications infrastructure and services in rural areas;
supporting rural commercial center redevelopment and community revitalization efforts; and
generally promoting the health, happiness, safety, employment opportunity, and general welfare of the residents of each of the rural counties and municipal corporations of the State.

paragraph.text: There is a Rural Maryland Prosperity Investment Fund.
The Fund is administered by the Rural Maryland Council with the assistance of the Board.

The purpose of the Fund is to provide funding to rural regional and statewide planning and development organizations, institutions of higher education serving rural communities, rural community development organizations, and local governments acting in partnership with one another to promote the quality of life in rural areas.

subsection.text: Each year, beginning in fiscal year 2008 and continuing through fiscal year 2020, the Governor may include an appropriation in the budget bill for the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of this article.
The Treasurer shall separately hold and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Treasurer may invest money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.

subsection.text: Disbursements of money appropriated to the Fund shall be allocated equally among the following categories:

paragraph.text: rural regional planning and development assistance, by targeting support to the:

subparagraph.text: regional councils serving rural areas; and
multicounty efforts serving rural communities in areas not served by the regional councils;

paragraph.text: regional infrastructure projects that directly involve two or more units of local government, not to exceed one–fourth of the total cost of any particular project;
rural entrepreneurship development, including programs and activities serving rural communities undertaken by nonprofit organizations and institutions of higher education; and

rural community development, programmatic assistance, and education, with money to be divided equally between the Council and the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Fund.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board shall award grants from the Fund on a competitive basis in accordance with the procedures in § 2–206(e) of this subtitle.
Any money received by the Council under subsection (f) of this section shall be used to help administer the Fund and perform other functions that benefit rural areas as the Council determines.
A grant recipient shall submit to the Council written documentation of how the grant recipient spent or otherwise used the grant.

subsection.text: The Board may reallocate money from one category listed in subsection (f) of this section to another category only if there is a lack of sufficient applications requesting use of money in a particular category.

paragraph.text: On or before October 1 of each year, the Council shall submit a report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
The report shall summarize the activities of the Fund during the preceding fiscal year, including:

subparagraph.text: the number of grants made during the fiscal year;
the names of the recipients of the grants;
the specific purpose of each grant awarded; and
documentation of how the grant recipient spent or otherwise used the grant.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authorized officer” means any official of the State or any of its political subdivisions whose signature to a public security or instrument of payment is required or permitted.
“Facsimile signature” means a reproduction by engraving, imprinting, stamping, or other means of the manual signature of any authorized officer.
“Instrument of payment” means a check, draft, warrant, or order for the payment, delivery, or transfer of funds.
“Public security” means a bond, note, certificate of indebtedness, or other obligation for the payment of money, issued by the State or by any of its political subdivisions.
“State” means the State or any of its departments, agencies, public bodies, or other instrumentalities.

section.text: This subtitle shall be construed to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the law of those states that enact it.

subsection.text: Any authorized officer, after filing with the Secretary of State the manual signature of the authorized officer certified under oath, may execute or cause to be executed with a facsimile signature instead of a manual signature:

paragraph.text: any public security, if the signature of at least 1 authorized officer required or permitted to be placed on the public security is manually subscribed; and
any instrument of payment.

subsection.text: If a public security is required to be manually signed by a trustee, issuing agent, fiscal agent, registrar, or other agent or custodian, any other signature required or permitted to be placed on the public security may be a facsimile signature.
Upon compliance with this subtitle by the authorized officer, the facsimile signature of the authorized officer has the same legal effect as the manual signature of the authorized officer.

When the seal of the State or of any of its political subdivisions is required in the execution of a public security or instrument of payment, the authorized officer may cause the seal to be printed, engraved, stamped, or otherwise placed in facsimile on the public security or instrument of payment.
The facsimile seal has the same legal effect as the impression of the seal.
A person may not use, with intent to defraud, on a public security or an instrument of payment:

paragraph.text: a facsimile signature, or any reproduction of it, of any authorized officer; or
a facsimile seal, or any reproduction of it, of the State or of any of its political subdivisions.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or both.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Uniform Facsimile Signature of Public Officials Act”.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Annual operating costs” include the cost of:

paragraph.text: the production, treatment, pumping, storage, transmission, and distribution of water and the maintenance and repair of equipment associated with these functions;
the collection, pumping, transmission, and treatment of wastewater, and the maintenance and repair of equipment associated with these functions;
administrative overhead;
debt service;
depreciation; and
servicing customer accounts.

subsection.text: “Lateral system construction costs” include:

paragraph.text: any cost necessary to plan, design, acquire, construct, inspect, test, and put into operation the lateral system to serve a State facility; and
any indirect cost incurred by the local jurisdiction that is necessary to construct water and sewer lines.

subsection.text: The State shall pay its share of:

paragraph.text: the annual operating costs of furnishing water and sewer service to any State facility; and
the lateral system construction costs associated with the installation of any water or sewer line that directly serves the State facility.

subsection.text: The State shall pay the cost of expanding a water or sewage treatment facility if the expansion is necessitated by the use of the facility by the State. However, the amount the State pays may not exceed the cost of the capacity required by the State.

section.text: The State shall pay any assessment, charge, or fee that is:

paragraph.text: levied by the local jurisdiction in which the State facility is located; and
designated as the State’s share of annual operating costs or lateral system construction costs.

subsection.text: If the State has agreed to pay the costs set out in § 2-402 of this subtitle and any additional construction costs associated with the connection, the State may connect a State facility, regardless of its location, to a publicly owned utility system.
If an existing publicly owned utility system is inadequate to handle proposed State utility needs, the State shall pay all costs that are:

paragraph.text: associated with the expansion of the publicly owned utility system to meet the needs of the State; and
in excess of available federal funds.

subsection.text: Before connecting to any publicly owned utility system, the State shall:

paragraph.text: coordinate with the owner of the publicly owned utility system; and
consider any existing master plan in establishing the fiscal obligation of the State under this section.
After determining the need of the State for water or sewerage capacity, the State shall provide the information to the appropriate local jurisdictions.
The local jurisdictions shall include State facility needs in developing their master plans for water and sewerage systems.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Facility for handicapped individuals” includes any door, elevator, handrail, ramp, specially treated surface, or similar design, convenience, or device that facilitates the health, safety, or comfort of a handicapped individual.
“Handicapped individual” means an individual with a measurable limitation of mobility caused by disease, trauma, or congenital defect.

paragraph.text: “Public building” means a building, structure, or improved area that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the State or any political subdivision of the State; or
constructed for lease by the State or a political subdivision of the State.

paragraph.text: “Public building” includes:

subparagraph.text: an educational facility constructed with public funds or owned or operated by the State or a political subdivision of the State;
a public mass transportation accommodation, such as a terminal or station, that is supported by public funds; and
an improvement of a public area used for gathering or amusement, including a public park, recreation center, or the like.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that public buildings that lack facilities for handicapped individuals:

paragraph.text: create a substantial risk of death or injury to handicapped individuals and others in both normal and emergency conditions; and
impair the full use and enjoyment of the public buildings by handicapped individuals for education, employment, recreation, training, or treatment.

section.text: The design of any public building by the State or a political subdivision of the State is governed by this subtitle.
Plans and specifications for the construction of any public building, other than a building to be used as a penal institution, shall provide for facilities for handicapped individuals.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, if curbs or sidewalks at the intersection of 2 or more streets or roads are constructed or reconstructed by the State Highway Administration, by a political subdivision, or by a private contractor for dedication to a political subdivision, the curbs or sidewalks shall have ramps or curb cuts:

paragraph.text: graded onto the crosswalks of the intersection;
at least 40 inches wide; and
constructed to allow reasonable access to the crosswalks by physically handicapped individuals.

subsection.text: Ramps or curb cuts are not required under this section if, for a particular intersection outside Baltimore City, the State Highway Administration determines or, for a particular intersection in Baltimore City, the Baltimore City Department of Public Works determines that:

paragraph.text: ramps or curb cuts would be contrary to public safety;
the cost of ramps or curb cuts would be too great considering the need for them or their probable use; or
the sparsity of population, the existence of other ways, or other factors show the lack of a need for ramps or curb cuts.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section may be construed to prevent the State Highway Administration from certifying any project described in this section for the purpose of determining statewide eligibility for federal assistance.

section.text: Braille numbers or raised print numbers that indicate floors or levels shall be installed on the control panels in each elevator located in a public building.

subsection.text: As provided in the State budget, the Secretary of General Services shall provide, in central locations in units of the State and local government and other public facilities jointly recommended by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene and the State Superintendent of Schools, teletypewriters for the use of deaf individuals. These locations shall provide access to emergency police, fire, and rescue services.

The teletypewriters shall be connected electronically so as to provide a means of communication between deaf individuals and the offices of major public and private facilities equipped with similar machines within a toll-free telephone district.

Whenever a unit of the State or a local government gives out conventional public service telephone numbers to the public on written material, it shall also give out corresponding teletypewriter numbers on the written material. The teletypewriter numbers may be included at the time of stock replenishment.

section.text: In any place to which this subtitle applies, any toilet facility, ramp, building entrance, drinking fountain, parking, or walk that is usable by handicapped individuals shall be marked with a suitable symbol.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works, through the Department of General Services, shall publish minimum standards for facilities for handicapped individuals in public buildings. The standards shall conform to American Standards Association specification A 117.1-1961, as modified by the Department of General Services.
The standards may not require facilities for handicapped individuals in any part of a public building that is not open to or used by the general working force or the general public.

The appropriate contracting authority shall determine whether the plans and specifications for any public building built by the State, a political subdivision of the State, or a public authority meet the standards adopted under this section.
The standards shall be filed with the Secretary of State.
The Department of General Services is responsible for the enforcement of this subtitle if:

paragraph.text: any State capital nonschool funds are used; or
construction is on State-owned land.

subsection.text: The governing body of a political subdivision is responsible for the enforcement of this subtitle if:

paragraph.text: construction is not on State-owned land;
funds of the political subdivision are used; and
no State funds are used, except for State funds for school construction.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Facilities for the Handicapped Act”.
Each officer and unit of the State government shall send to the Treasurer, for inventory and safekeeping, each certificate of stock or other security certificate that the officer or unit holds.

subsection.text: The Treasurer shall deposit in a box or vault as provided in subsection (b) of this section:

paragraph.text: all of the physical securities that the State owns; and
all of the physical securities that, by State law, the Treasurer holds, in trust or otherwise, for a corporation or individual.
With the approval of the Board of Public Works, the Treasurer shall procure a box or vault.
The box or vault shall be located in the offices of the Treasurer.
Each box or vault in which securities are kept shall be built so that 2 different keys are needed to gain access to the securities.
The Comptroller and the Treasurer each shall have 1 of these keys.
Access to a box or vault in which physical securities are kept under this section shall be permitted only:

subparagraph.text: when the Governor, the Comptroller, the Chief Deputy Comptroller, or a Deputy Comptroller accompanies the Treasurer; or
if access is needed and the Treasurer cannot be present:

sub-subparagraph.text: when the Governor, the Comptroller, the Chief Deputy Comptroller, or a Deputy Comptroller accompanies the Chief Deputy Treasurer; or
when the Governor, the Comptroller, or the Chief Deputy Comptroller accompanies a Deputy Treasurer.

subsection.text: The Treasurer shall determine which physical securities are deposited or held in each box or vault.

section.text: The Treasurer shall maintain all securities other than physical securities with:

paragraph.text: any institution incorporated under the laws of the State as a State bank, trust company, or savings bank;
any national banking association that has its principal office in the State; or
any trust company, as defined in § 1-101 of the Estates and Trusts Article.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section and notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Treasurer may lend to a bank or securities broker any security that is owned by the State and is in the custody of the Treasurer.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer and the bank or broker to whom a loan is to be made under this section shall make a written contract that governs the loan.
The contract shall set forth:

subparagraph.text: the term of the loan;
the consideration for the loan;
any provisions that the Treasurer determines are needed to protect the interests of the State; and
any other conditions of the loan.

subsection.text: Consideration for a loan under this section may not be less than the current market lending rate for the securities on loan.

paragraph.text: The bank or broker to whom a loan is to be made under this section shall deposit with the Treasurer collateral with a value that equals or exceeds the value of the securities on loan.
Collateral that may be used under this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: money; or
a security in which the Treasurer may invest under § 6-222 or § 6-223 of this article.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer may enter into a contractual agreement with a financial institution to lend, as agent, securities owned by the State and in the custody of the Treasurer.
The financial institution shall provide security or indemnification acceptable to the Treasurer.

subsection.text: Whenever a certificate of stock that the State owns and holds has been lost or misplaced, the Treasurer, at the direction of the Board of Public Works, may obtain a duplicate certificate.
The State shall indemnify the corporation that issues the duplicate certificate.

section.text: In this subtitle, “ethnic affairs unit” means:

paragraph.text: the Commission on African American History and Culture;
the Commission on Indian Affairs; and
the Office of Asian–Pacific American Affairs.

subsection.text: In order to become more financially self-sufficient, an ethnic affairs unit:

paragraph.text: may receive funds from any person or organization; and
may not receive funds either directly or indirectly from the use of any gaming device or raised through a gaming event or activity.

subsection.text: An ethnic affairs unit receiving funds under this section shall be subject to an annual fiscal audit by the Legislative Auditor.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Budget and Management.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Budget and Management.

section.text: There is a Department of Budget and Management, established as a principal department of the State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the Secretary of Budget and Management, who shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Secretary must have experience in public finance, budgeting, management, and fiscal planning.
Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor. The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on those matters.

The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department. The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Department as necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to the Secretary.
The Secretary is responsible for establishing policy to be followed by the units in the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a Deputy Secretary.
The Deputy Secretary:

subparagraph.text: is in the executive service of the State Personnel Management System and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary;
is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
has the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall appoint 1 or more budget analysts.
Each budget analyst must:

subparagraph.text: have at least 3 years’ experience in personnel and other subjects that are related to the operation of a business organization;
be a graduate of a recognized school of business administration or have the additional experience that the Secretary requires; and
meet any other qualifications that the Secretary sets.

paragraph.text: The budget analysts shall:

subparagraph.text: continually conduct studies of all budget expenditures of units of the Executive Branch of the State government;
make recommendations to the Secretary for greater efficiency and economy in those units; and
perform any other duties that the Secretary assigns.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

Each assistant secretary and professional consultant is in the executive service, management service, or is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System and is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
Except as provided in this section or otherwise by law, the Secretary shall appoint and remove all other staff in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
The appointment or removal of staff of any unit in the Department is subject to the approval of the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Secretary is responsible for the budget of the Department.
The Secretary may adopt regulations for the Department and its units.
The Secretary may create any citizens’ advisory body that the Secretary considers necessary for the operation of the Department.
The Secretary shall have a seal.

paragraph.text: The Secretary is responsible for the comprehensive planning of programs and services of the Department.
The Secretary shall review the plans of the units in the Department and may approve or disapprove any of the plans.

section.text: The Secretary or staff of the Secretary shall be subject to call by the Senate or the House of Delegates or any of their committees, to provide information that the Secretary has.

subsection.text: The Attorney General is legal adviser to the Department.

paragraph.text: With the advice of the Secretary, the Attorney General shall assign at least 1 assistant Attorney General to the Central Collection Unit.
At the request of the Governor, the Attorney General shall assign to the Department:

subparagraph.text: at least 1 assistant Attorney General; and
any other assistant Attorneys General authorized by law to be assigned to the Department.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate 1 of the assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department as counsel to the Department. After the Attorney General designates the counsel to the Department, the Attorney General may not reassign the counsel without consulting the Secretary.

The counsel may have no duty other than to give the legal aid, advice, and counsel required by the Secretary or any other official of the Department, to supervise the other assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department and its Central Collection Unit, and to perform for the Department the duties that the Attorney General assigns. The counsel shall perform these duties subject to the control and supervision of the Attorney General.

subsection.text: Each assistant Attorney General who is assigned to the Central Collection Unit shall devote full time to the duties with that Unit and may have no other duties.

The Secretary may contract with another attorney to handle on an agreed case by case basis a collection for the Central Collection Unit if it is not feasible for any of the assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Unit to handle the collection.
There is a Central Collection Unit in the Department.

paragraph.text: All employees and personnel of the Central Collection Unit shall:

subparagraph.text: except for assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Central Collection Unit, be in the management service or special appointments in the State Personnel Management System who are appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Secretary and are not subject to Title 11, Subtitle 2 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; and
receive such compensation as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: Except for employees in the Executive Pay Plan and any assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Central Collection Unit, a management service or special appointment of the skilled service or the professional service employee of the Central Collection Unit may not be permanently removed except for cause and until written charges have been filed and a hearing has been conducted in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article. This paragraph does not apply to the removal of a management service or special appointment employee because of a layoff that resulted from:

subparagraph.text: a lack of work; or
the lack of an appropriation.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Budget and Management may establish a performance incentive program to provide pay incentives for employees of the Central Collection Unit.
Pay incentives provided to employees under this subsection shall be paid from the Central Collection Fund established under § 3-306 of this subtitle as provided in the State budget.
Pay incentives may not be provided under this subsection if:

subparagraph.text: the Central Collection Unit sustains an operating loss for the fiscal year in which the pay incentives were earned; or
funds are not available in the Central Collection Fund to pay the incentives.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section or in other law, the Central Collection Unit is responsible for the collection of each delinquent account or other debt that is owed to the State or any of its officials or units.

An official or unit of the State government shall refer to the Central Collection Unit each debt for which the Central Collection Unit has collection responsibility under this subsection and may not settle the debt.
For the purposes of this subtitle, a community college or board of trustees for a community college established or operating under Title 16 of the Education Article is a unit of the State.

subsection.text: Unless, with the approval of the Secretary, a unit of the State government assigns the claim to the Central Collection Unit, the Central Collection Unit is not responsible for and may not collect:

paragraph.text: any taxes;
any child support payment that is owed under § 5–308 of the Human Services Article;
any unemployment insurance contribution or overpayment;
any fine;
any court costs;
any forfeiture on bond;
any money that is owed as a result of a default on a loan that the Department of Business and Economic Development or the Department of Housing and Community Development has made or insured; or
any money that is owed under Title 9, Subtitles 2, 3, and 4 and Title 20 of the Insurance Article.

subsection.text: The Central Collection Unit shall be responsible for the collection of each delinquent account or other debt that is owed to a community college established or operating under Title 16 of the Education Article if the board of trustees for the community college:

paragraph.text: adopts a resolution appointing the Central Collection Unit as the collector of delinquent accounts or other debt; and
submits the resolution to the Central Collection Unit.

section.text: The Secretary may adopt regulations that relate to collections under this subtitle, including:

paragraph.text: procedures for referral of a debt or claim;
the information that supports the debt or claim; and
the rate of fees to be charged under § 3-304 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In carrying out its responsibilities, the Central Collection Unit may:

subparagraph.text: institute, in its name, any action that is available under State law for collection of a debt or claim; or
without suit, settle the debt or claim;

paragraph.text: for all debts or claims collected on or after June 1, 1992:

subparagraph.text: in addition to the outstanding principal and interest, assess and collect from the debtor a fee, which may not exceed 20% of the outstanding principal and interest, sufficient to cover all collection and administrative costs; and
prior to crediting any amount to any agency which refers a debt for any purpose, withhold a fee sufficient to cover all collection and administrative costs;

paragraph.text: waive or reduce any fee assessed under paragraph (2) of this subsection; and
certify a debt or claim and the debtor responsible for the debt or claim to:

subparagraph.text: the Comptroller for income tax refund interception in accordance with Title 13, Subtitle 9 of the Tax – General Article; and
the State Lottery Agency for State lottery prize interception in accordance with § 3–307 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In addition to the authority provided under subsection (a) of this section, and notwithstanding that the Central Collection Unit is a unit of the State government and that assistant Attorneys General represent the Unit, the Unit may enforce a statutory or written contractual obligation of a debtor to pay costs in addition to principal, including collection costs, counsel fees, or interest penalties.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Central Collection Unit may report any account referred to it under this section to a consumer reporting agency.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Central Collection Unit shall pay the net proceeds of collections into the State Treasury.

If the funds of a unit of the State government are not part of the State Treasury, the Central Collection Unit shall deliver to the Treasurer the net proceeds of collection on a debt or claim that was due to the unit of the State government for its account.
All fees collected under § 3-304(a)(2) of this subtitle shall be credited to the Central Collection Fund established under § 3-306 of this subtitle.

The Central Collection Unit shall deliver the net proceeds of collections from defendants or liable parents in arrears on restitution payments to the Division of Parole and Probation or the Department of Juvenile Services to be forwarded by the Division or Department to the victim or other appropriate person or agency in accordance with the judgment of restitution.
There is a Central Collection Fund.
The Central Collection Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of this article.
The Fund shall consist of all fees collected under § 3–304(a)(2) of this subtitle.
Subject to the appropriation process in the State budget and subject to subsection (h) of this section, the Department shall use the Fund for the expenses of operating the Central Collection Unit.
The State Treasurer shall hold and the State Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Fund shall be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other State funds.
Investment earnings accrue to the benefit of the Fund.

For any fiscal year beginning on or after July 1, 2010, any balance in the Fund at the end of the fiscal year in excess of 15% of the actual expenses of operating the Central Collection Unit for that fiscal year reverts to the General Fund of the State.
Certification of a debt or claim owed to the State that the Central Collection Unit sends to the State Lottery Agency under § 3–304(a)(4) of this subtitle shall contain:

paragraph.text: the full name of the debtor and any other name known to be used by the debtor;
the Social Security number of the debtor; and
the amount of the debt.

subsection.text: If a debtor wins a lottery prize to be paid directly by the State Lottery Agency, the State Lottery Agency shall notify the debtor that:

paragraph.text: the debtor has won a prize to be paid by the State Lottery Agency;
the State Lottery Agency has received notice from the Central Collection Unit of the debtor’s debt or claim owed to the State in the specified amount;
State law requires the State Lottery Agency to withhold the prize and to pay it towards the debtor’s debt or claim;
the debtor may appeal to the Central Collection Unit if the debtor disputes the existence or the amount of the debt or claim; and

if an appeal is not filed within 15 days after the date of the notice, the State Lottery Agency will transfer the prize or the part of the prize that equals the amount of the debt or claim to the Central Collection Unit.

The State Lottery Agency shall withhold all or part of the prize up to the amount of the debt or claim owed to the State until the Central Collection Unit notifies the State Lottery Agency to whom the withheld prize money is to be paid.
The State Lottery Agency shall honor lottery prize interception requests in the following order:

subparagraph.text: an interception request under § 10–113.1 of the Family Law Article;
an interception request under § 11–618 of the Criminal Procedure Article; and
an interception request under this section.

paragraph.text: On receipt of a notice from the State Lottery Agency, a debtor who disputes the existence or amount of the debt or claim may appeal the proposed transfer in accordance with the provisions of the Administrative Procedure Act, Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
If an appeal is not filed within 15 days after the date of the notice, the State Lottery Agency shall transfer the amount of the prize withheld to the Central Collection Unit.
If the debtor appeals the proposed transfer, after a hearing the Central Collection Unit shall notify the State Lottery Agency that the withheld prize shall be:

subparagraph.text: paid to the debtor;
transferred to the Central Collection Unit; or
in specified amounts, partly paid to the debtor and partly transferred to the Central Collection Unit.

subsection.text: The Secretary and the Director of the State Lottery Agency may jointly adopt regulations to carry out this section.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the purchase, lease, or rental of motor vehicles by the University College of the University of Maryland for use in University College overseas programs or by the Maryland Port Administration.

subsection.text: Consistent with Division II of this article, the Secretary shall approve and submit to the Board of Public Works for concurrence:

paragraph.text: standards for purchase by the Department of General Services of motor vehicles for State use; and

all leases or rentals of motor vehicles for use by officials or employees of any unit of the Executive Branch of the State government, other than any individual motor vehicle lease or rental made under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: As far as practicable and feasible, the standards for purchase of motor vehicles shall be based on the lowest possible life cycle cost.

The purchase of State-owned motor vehicles for any unit of the Executive Branch of the State government shall be reviewed and approved by the Secretary before the purchase to ensure compliance with this section and § 3-503 of this subtitle and any implementing regulations.

paragraph.text: To ensure economical and efficient use of motor vehicles by units of the Executive Branch of the State government, the Secretary shall adopt and enforce regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.
The regulations adopted under this section shall apply to:

subparagraph.text: all phases of the use and maintenance of State-owned motor vehicles; and
the reimbursement of owners of privately owned motor vehicles.

paragraph.text: The regulations shall be directed to:

subparagraph.text: requiring the effective, efficient, and inexpensive use of all motor vehicles; and
compiling and maintaining accurate and detailed cost accounting records for all use of motor vehicles.

paragraph.text: The regulations shall provide that, unless the Secretary determines on the basis of published criteria that the use of a State-owned motor vehicle is required for the efficient operation of a State program regardless of miles traveled, State-owned motor vehicles shall be allocated to those State employees accumulating the greatest mileage for official use.

subsection.text: Consistent with this section, the Secretary may reassign State-owned motor vehicles between or among units of the Executive Branch of the State government if federally funded programs are substantially reduced or discontinued.
Subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the Secretary shall submit to the General Assembly an annual report that includes, in detail:

paragraph.text: the text of any regulations that have been adopted under this section and are currently in effect; and
a statement of any problems involved in ensuring compliance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: To establish relative priorities and avoid duplication and conflicts, the Department shall advise the Governor on the means and methods available to coordinate the capital plans and capital programs of all units of the State government. Upon request of the General Assembly, the Department shall provide assistance to the General Assembly in the development and coordination of capital plans and capital programs for the Legislative Branch of State government.

To avoid duplication and conflicts, the Department shall advise the Governor on the means and methods available to coordinate the capital plans and capital programs of federal, State, regional, and local governments.
The Department shall study each capital project proposed by any unit of the State government.

Except for a capital project designated as an emergency by the unit of the State government proposing the project, any unit of the State government requesting a capital project shall submit its request to the Department on or before June 30 of the fiscal year preceding the fiscal year in which the capital project is to begin.

Each request for a capital project by a unit of the State government, including the University System of Maryland, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and Morgan State University, shall include a detailed list of all proposed expenditures for capital improvements to be funded from grants or nonbudgeted revenues.

paragraph.text: Before an appropriation may be authorized for preliminary planning of a proposed capital project:

subparagraph.text: the unit of the State government requesting the appropriation shall submit to the Department a program describing, in detail, the scope and purpose of the project; and
the Secretary of Budget and Management must approve the program.

paragraph.text: Before an appropriation may be authorized for construction of a proposed capital project:

subparagraph.text: the unit of State government requesting the appropriation shall submit to the Departments of Budget and Management and General Services a detailed design program, which shall include all information required by the Departments; and
both the Secretary of Budget and Management and the Secretary of General Services must approve the detailed design program.

subsection.text: Except with the approval of the Secretary of Budget and Management and the Secretary of General Services, no change may be made in any proposed capital project after the preliminary plan for that project has been completed and approved.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to capital projects that involve construction of permanent or long-time duration.

When the request for an appropriation for a capital project is submitted to the General Assembly, the unit of the State government that would receive the capital project or a State officer on behalf of the unit shall submit to the General Assembly:

subparagraph.text: preliminary plans and outline specifications for the project that show the size, the type of construction, and the arrangement of each building; and
a statement on the sufficiency of the proposed appropriation to pay fully for the costs of that project.

subsection.text: Total project funding may utilize alternative construction methods, such as:

paragraph.text: design/build which involves a single solicitation to design and build the facility; or
“fast track” in which design and construction are implemented concurrently.

subsection.text: A request for total project funding may be authorized jointly by the Secretaries of Budget and Management and General Services if:

subparagraph.text: the planning, design, construction, and equipment funds for the project have been authorized and itemized in the State budget bill or a supplementary appropriation bill; or
the Secretaries make a determination, supported in writing and submitted to the Legislative Policy Committee of the General Assembly and the Board of Public Works, that:

sub-subparagraph.text: total project funding is time critical and will result in significant cost savings;
there is compelling reason why the procedure required in this paragraph cannot be adopted; and
circumstances necessitate that consideration of the total project funding occur during the legislative interim, rather than during the legislative session; and

subparagraph.text: the total project funding request has been submitted to the Legislative Policy Committee for its review and comment;
written comment from the Legislative Policy Committee has been received or 45 days have elapsed after the Legislative Policy Committee has received the request and all supporting information; and
the request has been approved by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: The submissions and approvals required by subsections (b) through (h) of this section are not required in connection with any capital project funded by the Transportation Trust Fund.

“Total project funding” means the funding for the planning, design, construction, and equipment of a capital project through a single appropriation or authorization or through a proposed capital lease.

“Capital lease” means any lease, defined as a capital lease in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, that is used to finance the acquisition, purchase, construction, and any related renovation or alteration of real property that is the subject of a capital project.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“High performance building” means a building that:

subparagraph.text: meets or exceeds the current version of the U.S. Green Building Council’s LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) Green Building Rating System Silver rating; or

achieves at least a comparable numeric rating according to a nationally recognized, accepted, and appropriate numeric sustainable development rating system, guideline, or standard approved by the Secretaries of Budget and Management and General Services.

paragraph.text: “Major renovation” means the renovation of a building where:

subparagraph.text: the building shell is to be reused for the new construction;
the heating, ventilating, and air conditioning (HVAC), electrical, and plumbing systems are to be replaced; and
the scope of the renovation is 7,500 square feet or greater.

subsection.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly that, to the extent practicable:

paragraph.text: the State shall employ green building technologies when constructing or renovating a State building not subject to this section; and
high performance buildings shall meet the criteria and standards established under the “High Performance Green Building Program” adopted by the Maryland Green Building Council.
This subsection applies to:

subparagraph.text: capital projects that are funded solely with State funds; and
community college capital projects that receive State funds.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this section, if a capital project includes the construction or major renovation of a building that is 7,500 square feet or greater, the building shall be constructed or renovated to be a high performance building.

subsection.text: The following types of unoccupied buildings are not required to be constructed or renovated to be high performance buildings:

paragraph.text: warehouse and storage facilities;
garages;
maintenance facilities;
transmitter buildings;
pumping stations; and
other similar types of buildings, as determined by the Department.

The Department of Budget and Management and the Department of General Services shall jointly establish a process to allow a unit of State government or a community college to obtain a waiver from complying with subsection (c) of this section.
The waiver process shall:

subparagraph.text: include a review by the Maryland Green Building Council established under § 4–809 of this article, to determine if the use of a high performance building in a proposed capital project is not practicable; and
require the approval of a waiver by the Secretaries of Budget and Management, General Services, and Transportation.

subsection.text: The Department shall prepare, revise, and keep current a 5-year capital program.
The capital program shall include all capital projects of the State whether funded by bond authorizations, operating budget funds, or capital leases.
The capital program shall be consistent with the annual recommendations of the Capital Debt Affordability Committee.

Except for the first year of the program, the capital program may not include General Fund capital appropriations as a source of funding other than for projects or programs that are ineligible for tax-exempt debt financing.

section.text: The capital program:

paragraph.text: shall include State public works and major capital improvement projects undertaken or recommended to be undertaken by the State; and
may include major projects undertaken or recommended to be undertaken with State aid or under State regulation.

section.text: The capital program shall:

paragraph.text: classify projects according to their necessity and urgency;
recommend a time sequence for the projects; and
include the following information about each project:

subparagraph.text: the contract price or an estimate of the cost of acquisition or construction;
an estimate of the operating and maintenance costs;
an estimate of the number of additional State positions that will be required as a result of the project;
an estimate of revenues likely to be received from the project; and
existing sources of funds or the need for additional sources of funds for construction, acquisition, and operation.

section.text: As far as possible, the capital program shall be based on existing information in the possession of the Department of Budget and Management, and other units of the State government.
The Department of Budget and Management may require the head of any unit of the State government to give information necessary for the preparation of the capital program.

subsection.text: In the annual budget the Governor shall provide a sum sufficient to establish a Revolving Preliminary Planning Fund under the jurisdiction of the Board of Public Works.

On the recommendation of the Department, the Board of Public Works may authorize money to be advanced from the Revolving Preliminary Planning Fund for preliminary plans, studies, designs, and outline specifications for any project that is part of the capital improvement program.
Any money advanced from the Revolving Preliminary Planning Fund shall be reimbursed to the Fund:

paragraph.text: from general funds; or
with the approval of the Board of Public Works, from:

subparagraph.text: the annual general construction loan; or
any other special loan funds separately authorized by the General Assembly.

subsection.text: There is a Construction Contingency Fund.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing, revolving fund that consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated to the Fund:

subparagraph.text: in the annual budget; or
in an annual General Construction Loan Act or in a Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loan Act; or

paragraph.text: unspent proceeds of an enabling act allocated to the Fund by the Governor under § 8-129 of this article; or

the amount of an appropriation in an annual General Construction Loan Act or in a Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loan Act that is in excess of the amount needed for a project included in the Act and that is allocated to the Fund by the Governor.

subsection.text: An appropriation or allocation to the Fund may not be made if it would cause the total balance in the Fund to exceed 1.25% of the capital debt affordability limit, determined under Title 8 of this article, for that year.
With the advice and assistance of the Departments of Budget and Management and General Services, the Fund shall be administered by the Board of Public Works.

With the approval of the Governor, the Secretaries of Budget and Management and General Services may request the Board of Public Works to authorize an expenditure from the Fund to supplement any capital appropriation or to conduct value engineering on a project:

paragraph.text: that is for a capital project to be owned by the State or a unit of the State government;
that was contained in a capital appropriation of an annual budget, in an annual general construction loan, or in an annual Maryland consolidated capital bond loan; and

subparagraph.text: that is insufficient in amount to permit the initial award of a contract for the project to the bidder or offeror selected in accordance with applicable State law, or to cover change orders during construction of the project which do not increase the scope of the project; or
if, in the belief of the Department of General Services or at the request of the budget committees, the project cost could be reduced or quality improved through the use of value engineering.

subsection.text: The Secretaries of Budget and Management and General Services shall evaluate any project for additional funding and certify in writing that the project meets the criteria in subsection (e) of this section and that:

paragraph.text: all reasonable attempts to reduce the cost of the project have been made;
no practicable alternative exists for securing funding to complete the project; and
the requested additional funding does not increase the scope of the project.
Prior to seeking approval from the Board of Public Works, the Department of General Services and the Department of Budget and Management shall:

subparagraph.text: provide written notice to the budget committees on the planned use of the funds; and
allow 45 days for review and comment by the budget committees.

paragraph.text: Each time an expenditure from the Fund is authorized by the Board of Public Works, the amount specified by the Board of Public Works may be transferred from the account to the appropriate annuity bond account to supplement the specified authorization.

subsection.text: By January 1 of each year, the Secretaries of Budget and Management and General Services shall submit a report, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the moneys:

paragraph.text: appropriated to the Fund;
authorized for expenditure from the Fund; and
expended from the Fund.

subsection.text: Money in the Fund shall be deposited with the State Treasurer.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agency” means an entity of the Executive Branch of State government.

“Goal” means a broad statement that describes the desired long–term results toward which an agency directs its efforts. Goals support, clarify, and provide direction to the agency’s mission and assist in the application of State resources toward implementation of the managing for results State comprehensive plan.

“Managing for results” means a planning, performance measurement, and budgeting process that emphasizes use of resources to achieve measurable results, accountability, efficiency, and continuous improvement in State government programs.
“Mission” means the purpose for an agency’s existence and includes a description of what an agency does and for whom it does it.
“Objective” means a specific and measurable short–term target for achievement of an agency’s goals and includes a description of the desired results and a target date for accomplishment.

paragraph.text: “Performance measure” means a quantitative or qualitative indicator used to assess whether an agency is meeting its goals and objectives.
“Performance measure” includes the following:

subparagraph.text: an efficiency measure that quantifies the relationship between measures of the inputs used to produce goods or services and the measures of the outputs of these activities;
an input measure that quantifies the amount of resources used to provide goods and services;
an outcome measure that quantifies the results an agency achieves or the benefits citizens receive from an agency’s activities;
an output measure that quantifies the amount of goods and services produced by the agency; and
a quality measure that quantifies or describes:

sub-subparagraph.text: the effectiveness of the agency in meeting agency objectives;
aspects of the satisfaction that customers may or may not have with State goods or services; or
how State goods or services compare to some external or internal standard.

subsection.text: “State comprehensive plan” means a statement of goals which serve as a broad directive for improving or making more cost effective State resources and services. The plan shall include no more than 10 statewide goals and 50 to 100 performance measures that describe the statewide progress towards its goals.
“StateStat” means the accountability process described in § 3–1003(b) of this subtitle.
“Strategic plan” means a statement of direction implemented by an agency to carry out its mission.
The Department shall review and update as necessary:

paragraph.text: the goals developed in the managing for results State comprehensive plan; and
the plan’s objectives and performance measures.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, on or before July 1 of each year an agency, in conjunction with the Department, shall select no more than six agency goals that are:

paragraph.text: compatible with the managing for results State comprehensive plan; or
consistent with the agency’s mission if the goals identified in the managing for results State comprehensive plan do not apply to the agency.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, with its annual budget submission to the Department, an agency shall develop and submit to the Department as part of the budget process a managing for results agency strategic plan that shall include:

paragraph.text: a mission statement;
a description of the agency’s goals;
a description of the objectives and performance measures implemented at the program level to achieve the agency’s goals, including:

subparagraph.text: performance measure statistics for at least the 2 most recently completed fiscal years; and
performance measure estimates for the current year appropriation and budget request year;

paragraph.text: a discussion of the agency’s progress in meeting its goals and performance measures and any challenges the agency has faced in working toward its goals;
a description of the internal controls established to ensure reliability of the data collected for each performance measure; and
an identification of the customers and stakeholders served.

subsection.text: An agency subject to this subtitle shall maintain documentation of the internal controls established to evaluate performance measures that shall be subject to review by the State, including the Office of Legislative Audits.

paragraph.text: The Department shall provide a report to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and House Appropriations Committee in January of each year on the contents of the State comprehensive plan and the State’s progress toward the goals outlined in the plan.
The report shall include details on each agency’s progress.
The Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and House Appropriations Committee may hold hearings after receiving the report.
The first report shall be submitted on or before January 31, 2005 and shall include a presentation of the first managing for results State comprehensive plan.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall review the strategic plans and the State comprehensive plan and may recommend appropriate changes to agency budgets.

paragraph.text: There is a StateStat process that is managed by the Executive Branch.
StateStat is an accountability process that involves:

subparagraph.text: the adoption of a strategic plan and the establishment of goals by an agency;
the adoption of a comprehensive set of performance and citizen satisfaction measurements by an agency;
regular and frequent:

sub-subparagraph.text: submission of timely and accurate data by an agency;
review and analysis of submitted data; and
accountability meetings to assess an agency’s performance;

subparagraph.text: continuous review of the strategies and tactics used by an agency to meet the goals of the agency; and
continuous assessment of the progress of an agency towards meeting the goals of the agency.

subsection.text: The Governor may require an agency to participate in the StateStat process to help facilitate and accelerate the achievement of managing for results goals and objectives.

paragraph.text: Each agency that participates in the StateStat process shall submit a strategic plan and performance measurement report to the Secretary as part of its annual budget submission.
The report submitted by each agency that participates in the StateStat process shall contain the information required in § 3–1002(c) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Information Technology.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Information Technology.
“Telecommunication” means the transmission of information, images, pictures, voice, or data by radio, video, or other electronic or impulse means.
“Unit of State government” means an agency or unit of the Executive Branch of State government.

section.text: There is a Department of Information Technology established as a principal department of State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the Secretary of Information Technology, who shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Secretary shall have experience in information technology, data processing, telecommunications, and systems procurement, planning, and management.
Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.
