The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on those matters.
The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and may establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department.
The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Department necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to the Secretary.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a Deputy Secretary.
The Deputy Secretary:

subparagraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the Secretary;
is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
has the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.

subsection.text: Each assistant secretary and professional consultant is in the executive service, management service, or is a special appointment in the State personnel management system and is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
Except as provided in this section or otherwise by law, the Secretary shall appoint and remove all other staff in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
The appointment of or removal of staff of any unit in the Department is subject to the approval of the Secretary.
The Attorney General is legal adviser to the Department.
At the request of the Governor, the Attorney General shall assign to the Department the number of assistant Attorneys General authorized by law to be assigned to the Department.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate one of the assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department as counsel to the Department.
After the Attorney General designates the counsel to the Department, the Attorney General may not reassign the counsel without consulting the Secretary.

subparagraph.text: The counsel may have no other duty other than to:

sub-subparagraph.text: give the legal aid, advice, and counsel required by the Secretary or any other official of the Department;
supervise the other assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department; and
perform for the Department the duties that the Attorney General assigns.

subparagraph.text: The counsel shall perform these duties subject to the control and supervision of the Attorney General.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Development” means all expenditures for a new information technology system or an enhancement to an existing system including system:

subparagraph.text: planning;
procurement;
creation;
installation;
testing; and
initial training.

paragraph.text: “Development” does not include:

subparagraph.text: ongoing operating costs, software or hardware maintenance, routine upgrades, or modifications that merely allow for a continuation of the existing level of functionality; or
expenditures made after a new or enhanced system has been legally accepted by the user and is being used for the business process for which it was intended.

subsection.text: “Fund” means the Major Information Technology Development Project Fund.
“Information technology” means all electronic information processing hardware and software, including:

paragraph.text: maintenance;
telecommunications; and
associated consulting services.

subsection.text: “Information technology services” means information provided by electronic means by or on behalf of a unit of State government.
“Major information technology development project” means any information technology development project that meets one or more of the following criteria:

paragraph.text: the estimated total cost of development equals or exceeds $1,000,000;
the project is undertaken to support a critical business function associated with the public health, education, safety, or financial well–being of the citizens of Maryland; or
the Secretary determines that the project requires the special attention and consideration given to a major information technology development project due to:

subparagraph.text: the significance of the project’s potential benefits or risks;
the impact of the project on the public or local governments;
the public visibility of the project; or
other reasons as determined by the Secretary.

subsection.text: “Master plan” means the statewide information technology master plan.

“Nonvisual access” means the ability, through keyboard control, synthesized speech, Braille, or other methods not requiring sight to receive, use, and manipulate information and operate controls necessary to access information technology.
“Resource sharing” means the utilization of a State resource by private industry in exchange for the provision to the State of a communication service or other consideration.

“Systems development life cycle plan” means a plan that defines all actions, functions, or activities to be performed by a unit of State government in the definition, planning, acquisition, development, testing, implementation, operation, enhancement, and modification of information technology systems.
This subtitle does not apply to changes relating to or the purchase, lease, or rental of information technology by:

paragraph.text: public institutions of higher education solely for academic or research purposes;
the Maryland Port Administration;
the University System of Maryland;
St. Mary’s College of Maryland; or
Morgan State University.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, except as provided in subsection (a) of this section and §§ 3A–307(a)(2), 3A–308, and 3A–309 of this subtitle, this subtitle applies to all units of the Executive Branch of State government including public institutions of higher education other than Morgan State University, the University System of Maryland, and St. Mary’s College of Maryland.

section.text: The Secretary is responsible for carrying out the following duties:

paragraph.text: developing, maintaining, revising, and enforcing information technology policies, procedures, and standards;
providing technical assistance, advice, and recommendations to the Governor and any unit of State government concerning information technology matters;
reviewing the annual project plan for each unit of State government to make information and services available to the public over the Internet;
developing and maintaining a statewide information technology master plan that will:

subparagraph.text: be the basis for the management and direction of information technology within the Executive Branch of State government;
include all aspects of State information technology including telecommunications, data processing, and information management;
consider interstate transfers as a result of federal legislation and regulation;
work jointly with the Secretary of Budget and Management to ensure that information technology plans and budgets are consistent;

ensure that State information technology plans, policies, and standards are consistent with State goals, objectives, and resources, and represent a long–range vision for using information technology to improve the overall effectiveness of State government; and
include standards to assure nonvisual access to the information and services made available to the public over the Internet; and

paragraph.text: adopting by regulation and enforcing nonvisual access standards to be used in the procurement of information technology services by or on behalf of units of State government.

section.text: The Secretary shall develop a statewide information technology master plan.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, in accordance with guidelines established by the Secretary, each unit of State government shall develop and submit to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: information technology policies and standards;
an information technology plan; and
an annual project plan outlining the status of efforts to make information and services available to the public over the Internet.

The governing boards of the public institutions of higher education shall develop and submit information technology policies and standards and an information technology plan for their respective institutions or systems to the Secretary.
If the Secretary finds that the submissions required under this subsection are consistent with the master plan, the Secretary shall incorporate those submissions into the master plan.
If the Secretary finds that the submissions required under this subsection are not consistent with the master plan:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary shall return the submissions to the governing boards; and
the governing boards shall revise the submissions as appropriate and submit the revised policies, standards, and plans to the Secretary.

section.text: Information technology of each unit of State government shall be consistent with the master plan.

paragraph.text: A unit of State government may not purchase, lease, or rent information technology unless consistent with the master plan.

A unit of State government other than a public institution of higher education may not make expenditures for major information technology development projects except as provided in § 3A–308 of this subtitle.
The Secretary may review any information technology project for consistency with the master plan.
Any information technology project selected for review may not be implemented without the approval of the Secretary.

A unit of State government shall advise the Secretary of any information technology proposal involving resource sharing, the exchange of goods or services, or a gift, contribution, or grant of real or personal property.

The Secretary shall determine if the value of the resources, services, and property to be obtained by the State under the terms of any proposal submitted in accordance with the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection equals or exceeds $100,000.

If the value of any proposal submitted in accordance with this subsection equals or exceeds $100,000 and the Secretary and unit agree to proceed with the proposal, information on the proposal shall be:

subparagraph.text: advertised for a period of at least 30 days in the eMaryland Marketplace; and

submitted, simultaneously with the advertisement, to the Legislative Policy Committee for a 60–day review and comment period, during which time the Committee may recommend that the proposal be treated as a procurement contract under Division II of this article.

paragraph.text: Following the period for review and comment by the Legislative Policy Committee under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the proposal is subject to approval by the Board of Public Works.

This subsection may not be construed as authorizing an exception from the requirements of Division II of this article for any contract that otherwise would be subject to the State procurement process.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a public institution of higher education.
In submitting its information technology project requests, a unit of State government shall designate projects which are major information technology development projects.
In reviewing information technology project requests, the Secretary may change a unit’s designation of a major information technology development project.

The Secretary shall review and, with the advice of the Secretary of Budget and Management, approve major information technology development projects and specifications for consistency with all statewide plans, policies, and standards, including a systems development life cycle plan.
The Secretary shall be responsible for overseeing the implementation of major information technology development projects, regardless of fund source.

With the advice of the Secretary of Budget and Management, expenditures for major information technology development projects shall be subject to the approval of the Secretary who shall approve expenditures only when those projects are consistent with statewide plans, policies, and standards.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall approve funding for major information technology development projects only when those projects are supported by an approved systems development life cycle plan.
An approved systems development life cycle plan shall include submission of:

subparagraph.text: a project planning request that details initial planning for the project, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the project title, appropriation code, and summary;
a description of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the needs addressed by the project;
the potential risks associated with the project;
possible alternatives; and
the scope and complexity of the project; and

sub-subparagraph.text: an estimate of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the total costs required to complete through planning; and
the fund sources available to support planning costs; and

subparagraph.text: a project implementation request to begin full design, development, and implementation of the project after the completion of planning, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the project title, appropriation code, and summary;
a description of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the needs addressed by the project;
the potential risks associated with the project;
possible alternatives;
the scope and complexity of the project; and
how the project meets the goals of the statewide master plan; and

sub-subparagraph.text: an estimate of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the total project cost; and
the fund sources available.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may approve funding incrementally, consistent with the systems development life cycle plan.

subsection.text: There is a Major Information Technology Development Project Fund.
The purpose of the Fund is to support major information technology development projects.
The Secretary:

paragraph.text: shall administer the Fund in accordance with this section; and
subject to the provisions of § 2–201 of this article and § 3A–307 of this subtitle, may receive and accept contributions, grants, or gifts of money or property.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of this article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The State Treasurer shall invest and reinvest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, the Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
money received from the sale, lease, or exchange of communication sites or communication frequencies for information technology purposes as approved by the Secretary;
that portion of moneys earned from pay phone commissions to the extent that the commission rates exceed those in effect in December 1993;
money received and accepted as contributions, grants, or gifts as authorized under subsection (c) of this section;
general funds appropriated for major information technology development projects of any unit of State government other than a public institution of higher education that:

subparagraph.text: are unencumbered and unexpended at the end of a fiscal year;
have been abandoned; or
have been withheld by the General Assembly or the Secretary;

paragraph.text: any investment earnings; and
any other money from any source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund does not include any money:

paragraph.text: received by the Department of Transportation, Maryland Transportation Authority, or Maryland Public Broadcasting Commission;
received by the Judicial or Legislative branches of State government; or

generated from pay phone commissions that are credited to other accounts or funds in accordance with other provisions of law or are authorized for other purposes in the State budget or through an approved budget amendment.

subsection.text: The Governor shall submit with the State budget:

paragraph.text: a summary showing the unencumbered balance in the Fund as of the close of the prior fiscal year and a listing of any encumbrances;
an estimate of projected revenue from each of the sources specified in subsection (e) of this section for the fiscal year for which the State budget is submitted; and
a descriptive listing of projects reflecting projected costs for the fiscal year for which the State budget is submitted and any estimated future year costs.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund shall be made only:

paragraph.text: in accordance with an appropriation approved by the General Assembly in the annual State budget; or

through an approved State budget amendment under Title 7, Subtitle 2, Part II of this article, provided that a State budget amendment for any project not requested as part of the State budget submission or for any project for which the scope or cost has increased by more than 5% or $250,000 shall be submitted to the budget committees allowing a 30–day period for their review and comment.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used:

paragraph.text: for major information technology development projects;
as provided in subsection (j) of this section; or
notwithstanding § 3A–301(b)(2) of this subtitle, for the costs of the first 12 months of operation and maintenance of a major information technology development project.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section and except for the cost incurred in administering the Fund, each fiscal year up to $1,000,000 of this Fund may be used for:

paragraph.text: educationally related information technology projects;
application service provider initiatives as provided for in Title 9, Subtitle 22 of the State Government Article; or
information technology projects, including:

subparagraph.text: pilots; and
prototypes.

subsection.text: A unit of State government or local government may submit a request to the Secretary to support the cost of an information technology project with moneys under subsection (j) of this section.

paragraph.text: On or before November 1 of each year, the Secretary shall report to the Governor, the Secretary of Budget and Management, and to the budget committees of the General Assembly and submit a copy of the report to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: the financial status of the Fund and a summary of its operations for the preceding fiscal year;
an accounting for the preceding fiscal year of all moneys from each of the revenue sources specified in subsection (e) of this section, including any expenditures made from the Fund; and

for each project receiving moneys from the Fund in the preceding fiscal year and for each major information technology development project receiving funding from any source other than the Fund in the preceding fiscal year:

sub-subparagraph.text: the status of the project;
a comparison of estimated and actual costs of the project;
any known or anticipated changes in scope or costs of the project;
an evaluation of whether the project is using best practices; and

a summary of any monitoring and oversight of the project from outside the agency in which the project is being developed, including a description of any problems identified by any external review and any corrective actions taken.

subsection.text: On or before January 15 of each year, for each major information technology development project currently in development or for which operations and maintenance funding is being provided in accordance with subsection (i)(3) of this section, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the Secretary shall provide a summary report to the Department of Legislative Services with the most up–to–date project information including:

paragraph.text: project status;
any schedule, cost, and scope changes since the last annual report;
a risk assessment including any problems identified by any internal or external review and any corrective actions taken; and
any change in the monitoring or oversight status.

section.text: This subtitle may not be construed to give the Secretary authority over:

paragraph.text: the content of educational applications or curriculum at the State or local level; or
the entities that may participate in such educational programs.

subsection.text: The Secretary, in consultation with other units of State government, and after public comment, shall develop a nonvisual access clause for use in the procurement of information technology and information technology services that specifies that the technology and services:

paragraph.text: must provide equivalent access for effective use by both visual and nonvisual means;
will present information, including prompts used for interactive communications, in formats intended for both visual and nonvisual use;
can be integrated into networks for obtaining, retrieving, and disseminating information used by individuals who are not blind or visually impaired; and
shall be obtained, whenever possible, without modification for compatibility with software and hardware for nonvisual access.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the nonvisual access clause required under subsection (a) of this section shall be included in each invitation for bids or request for proposals and in each procurement contract or modification of a contract issued under Title 13 of this article, without regard to the method chosen under Title 13, Subtitle 1 of this article for the purchase of new or upgraded information technology and information technology services.
Except as provided in subsection (a)(4) of this section, the nonvisual access clause required under paragraph (1) of this subsection is not required if:

subparagraph.text: the information technology is not available with nonvisual access because the essential elements of the information technology are visual and nonvisual equivalence cannot be developed; or
the cost of modifying the information technology for compatibility with software and hardware for nonvisual access would increase the price of the procurement by more than 5%.

section.text: The Secretary may delegate the duties set forth in this subtitle to carry out its purposes.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Payee” means any party who receives from the State an aggregate payment of $25,000 in a fiscal year.
“Payee” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a State employee with respect to the employee’s compensation; or
a State retiree with respect to the retiree’s retirement allowance.

paragraph.text: “Searchable website” means a website created in accordance with this section that displays and searches State payment data.

subsection.text: On or before January 1, 2009, the Department shall develop and operate a single searchable website, accessible to the public at no cost through the Internet.
The searchable website shall contain State payment data, including:

paragraph.text: the name of a payee receiving a payment;
the location of a payee by postal zip code;
the amount of a payment; and
the name of an agency making a payment.

subsection.text: The searchable website shall allow the user to:

paragraph.text: search data for fiscal year 2008 and each year thereafter; and
search by the following data fields:

subparagraph.text: a payee receiving a payment;
an agency making a payment; and
the zip code of a payee receiving a payment.

subsection.text: State agencies shall provide appropriate assistance to the Secretary to ensure the existence and ongoing operation of the single website.
This section may not be construed to require the disclosure of information that is confidential under State or federal law.
This section shall be known and may be cited as the “Maryland Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2008”.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: coordinate the development, procurement, management, and operation of telecommunication equipment, systems, and services by State government;

acquire and manage common user telecommunication equipment, systems, or services and charge units of State government for their proportionate share of the costs of installation, maintenance, and operation of the common user telecommunication equipment, systems, or services;

promote compatibility of telecommunication systems by developing policies, procedures, and standards for the acquisition and use of telecommunication equipment, systems, and services by units of State government;
coordinate State government telecommunication systems and services by reviewing requests by units of State government for telecommunication equipment, systems, or services;
advise units of State government about planning, acquisition, and operation of telecommunication equipment, systems, or services; and
provide radio frequency coordination for State and local governments in accordance with regulations of the Federal Communications Commission.

subsection.text: The Department may make arrangement for a user other than a unit of State government to have access to and use of State telecommunication equipment, systems, and services and shall charge the user any appropriate amount to cover the cost of installation, maintenance, and operation of the telecommunication equipment, system, or service provided.

The provisions of this subtitle do not apply to a telecommunication system or service that is owned or operated by the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, or a unit of the Legislative or Judicial Branch.
The provisions of this subtitle do not preempt the authority of the Maryland Public Broadcasting Commission to own, operate, or manage telecommunication equipment, systems, or services.

section.text: Telecommunications, including those of the Maryland Public Broadcasting System, shall be consistent with statewide information technology policies and standards and the statewide information technology master plan.

subsection.text: The General Assembly declares that:

paragraph.text: it is the policy of the State to foster telecommunication and computer networking among State and local governments, their agencies, and educational institutions in the State;
there is a need to improve access, especially in rural areas, to efficient telecommunication and computer network connections;

improvement of telecommunication and computer networking for State and local governments and educational institutions promotes economic development, educational resource use and development, and efficiency in State and local administration;

rates for the intrastate inter–LATA telephone communications needed for effective integration of telecommunication and computer resources are prohibitive for many smaller governments, agencies, and institutions; and

the use of improved State telecommunication and computer networking under this section is intended not to compete with commercial access to advanced network technology, but rather to foster fundamental efficiencies in government and education for the public good.
The Department shall establish a telecommunication and computer network in the State.
The network shall consist of:

subparagraph.text: one or more connection facilities for telecommunication and computer connection in each local access transport area (LATA) in the State; and
facilities, auxiliary equipment, and services required to support the network in a reliable and secure manner.

subsection.text: The network shall be accessible through direct connection and through local intra–LATA telecommunications to State and local governments and public and private educational institutions in the State.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Governor’s Advisory Board for Telecommunications Relay.
“Communications company” means a public service company, as defined in § 1–101 of the Public Utilities Article, or any other company, that provides a communications service.
“Communications service” means:

paragraph.text: landline telephone service;
wireless or cellular telephone service; or
Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) service, as defined in § 8–601 of the Public Utilities Article.

subsection.text: “Dual party telephone relay program” means a service that provides full and simultaneous communication between a person or persons with a disability that prevents them from using a standard telephone and a person or persons without that disability using conventional telephone equipment or other technology or equipment, whereby the disabled person or persons have their message relayed through an intermediary party using specialized telecommunications equipment.
“Program” means the dual party telephone relay program.
“Program participant” means a resident of the State who uses the dual party telephone relay program.

paragraph.text: “Specialized customer telephone equipment” means any communications device that enables or assists a person with a disability to communicate with others by means of the public switched telephone network or Internet protocol–enabled voice communications service.
“Specialized customer telephone equipment” includes:

subparagraph.text: TDD/TT/TTY;
amplifiers;
captioned telephones;
VRS equipment;
cell phones;
pagers;
puff blow devices;
Braille–TTY devices; and
equipment for the mobility disabled.

subsection.text: “Telecommunications device for the deaf” or “TDD/TT/TTY” means all types of mechanical devices that enable disabled individuals to communicate through messages sent and received through a telephone or wireless network.

section.text: There is a Governor’s Advisory Board for Telecommunications Relay in the Department.

subsection.text: The Board shall be composed of 12 individuals appointed by the Governor, who shall designate the chair, including:

paragraph.text: five representatives of the deaf or hard of hearing community;
one representative of the mobility–impaired community who requires the use of specialized customer telephone equipment;
one representative of the speech–impaired community who requires the use of specialized customer telephone equipment;
one representative of the senior citizen community who requires the use of specialized customer telephone equipment;
one representative of the deaf–blind community; and
three representatives of government, one of whom is a representative of the Public Service Commission.
The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on June 30, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

subsection.text: The members of the Board shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for all reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.
By January 1 of each year, the Board shall file an annual report on its activities to the General Assembly in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall advise the Department with regard to the program’s:

paragraph.text: level of access to program participants; and
quality of service.

subsection.text: The Department in consultation with the Board shall:

paragraph.text: establish and administer a program to provide cost–efficient, 24–hour, dual party relay service to program participants at a comparable level of access and quality that a standard telecommunication service provides to a person without a hearing or speech disability;
develop the program in collaboration with State programs currently serving disabled individuals and with community agencies or other organizations that have established relay programs; and
maintain an information and referral service to provide information about the availability of the relay service.

subsection.text: The Department in consultation with the Board may:

paragraph.text: contract with a private vendor or nonprofit organization to provide the information and referral service required under subsection (a)(3) of this section; and
provide appropriate staff assistance from the Department to assist the Board in carrying out its duties under this subtitle.

section.text: The Department in consultation with the Board shall adopt regulations to carry out the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The programs under § 3A–504(a) of this subtitle and § 3A–602(a) of this title shall be funded as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: There is a Universal Service Trust Fund created for the purpose of paying the costs of maintaining and operating the program under § 3A–504(a) of this subtitle subject to the limitations and controls provided in this subtitle, and the program under § 3A–602(a) of this title subject to the limitations and controls provided in Subtitle 6 of this title.
Moneys in the Universal Service Trust Fund shall be held in the State Treasury.
Money in the Universal Service Trust Fund may only be used:

subparagraph.text: to fund the costs of the programs specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
to pay for the administration of the Universal Service Trust Fund.

paragraph.text: The costs of the programs under § 3A–504(a) of this subtitle and § 3A–602(a) of this title shall be funded by revenues generated by:

subparagraph.text: a surcharge to be paid by the subscribers to a communications service; and
other funds as provided in the State budget.
The surcharge may not exceed 18 cents per month for each account and shall be applied to all current bills rendered for a communications service in the State.
The surcharge is payable at the time the bills for a communications service are due.

paragraph.text: The surcharge to be collected under this section only applies to a communications service for which charges are billed by, or on behalf of, a communications company to a subscriber of the communications service.

The Secretary shall annually certify to the Public Service Commission the costs of the programs under § 3A–504(a) of this subtitle and § 3A–602(a) of this title to be paid by the Universal Service Trust Fund for the following fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: The Public Service Commission shall determine the surcharge for the following fiscal year necessary to fund the programs under § 3A–504(a) of this subtitle and § 3A–602(a) of this title.

sub-subparagraph.text: In accordance with subsection (c)(2) and subsubparagraph 2 of this subparagraph, the Public Service Commission shall set the surcharge for the following fiscal year at an amount that is no higher than necessary to generate sufficient revenues to fund the costs of the programs for the following fiscal year, as certified under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

In setting the surcharge under subsubparagraph 1 of this subparagraph, the Public Service Commission shall take into account whether the surcharge may be adjusted as a result of any uncommitted funds in the Universal Service Trust Fund at the end of the fiscal year that may be used to fund the costs of the programs for the following fiscal year.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall, on 60 days’ notice, direct the affected communications companies to add the surcharge determined by the Public Service Commission under paragraph (2) of this subsection to all current bills rendered for communications service in the State.

The affected communications companies shall act as collection agents for the Universal Service Trust Fund and shall remit all proceeds monthly to the Comptroller for deposit to the Universal Service Trust Fund.

The communications companies shall be entitled to credit against these proceeds in an amount equal to 1 1/2 percent of these proceeds to cover the expenses of billing, collecting, and remitting the surcharge and any additional charges.
The Secretary shall administer the Universal Service Trust Fund.
The income derived from investment of money in the Universal Service Trust Fund shall accrue to the Universal Service Trust Fund.

Any funds remaining at the end of a fiscal year in the Universal Service Trust Fund shall be carried forward within the Universal Service Trust Fund for the maintenance and operation of the programs specified under subsection (b) of this section in the following fiscal year.

The Legislative Auditor shall conduct postaudits of a fiscal and compliance nature of the Universal Service Trust Fund and the expenditures made for purposes of § 3A–504(a) of this subtitle and § 3A–602(a) of this title.
The cost of the fiscal portion of the postaudit examination shall be paid from the Universal Service Trust Fund as an administrative cost.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Governor’s Advisory Board for Telecommunications Relay established in Subtitle 5 of this title.

“Program” means the program developed and administered by the Department in consultation with the Board and the Department of Disabilities to provide financial assistance for the purchase of specialized customer telephone equipment by eligible program participants.
“Program participant” means a person who:

paragraph.text: is a resident of the State;
is certified by a licensed professional as having a disability which seriously limits or prohibits the use of the telephone or wireless network without specialized customer telephone equipment;
is certified by a licensed professional as being able to use specialized customer telephone equipment for which application is made;
meets the financial eligibility requirements established by the Department in consultation with the Department of Disabilities as a recipient of:

subparagraph.text: Transitional Emergency Medical and Housing Assistance (TEMHA);
Supplemental Security Income (SSI);
Social Security Disability Income (SSDI); or
Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF); and

paragraph.text: at the time of application is not receiving similar services which are available and can be provided in a timely manner through another program.

subsection.text: “Qualified entity” means a nonprofit organization that:

paragraph.text: produces audio editions of daily newspapers, available for interstate distribution using high–speed computer and telecommunications technology; and
provides a means of program administration and reader registration on the Internet.

subsection.text: “Specialized customer telephone equipment” or “equipment” means any communications device designed to assist program participants in using a telephone or wireless service provider’s network.
“System” means the method which the Department shall use to provide equipment to eligible program participants.
In accordance with the State budget and § 3A–506 of this title, the Department, in consultation with the Board and the Department of Disabilities, shall establish and administer a program:

paragraph.text: to provide specialized customer telephone equipment to eligible program participants; and
to provide reimbursement of costs under § 3A–606 of this subtitle.

In this subsection, “shopping facility” means an outdoor or indoor retail facility with a common pedestrian area housing more than five sales or rental establishments in which a majority of the tenants have a main entrance from the common pedestrian area.
This subsection applies to a shopping facility that:

subparagraph.text: provides a total number of four or more public pay telephones at the facility of which at least one is located in the common pedestrian area; and
is larger than 500,000 square feet.

paragraph.text: In accordance with the standards and regulations established by the Department, the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control of a shopping facility shall acquire and install at least one specialized communications device designed to enable customers with hearing or speech disabilities to access a telephone or wireless service providers network.

subsection.text: The Department, in consultation with the Board and the Department of Disabilities, shall:

paragraph.text: provide a system for eligible program participants to obtain equipment, but no single eligible participant shall receive more than $6,000;

establish an information and referral service, including the toll–free numbers for the various access modes for the Maryland relay service and provide information about the availability of the equipment;
contract with private vendors or nonprofit organizations to provide the information and referral service and other auxiliary services;
as necessary, establish interagency agreements with other State agencies that provide technical assistance for disabled individuals to prevent duplicative programs; and
appoint appropriate staff to assist the Board in carrying out its activities under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board and the Department of Disabilities shall:

paragraph.text: assist the Department in the development of regulations;
develop and implement educational outreach programs;
review and monitor the program; and
advise the Department on unusual hardship cases.

section.text: This subtitle may not be construed to establish an entitlement program.
The Department in consultation with the Board and the Department of Disabilities shall adopt regulations to carry out the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Department in consultation with the Board and the Department of Disabilities shall enter into an agreement with the State Department of Education, Division of Library Development and Services, providing for an annual payment to be made to the Division in an amount equal to the cost incurred for the distribution of newspapers in a computerized audio format.

Under the agreement, the Division of Library Development and Services shall provide eligible blind and disabled individuals with access to newspapers in a computerized audio format by a qualified entity.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of General Services.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of General Services.

section.text: There is a Department of General Services, established as a principal department of the State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the Secretary of General Services, who shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor. The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on those matters.

The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department. The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Department as necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to the Secretary.
The Secretary is responsible for establishing policy to be followed by the units in the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a Deputy Secretary.
The Deputy Secretary:

subparagraph.text: is in the executive service of the State Personnel Management System and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary;
is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
has the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may employ a staff attached to the Office of the Secretary in accordance with the Code or the State budget.

Each staff assistant in the Office of the Secretary in charge of a particular area of responsibility and each professional consultant is in the executive service, management service, or is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System and is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.

Except as provided in this section or otherwise by law, the Secretary shall appoint and remove all other staff in the Office of the Secretary in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

The Secretary may review any personnel action taken by any unit in the Department. The Secretary may delegate the power to approve any appointment or removal to the head or governing body of any unit in the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is responsible for the budget of the Office of the Secretary and for the budget of each unit in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may adopt regulations for the Department and its units.
The Secretary shall review and may approve, disapprove, or revise regulations of any unit of the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary may create any advisory body of any size that the Secretary considers appropriate for the operation of the Department.
The Secretary shall have a seal.

paragraph.text: The Secretary is responsible for the planning of activities, programs, and services of the Department.
The Secretary may review, approve, disapprove, or modify the plans, proposals, and projects of the units in the Department.

subsection.text: On or before December 1 of each year, the Secretary shall send a report to the Governor on the activities of the Department during the previous fiscal year.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary may exercise any authority that is granted to any unit in the Department.
This subsection does not authorize the Secretary to exercise any authority granted to the General Professional Services Selection Board.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a unit in the Department to the extent that the unit is permitted by law to employ its own legal adviser or counsel.
The Attorney General is legal adviser to the Department.
The Attorney General shall assign to the Department the number of Assistant Attorneys General authorized by law to be assigned to the Department and to its units.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate 1 of the Assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department as counsel to the Department. After the Attorney General designates the counsel to the Department, the Attorney General may not reassign the counsel without consulting the Secretary.

The counsel may have no duty other than to give the legal aid, advice, and counsel required by the Secretary or any other official of the Department, to supervise the other Assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department, and to perform for the Department the duties that the Attorney General assigns. The counsel shall perform these duties subject to the control and supervision of the Attorney General.

subsection.text: The following units are in the Department:

paragraph.text: the Board of Architectural Review;
the General Professional Services Selection Board;
the Purchasing Bureau; and
any other unit that is in the Department under any other law.

subsection.text: Each unit in the Department shall report to the Secretary.

section.text: In addition to its other functions, the Department shall perform any function requested of it or delegated to it by the Board of Public Works.
The Department has any power necessary and proper to accomplish a function conferred on it by law or delegated to it or requested of it by the Board of Public Works.

The Department of General Services, the Department of Transportation, and the University System of Maryland shall reserve a reasonable amount of space in State buildings under their control, subject to regulations adopted by the Board of Public Works, so that any law enforcement agency or State recognized nonprofit advocacy group for abducted children can display the picture of a child abducted in a noncustody-related abduction in the reserved space.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bid” means a bid, proposal, or other response to a solicitation.
“Supplies” means tangible property, including equipment and materials.

section.text: There is a Purchasing Bureau in the Department.
The Secretary may delegate any power or duty set forth in Part I or Part II of this subtitle to the Chief of the Purchasing Bureau.

subsection.text: The Secretary or any employee of the Department may not:

paragraph.text: be interested in any contract or bid for furnishing any supplies to any unit that procures supplies under Division II of this article;
be connected in any manner, directly or indirectly, with any contract or bid for furnishing any supplies to any of those units; or
accept or receive, directly or indirectly, whether by rebate, gift, or otherwise, from a person to whom a contract may be awarded:

subparagraph.text: any money or thing of value; or
any promise, obligation, or contract for future reward or compensation.

subsection.text: If the Secretary or any employee of the Department violates any provision of this section, the Secretary or employee is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not less than $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

section.text: Any contract for printing for the State shall be made through or with the approval of the Secretary except for:

paragraph.text: a contract for printing for the General Assembly and its staff agencies;
a contract for printing a record or brief for the Office of the Attorney General; and
a contract for printing of the Maryland Reports or the Maryland Appellate Reports.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall adopt standards for maintaining stores and inventory control for all supplies required by any unit that procures supplies under Division II of this article.

paragraph.text: To the extent required by the Secretary, each unit that procures supplies under Division II of this article shall file with the Secretary an inventory of the supplies in its possession.
The unit shall submit the inventory to the Secretary at least once a year.
The inventory is subject to audit.

section.text: The Secretary shall provide a copy of each award for supplies to the requisitioning unit.
Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, each unit of the Executive Branch of the State government shall purchase all supplies through or with the approval of the Secretary.

An invoice for supplies purchased by the Secretary or by any unit that procures supplies under Division II of this article may not be paid until the invoice has been approved by the Secretary or a designee of the Secretary.

Consistent with Division II of this article, the Secretary shall set standards for supplies to be purchased by a unit, including standards for electronic equipment used by State employees or the public for communications that are consistent with the standards for nonvisual access information technology issued under § 3-410 of this article.
Consistent with Division II of this article, the Secretary shall contract for or purchase any supplies for a unit except an item that the Secretary:

paragraph.text: determines is strictly perishable;
determines is impracticable for the unit to purchase through or with the approval of the Secretary; or
permits the unit to purchase with the approval of the Secretary.

section.text: At time intervals set by the Secretary, each unit that procures supplies under Division II of this article shall send to the Secretary estimates of the amount and quality of any needed supplies.

subsection.text: An employee of a unit that procures supplies under Division II of this article whose salary and expenses are paid from the fees of the employee’s office may not pay any contractor or seller for any article of any kind acquired for the unit unless the invoice approved by the employee is also approved by the Secretary or a designee of the Secretary.
The Governor may remove an employee for any violation of the provisions of this section.

section.text: This Part III of this subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: intergovernmental lease transactions;
lease transactions involving property located outside the State;
lease transactions declared by the Secretary to be necessary because of an emergency;
lease transactions where the State is the lessor; or
lease transactions involving less than 2,500 square feet of property.

subsection.text: This section applies to any lease of property by the State.

paragraph.text: The Department shall give written notice of each proposed initial lease of property to:

subparagraph.text: the governing body of each political subdivision in which the property is located; and
each member of the General Assembly in whose legislative district the property is located.

paragraph.text: If the notice given under paragraph (1) of this subsection is for at least 2 proposed sites from which 1 site is to be selected, before any site is finally selected, the Department shall give written notice of the site that has been proposed for final selection.

subsection.text: Within 30 days after receiving notice under subsection (b)(1) of this section, the governing body or the member of the General Assembly may submit written comments to the Department.
A lease for a site may not be executed until 31 days after the day that notice is received under subsection (b)(1) of this section.
The Department shall advertise any need of the State to rent building space at least 30 days before proposals for a lease are due.
The Department shall advertise the proposed leasing in daily or weekly newspapers with circulation sufficient to provide notice:

paragraph.text: to the people of the State; or
at least to the people of the affected locality.

subsection.text: The advertisement shall contain:

paragraph.text: the number of square feet proposed to be leased; and
the general area in which the State desires to lease the space.

subsection.text: Each proposal for the lease of building space by the State shall be submitted to the Secretary.

Unless a regulation of the Board of Public Works provides otherwise, the Secretary shall submit each proposal, along with any recommendation of the Secretary, to the Board of Public Works for final approval.

The Board of Public Works shall adopt regulations in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article concerning submission of proposals for the lease of building space under this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Chief” means the Chief of the Division.
“Division” means the Land Acquisition Division of the Department.
“Public improvement” includes any construction, maintenance, or repair of any building, structure, or other public work:

paragraph.text: owned or constructed by the State or any unit of the State government, including the University System of Maryland, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and Morgan State University; or
acquired or constructed in whole or in part with State funds.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 4-409 of this subtitle, this subtitle does not apply to any public improvement made by:

paragraph.text: the Department of Transportation or a unit in that Department;
any housing authority created under Division II of the Housing and Community Development Article;
the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission;
the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
the Baltimore County Metropolitan District;
a county, municipal corporation, or unit of a county or municipal corporation;
the University System of Maryland;
Morgan State University; or
St. Mary’s College of Maryland.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works may exempt specific projects of a unit of the State government from the provisions of this subtitle.

The Board of Public Works shall adopt regulations in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article establishing procedures for the exemption of specific projects of units of State government under subsection (b) of this section.
The Department of General Services shall assist the Department of Budget and Management:

paragraph.text: in developing technical details necessary for the preparation of the Capital Improvement Program for any unit of the State government; and
in any regional study relating to land acquisition, dedication, lease, transfer, and the like.

subsection.text: The Department shall assist and advise any unit of the State government, including the Board of Public Works:

paragraph.text: in the review and approval of any change to a contract, plan, or specification for a public improvement; and
on any engineering matter, survey, plan, specification, or contract for a public improvement or land acquisition that:

subparagraph.text: may come before the Board of Public Works; or
may be of interest to the unit of the State government.

subsection.text: The Department shall enforce the State Building Code.

paragraph.text: The Department shall advise the Board of Public Works and any unit of the State government in connection with any engineering question or matter concerning a public improvement.
The Department shall supervise any engineering question or matter concerning a public improvement.
Any contract, plan, or specification for any public improvement that involves an engineering question:

subparagraph.text: shall be submitted to the Department; and
is subject to the approval of the Department.

paragraph.text: At the request of the Board of Public Works, the Department shall advise the Board of Public Works on any contract that exceeds $500,000 if the contract involves an engineering question or a matter concerning a public improvement undertaken by the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, or St. Mary’s College of Maryland.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: represent the Board of Public Works at the opening of bids for a public improvement;
tabulate and record the bids; and
advise the Board of Public Works on the bids.

subsection.text: The Department shall supervise each appraisal related to a public improvement.

paragraph.text: The Department shall collect and maintain a complete and accurate file of drawings and plats of the location of all public improvements.
The Department shall collect and maintain records of construction costs and progress on each public improvement.
The Department shall adequately store and protect any original drawing, plat, record, or specification.

subsection.text: The Department shall examine and approve or disapprove each plan and specification prepared in connection with the preparation or execution of a contract for a public improvement.

paragraph.text: The Department shall inspect and approve or disapprove any material, equipment, and methods used in making public improvements and shall inspect each public improvement during the course of construction or repair.
The duty of the Department under this subsection does not relieve an architect or engineer of any supervisory responsibility for which the architect or engineer is employed.
The provisions of subsections (a), (b), (e), and (f) of this section do not apply to State correctional facilities as defined in § 11-101 of this article.

In accordance with §§ 10-102 through 10-105 of the Correctional Services Article, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services shall perform the duties specified in subsections (a), (b), (e), and (f) of this section for State correctional facilities.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: units of the State government are under pressure to delay or eliminate needed physical facility maintenance and repair because of fiscal constraints;
lack of regular maintenance and repair results in deterioration of public improvements and increased costs for repair or construction of entirely new replacement facilities; and
a specific set of procedures is necessary to ensure that all units of the State government perform regular maintenance and repair.
The Department of General Services shall establish general policies and standards for maintenance and repair of public improvements.
On or before December 31 of each year, the Department of General Services shall send any changes to these general policies and standards to:

subparagraph.text: the Board of Public Works; and
the Department of Budget and Management.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: establish and supervise a comprehensive and continuing program of maintenance and repair of all public improvements; and
review maintenance and operation of public improvements to the extent that any engineering question is involved.

subsection.text: Each unit of the State government shall carry out a maintenance and repair program for each public improvement under the jurisdiction of the unit. In carrying out the program, the unit shall:

paragraph.text: conform to the policies and standards established by the Department; and
allocate sufficient funds and personnel.

subsection.text: On or before May 31 of each year, each unit of the State government shall send a report on the condition of each public improvement under its jurisdiction to:

paragraph.text: the Department of Budget and Management; and
the Department of General Services.

subsection.text: The report shall:

paragraph.text: identify the public improvement; and
state whether the public improvement is being maintained in accordance with the policies and standards established by the Department of General Services.

subsection.text: With the assistance of the Department of Budget and Management, the Department of General Services shall recommend measures necessary to correct deficiencies in the maintenance and repair programs.

section.text: On an annual basis, the Department may inspect the physical facilities of the public junior or community colleges and the regional community colleges in the State.
There is a Land Acquisition Division in the Department.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Division exclusively shall negotiate the acquisition of land for any public improvement.
The Division shall make each State acquisition in the name of:

paragraph.text: the unit of the State government; or
the principal department of the State government to which the unit belongs.

subsection.text: The Division is not responsible for acquiring land for a local project.

paragraph.text: The Division is not responsible for developing any acquired land.
Development of any land acquired under Program Open Space is the responsibility of the unit of the State government.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section and §§ 4–413 through 4–416 of this subtitle do not apply to land acquired by the Department of Natural Resources under Title 1, Subtitle 1 of the Natural Resources Article.
The head of the Division is the Chief of the Land Acquisition Division, who shall be appointed by the Secretary with the approval of the Governor.
The Chief serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The Chief must be experienced and skilled in the field of land acquisition.
The Chief is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
The Chief is responsible to the Department for:

paragraph.text: administering the Division; and
carrying out any function assigned to the Division.

subsection.text: The Chief shall organize the Division as necessary to carry out the powers and duties of the Division.
Subject to the approval of the Secretary, the Chief may employ a staff and any professional consultant in accordance with the State budget.
This section does not apply to any capital expenditures by the Department of Transportation or the Maryland Transportation Authority in connection with State roads, bridges, or highways.
Before execution, a contract for the acquisition of land shall be:

paragraph.text: reviewed by the Secretary of General Services; and
except as provided in § 12-204 of this article, after that review, approved by the Board of Public Works.
This subsection does not apply to any capital expenditure by:

subparagraph.text: the Maryland Aviation Administration;
the Maryland Port Administration; or
the Maryland Transit Administration.

paragraph.text: At least 40 days before the Board of Public Works may act on a land acquisition, the Division shall give written notice of a potential acquisition of land:

subparagraph.text: to the governing body of the county in which the land is located; and
if the land is located within a municipal corporation, to the governing body of the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: Within 30 days after receiving notice under this subsection, the governing body may submit written comments to the Division.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works shall supervise the expenditure of any money that the General Assembly appropriates for the acquisition of land.
Except for real property that is acquired by gift, before any real property is acquired from a private owner, the Board of Public Works shall obtain two independent appraisals of the property.
The Board of Public Works shall adopt regulations, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, to carry out this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Excess personal property” means an item of personal property that is declared to be in excess of the needs of the custodial unit of the State government because the item:

paragraph.text: is not necessary to the efficient operation of the unit; or
has been replaced by a similar item.

subsection.text: “Nonexpendable item” means an item of equipment or furnishing that has:

paragraph.text: an anticipated useful life of more than 1 year; and
an original cost exceeding a minimum dollar amount established by the Department by regulation.

subsection.text: “Surplus personal property” means an item of excess personal property that the Department declares is not needed by any unit of the State government.

paragraph.text: The head of a unit of the State government may declare an item of personal property in the possession of the unit to be excess personal property by submitting a declaration of excess personal property to the Department.
The declaration is effective on approval by the Department.

subsection.text: The Department may declare excess personal property to be surplus personal property if the Department determines that the excess personal property cannot be used by any unit of the State government.
The Department shall administer all arrangements for moving excess personal property or surplus personal property.
The Department shall decide whether excess personal property or surplus personal property shall be:

paragraph.text: moved to a central location; or
disposed of at its present location.

subsection.text: The Secretary may dispose of excess personal property and surplus personal property as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: Whenever feasible, the Secretary shall dispose of excess personal property by transferring it to another unit of the State government.
The unit of the State government that receives the excess personal property shall pay any cost of the transfer.

subsection.text: The Secretary:

paragraph.text: may dispose of any surplus personal property; and
shall seek to gain the maximum value for the State in the disposition.
The Secretary shall dispose of surplus personal property:

subparagraph.text: by dismantling it for recovery of valuable parts;
by trading it in;
by transferring it to a local jurisdiction, public school system, or nonprofit organization;
by auctioning or selling it, including selling it for scrap value; or
if no value can be realized from it, by destroying it.

paragraph.text: If surplus personal property is destroyed under this subsection, the unit of the State government that declared the item to be excess personal property shall pay any cost of destruction.

subsection.text: The Secretary may delegate the authority to dispose of surplus personal property to a designee of the Secretary or, by regulation, to another unit of the State government.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, money received from the auction or sale of any surplus personal property in excess of charges which might be imposed by the Department of General Services for conducting the auction or sale shall be deposited in the General Fund of the State. If the Department of Budget and Management approves, the money in excess of the service charge may be credited to the account of the unit of the State government that declared the property to be excess personal property.
Money received from the auction or sale of surplus personal property shall be deposited as follows:

paragraph.text: if the item was purchased from a special fund appropriation, the proceeds shall be deposited in the appropriate special fund;
if the item was purchased with bond money, the proceeds shall be deposited in the Annuity Bond Fund; and
if the item was purchased with federal money, the proceeds shall be disbursed in accordance with federal law.

subsection.text: The Department shall distribute periodically a list of excess personal property to each unit of the State or a local government.
The Department shall adopt regulations to implement this subtitle. Any regulation adopted under this subtitle is subject to approval by the Board of Public Works.
The Department may use excess personal property to satisfy a purchase requisition if the excess personal property:

paragraph.text: is functional;
is serviceable; and
satisfies the need of the requisitioning unit.

section.text: If the Department trades in surplus personal property for a replacement for the unit of the State government that declared the item excess, the Department shall give credit to that unit in the form of a reduced cost for the replacement property.

If a unit of the State government requisitions a nonexpendable item to replace any item, the unit shall declare the existing item to be excess personal property unless the Department of Budget and Management waives this requirement. The unit of the State government seeking to replace the item shall submit a declaration of excess personal property to the Department of General Services with the purchase requisition for the replacement item.
The Department has jurisdiction over and full police authority for the enforcement of the criminal laws and the parking and motor vehicle laws as to the operation, maintenance, and protection of:

paragraph.text: buildings and grounds that, on June 30, 1984, were administered by the Office of Annapolis Public Buildings and Grounds, and extending to the surrounding area that encompasses 1,000 feet in any direction from the boundary of those buildings and grounds;

buildings and grounds that, on June 30, 1984, were administered by the Office of Baltimore Public Buildings and Grounds, and extending to the surrounding area that encompasses 1,000 feet in any direction from the boundary of those buildings and grounds;
multiservice centers designated by law or by the Board of Public Works; and
other public improvements or grounds designated by law or by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: In accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article, the Secretary may appoint and remove superintendents to supervise designated improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers under the jurisdiction of the Department, including those in Annapolis and Baltimore City.
A superintendent shall perform the duties delegated by the Secretary.
A superintendent is entitled to compensation in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: The Secretary may establish divisions or offices in the Department to carry out the responsibilities for improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers under the jurisdiction of the Department.
For all improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers under the jurisdiction of the Department, the responsibilities of the Department include:

paragraph.text: keeping a complete inventory of movable property assigned to the Department;
supervising utility and sanitation services and fire and safety systems;
supervising repairs and other work;
landscaping;
purchasing carpets, equipment, furniture, and supplies;
protecting persons and property, including dispersing any assemblage that is unlawful, is dangerous, or obstructs free passage;
preserving and protecting the public peace, health, and safety; and

controlling pedestrian and vehicular traffic, including establishing speed limits and parking and impoundment regulations for parking garages, surface parking lots, roads, and sidewalks that are owned or leased by the State and that are within the improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers.

In accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article, the Secretary may establish a police and security force to protect people and property on or about improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers under the jurisdiction of the Department, and in the surrounding areas of the buildings and grounds in Annapolis and Baltimore City as described in § 4–601(1) and (2) of this subtitle.
The police and security force may include sworn police officers.

subsection.text: A member of the police and security force may not be involuntarily transferred from a site to another site.
A member of the police and security force has the same powers as a sheriff or police officer under § 2–101 of the Criminal Procedure Article only if the member:

paragraph.text: meets the legal requirements set forth by the Maryland Police Training Commission; and
is designated by the Department as a police officer.

subsection.text: In this section, “Chief of Police” means:

paragraph.text: as to improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers in the City of Annapolis, the Chief of Police of the City of Annapolis;
as to improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers in Baltimore City, the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City; and

as to improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers not located in the City of Annapolis or Baltimore City, the head of the local police force of the county in which the improvements, grounds, or multiservice centers are located.

subsection.text: The Secretary has concurrent authority with the Chief of Police to enforce the criminal laws and parking and motor vehicle laws on streets adjacent to all improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers under the jurisdiction of the Department, and in the surrounding areas of the buildings and grounds in Annapolis and Baltimore City as described in § 4–601(1) and (2) of this subtitle.
The Secretary may adopt regulations for the operation, maintenance, and security of the improvements, grounds, and multiservice centers under the jurisdiction of the Department.
Any regulation adopted under this section shall be conspicuously posted.

A person who violates a regulation adopted under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $20 plus costs. A person who fails to pay any fine or costs imposed under this section may be imprisoned in jail for a period not exceeding 30 days.

section.text: Annually, the State shall appropriate and pay to the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Annapolis the sum provided in the State budget as payment for:

paragraph.text: the collection of refuse from State buildings located in the City of Annapolis; and
other services provided to the State by the City of Annapolis.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Board” means the State Board of Architectural Review.
There is a State Board of Architectural Review in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.

subparagraph.text: Upon the recommendation of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate, the Governor shall appoint the members from a list of names:

sub-subparagraph.text: of architects, submitted by the Baltimore, Chesapeake Bay, and Potomac Valley chapters of the American Institute of Architects;
of engineers, submitted by the Maryland Society of Professional Engineers; and
of landscape architects, submitted by the Maryland Chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects.

subparagraph.text: There shall be at least 5 names on the list submitted by each organization.

paragraph.text: The Board shall consist of architects and at least 1 engineer, 1 landscape architect, and 1 architect who specializes or has particular experience in building preservation.

subsection.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: Except for the Department of Transportation and the Maryland Transportation Authority in connection with the construction of roads, bridges, or highways, each State agency shall refer to the Board any major architectural problem or plan concerning the construction, reconstruction, or repair of a State building.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Building” means:

paragraph.text: any new structure with an area of at least 5,000 square feet;
any change to an existing structure that:

subparagraph.text: will add at least 10% gross floor space to the structure and has an estimated construction cost of more than $25,000; or
constitutes a major renovation; or

paragraph.text: any structure with an area of at least 5,000 square feet that is leased or owned by the State.

subsection.text: “Energy-consumption analysis” means an evaluation, by type and amount of energy used, of:

paragraph.text: each piece of equipment that serves a building, including any piece of equipment that is used:

subparagraph.text: to cool the building;
to heat the building; or
to heat water used in the building;

paragraph.text: each piece of equipment on the building site that is:

subparagraph.text: used to generate electricity for the building; or
powered, in whole or in part, by coal, electricity, natural gas, oil, sun, or wind; and

paragraph.text: each conservation measure included in the building that decreases the energy requirements of the building.

subsection.text: “Energy performance index” means a number that:

paragraph.text: describes the energy requirements of a building measured at the building boundaries under defined internal and external ambient conditions over an entire seasonal cycle; and
is stated either:

subparagraph.text: per square foot of floor space in the building; or
per cubic foot of occupied volume of the building.

subsection.text: “Life of the building” has the meaning established by the Department under § 4-808 of this subtitle.
“Life-cycle costs” means the sum of the following costs of a building:

paragraph.text: the cost of initial construction;
the cost of all energy conservation measures;
the cost of operation and maintenance, including labor and materials, for the life of the building;
the cost, over the life of the building, of the fuel used by:

subparagraph.text: the equipment that controls or provides the humidity, lighting, power, temperature, and ventilation of the building; and
other energy-using equipment in the building; and
