to pay for the Trust to acquire historic properties or interests in historic properties for its authorized purposes or for resale or lease subject to appropriate preservation covenants;
to pay costs, including preparation costs, to restore or rehabilitate historic properties owned by the Trust for:

subparagraph.text: the Trust’s authorized purposes; or
resale or lease subject to appropriate preservation covenants; or

paragraph.text: to make loans to nonprofit organizations, political subdivisions, business entities, and individuals to:

subparagraph.text: acquire, rehabilitate, restore, or refinance historic properties; or

provide short–term financing for costs, including preparation costs, directly related to work that the Trust or the State Historic Preservation Officer requires or recommends to be undertaken before a construction project financed with federal or State money is begun or continued.

paragraph.text: The MHT Loan Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of this article.
The State Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for the MHT Loan Fund.

subsection.text: The MHT Loan Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the MHT Loan Program;
money received as interest or repayment of principal on loans made under the MHT Loan Program or the Capital Revolving Fund for Historic Preservation;
the proceeds from the resale or lease of property originally acquired by the Trust with money from the MHT Loan Fund or the Capital Revolving Fund for Historic Preservation;
money received from other public or private sources for the benefit of the MHT Loan Fund; and
money received from the sale of general obligation bonds.

subsection.text: Money in the MHT Loan Fund shall be invested in the same manner as other State money.

paragraph.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the purposes of the MHT Loan Program.
The regulations shall include:

subparagraph.text: application procedures;
procedures to give adequate notice to the public of assistance available under the MHT Loan Program;
provisions for the review of plans and specifications;
provisions for the inspection of projects during construction; and
selection criteria the Trust must consider in evaluating loan applications, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the relative historical or cultural significance of, and the urgency of need for, the project to be financed by the loan;
any proposed contribution by the appropriate political subdivision to the project;
the geographic distribution of loan assistance from the MHT Loan Fund; and
other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Secretary, for each loan the Trust may set:

subparagraph.text: the principal amount;
the maturity;
the repayment terms; and
an interest rate that complies with applicable federal regulations governing State borrowing.

paragraph.text: A loan from the MHT Loan Fund may be granted at an interest rate lower than rates on other loans from the MHT Loan Fund if:

subparagraph.text: the loan recipient is a nonprofit organization or a political subdivision; or

the Secretary of Housing and Community Development determines under § 4–212 of the Housing and Community Development Article that after restoration or rehabilitation, the historic property will be wholly or partly occupied by individuals or families of limited income.

paragraph.text: A loan from the MHT Loan Program may be secured by:

subparagraph.text: a mortgage lien, which may be subordinate to other mortgage liens;
a guarantee of repayment; or
another form of collateral acceptable to the Trust.

paragraph.text: Without approval or execution by the Board of Public Works, the Trust may take title to a mortgaged property by foreclosure or by deed in lieu of foreclosure and:

subparagraph.text: convey title to a buyer; and
obtain and seek enforcement of a deficiency judgment.

paragraph.text: An individual or business entity may receive a loan only if the recipient can document that private financing is unavailable.

The Trust shall ensure that no loan is made under the MHT Loan Program to acquire, restore, or rehabilitate a historic property unless the historic property is listed in or eligible to be listed in the Historic Register.
The Trust shall require the recipient of a loan from the MHT Loan Program to enter into an agreement to preserve and maintain the property.
If the property is real property, the agreement shall be a recordable historic preservation easement.
The Secretary may waive the agreement requirement if the Secretary finds that an agreement is impracticable.

subsection.text: The trustees shall review and make recommendations to the Secretary about loans and expenditures from the MHT Loan Fund, and the Secretary shall approve each loan and expenditure from the MHT Loan Fund.

paragraph.text: To the extent required by regulations adopted by the Secretary and approved by the Board of Public Works, the Secretary shall submit to the Board of Public Works for approval a proposed loan or expenditure from the MHT Loan Fund that will be financed through the sale of State general obligation bonds.
Except for an expenditure under subsection (d)(2) or (3) of this section, a loan or expenditure from the MHT Loan Fund is not subject to Titles 4 and 5 of this article.

subsection.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Trust shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the financial status and the activities of the MHT Loan Program for the preceding fiscal year.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a material false statement of fact, including an understatement or overstatement of financial condition, in a statement or report in or regarding an application for a loan or affecting an existing loan.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“MHT Grant Fund” means the Historic Preservation and Historical and Cultural Museum Assistance Grant Fund of the Trust.
“MHT Grant Program” means the Historic Preservation Grant Program of the Trust.
There is an MHT Grant Program in the Trust.
The purposes of the MHT Grant Program are to:

subparagraph.text: implement and encourage the preservation of historic properties; and
promote interest in and study of historic properties and their preservation.

paragraph.text: The Trust shall administer the MHT Grant Program and coordinate the MHT Grant Program with federal and State programs that complement or facilitate the MHT Grant Program.

The Trust shall ensure that a grant awarded under the MHT Grant Program to acquire, restore, or rehabilitate a historic property is used only if the historic property is listed in or is eligible to be listed in the Historic Register.

subparagraph.text: The Trust shall require a grantee under the MHT Grant Program to enter into an agreement to preserve and maintain the property.
If the property is real property, the agreement shall be a recordable historic preservation easement.
The Secretary may waive the agreement requirement if the Secretary determines that an agreement is impracticable.

paragraph.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the purposes of the MHT Grant Program.
The regulations shall include:

subparagraph.text: application procedures;
procedures to give adequate notice to the public of assistance available under the MHT Grant Program;
provisions for the review of plans and specifications;
provisions for the inspection of projects during construction; and
selection criteria the Trust must consider when evaluating applications for grants, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the relative historical or cultural significance of, and the urgency of need for, the project to be financed by the grant;
any proposed contribution by the appropriate political subdivision to the project;
the geographic distribution of grant assistance from the MHT Grant Fund under subsection (e) of this section; and
other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: There is an MHT Grant Fund in the Trust.
The MHT Grant Fund may be used:

subparagraph.text: for the purposes set forth in § 5A–353 of this subtitle;
to make grants to nonprofit organizations, political subdivisions, business entities, and individuals to acquire, rehabilitate, or restore historic properties;
to make grants to nonprofit organizations and political subdivisions to pay costs, including preparation costs, that are directly related to a rehabilitation or restoration project;

to make grants to nonprofit organizations and political subdivisions for historic preservation education and promotion, including the research, survey, and evaluation of historic properties and the preparation of historic preservation planning documents and educational materials;
to purchase or acquire historic properties or interests in historic properties for the Trust’s authorized purposes or for resale or lease with appropriate preservation covenants;

to pay costs, including preparation costs, that are directly related to restoring or rehabilitating historic properties that the Trust owns for use in accordance with the Trust’s authorized purposes or for resale or lease subject to appropriate preservation covenants; and

to pay for historic preservation education and promotion conducted by the Trust, and for the research, survey, and evaluation of historic properties and the preparation of historic preservation planning documents and educational materials.

subsection.text: The Trust shall administer the MHT Grant Fund.

paragraph.text: The MHT Grant Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of this article.
The Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for the MHT Grant Fund.

subsection.text: The MHT Grant Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the MHT Grant Program or the Historical and Cultural Museum Assistance Program under § 5A–352 of this subtitle;
the proceeds from the resale or lease of any properties originally acquired by the Trust from the MHT Grant Fund or the Capital Grant Fund for Historic Preservation;
money received from other public or private sources for the benefit of the MHT Grant Fund; and
money received from the sale of State general obligation bonds.

subsection.text: Money in the MHT Grant Fund shall be invested in the same manner as other State money.

paragraph.text: The trustees shall review and make recommendations to the Secretary about grant applications and expenditure requests from the MHT Grant Fund.
The trustees shall base their grant recommendations on a competitive selection process.
In any fiscal year, the Secretary may hold up to 20% of the money in the MHT Grant Fund in reserve for emergency use in accordance with subsection (e) of this section.
Grants to business entities may not exceed 10% of all grants awarded from the MHT Grant Fund under this section.

To the extent required by regulations adopted by the Secretary and approved by the Board of Public Works, the Secretary shall submit to the Board of Public Works for approval grants or expenditures from the MHT Grant Fund to be financed through the sale of State general obligation bonds.
Except for an expenditure under subsection (e)(2)(v) and (vi) of this section, grants and expenditures from the MHT Grant Fund are not subject to Titles 4 and 5 of this article.

subsection.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Trust shall report to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the financial status and the activities of the MHT Grant Program and the MHT Grant Fund for the preceding fiscal year.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a material false statement of fact, including an understatement or overstatement of financial condition, in a statement or report in or regarding an application for a grant or affecting an existing grant.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Historic Marker Program Fund.
There is a Historic Marker Program Fund in the Trust.
The purpose of the Fund is to produce and install historic markers at sites of statewide historical significance.
The Trust shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of this article.
The State Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated to the Fund in the State budget;
money recovered by the State to replace damaged or destroyed historic markers; and
money from any other source received for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Trust may use money from the Fund to produce and install a historic marker at a site that the Trust determines to have statewide historical significance:

paragraph.text: if the site is on State-owned land; or
if the site is not on State-owned land and at least one-half of the cost of producing and installing the historic marker is provided from sources other than the State.

subsection.text: Money in the Fund shall be invested in the same manner as other State money.

paragraph.text: The Trust shall approve the form and text of historic markers produced and installed under this section.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Trust shall approve the location of a historic marker.

If a historic marker is to be placed within the right-of-way of a public highway or street, the unit of the State or the political subdivision that maintains the public highway or street shall approve the location and manner of installation of the historic marker.

subsection.text: The State owns the historic markers produced and installed under this section.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL MAY 31, 2015 PER CHAPTERS 278 AND 279 OF 2010 //

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Capital project” means the:

subparagraph.text: acquisition of land or buildings for an African American heritage preservation project; or
construction or improvement of an African American heritage preservation project.

paragraph.text: “Commission” means the Commission on African American History and Culture.

“Construction or improvement” means planning, design, engineering, alteration, construction, reconstruction, enlargement, expansion, extension, improvement, replacement, rehabilitation, renovation, upgrading, repair, or capital equipping.
“Grantee” means a business entity, individual, nonprofit organization, or political subdivision.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Planning.
There is an African American Heritage Preservation Program in the Trust.

The purpose of the African American Heritage Preservation Program is to identify and preserve buildings, communities, and sites of historical and cultural importance to the African American experience in Maryland.

subsection.text: The Trust shall develop and administer the African American Heritage Preservation Program in partnership with the Commission.

paragraph.text: On or before July 15 of each year, a grantee may submit an application to the joint partnership of the Trust and Commission to receive a grant for an African American heritage preservation capital project for the next fiscal year.
An application shall include:

subparagraph.text: a description of the scope and purpose of the project;
a building plan that includes the estimated total cost of the project; and
any other information required by the Trust and Commission.

subsection.text: Grants under the Program to a business entity, individual, or political subdivision:

paragraph.text: require a matching fund from any combination of federal, county, municipal, or private sources; and
may not exceed 50% of the total cost of an African American heritage preservation capital project.

The Trust and Commission shall review grant applications submitted in accordance with subsection (d) of this section and shall make recommendations for African American heritage preservation capital project grants for the next fiscal year.
In making recommendations under this subsection, the Trust and Commission shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the public necessity and urgency of a project;
the need for additional sources of funding for a project;
the estimated cost and timeliness of executing a project;
the viability of matching funds for a project; and
geographic diversity.

paragraph.text: On or before November 1 of each year, the Trust and Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: recommend African American heritage preservation capital projects for funding in the State capital budget for the next fiscal year; and
forward the list of recommended projects and grantees to the Department of Budget and Management.

subsection.text: For fiscal year 2012 and each fiscal year thereafter, the Governor shall include in the annual capital budget submission $1,000,000 for African American heritage preservation capital projects.

On or before October 1 of each year, the Trust and Commission shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly, on State grants awarded for African American heritage preservation capital projects for the prior fiscal year.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Trust shall require a grantee under the African American Heritage Preservation Program to enter into an agreement to preserve and maintain the property.
If the property is historic real property, the agreement shall be a recordable historic preservation easement.
The Secretary may waive the easement requirement if the Secretary determines that an easement is impracticable or infeasible under the circumstances.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, shall adopt regulations to implement the African American Heritage Preservation Program.

A proposed regulation that relates to approval by the Board of Public Works of grants to be financed through the sale of State general obligation bonds may not be adopted under paragraph (1) of this subsection unless the regulation is approved by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: To the extent required by regulations adopted under subsection (j) of this section, the Trust and the Commission shall submit to the Board of Public Works for the Board’s approval each recommended African American Heritage Preservation Program grant that is to be financed through the sale of State general obligation bonds.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Archaeology Office” means the Archaeology Office established under § 5A-334 of this subtitle.
“Associated funerary objects” means objects that are reasonably believed to have been placed with individual human remains as a part of the death rite or ceremony of a culture.

paragraph.text: “Cave” has the meaning stated in § 5-1401 of the Natural Resources Article.
“Cave” includes:

subparagraph.text: any naturally occurring void, cavity, recess, cavern, sinkhole, grotto, rock shelter, or system of interconnecting passages beneath the surface of the earth or within a cliff or ledge; and
natural subsurface water and drainage systems.

subsection.text: “Committee” means the Advisory Committee on Archaeology.
“Human remains” means any part of the body of a deceased human being in any state of decomposition.
“Native American” means an individual or a descendant of an individual who inhabited North America before European contact.
“Submerged archaeological historic property” means any underwater structure, remains, or object that:

paragraph.text: yields or is likely to yield information significant to the study of human prehistory, history, or culture; and

subparagraph.text: is so embedded in underwater land that excavating tools are needed to move the bottom sediments to reach all or part of it and has remained unclaimed for at least 100 years; or
is included or is eligible to be included in the National Register of Historic Places.

subsection.text: There is an Archaeology Office in the Trust.

paragraph.text: The Archaeology Office includes a research unit.
The research unit shall:

subparagraph.text: engage in and direct fundamental archaeological research;
synthesize existing research information; and
encourage archaeological research and investigation by museums, institutions of higher education, and scientific and historical institutions and organizations in the State.

paragraph.text: The Director shall employ a Chief Archaeologist, a State Terrestrial Archaeologist, and a State Underwater Archaeologist in accordance with § 5A-316 of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Each archaeologist employed under this subsection shall have an advanced degree in archaeology or a closely related field from an accredited college or university.
The Chief Archaeologist shall be a professional archaeologist.

paragraph.text: The Chief Archaeologist is the administrative head of the Archaeology Office.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Archaeology Office includes all staff members of the Trust who are archaeologists or hired to perform archaeological work, including those who may be assigned archaeological-related functions in other units of the Trust.
The Archaeology Office does not include individuals specifically assigned to a park, museum, or other site-specific facility under the jurisdiction of the Trust.

subsection.text: The Archaeology Office shall:

paragraph.text: cooperate in excavating historically or archaeologically significant sites in the custody or control of any other State unit;
encourage the preservation of prehistoric or historic sites on privately owned land in the State;
coordinate the work of retrieving and preserving archaeologically significant objects and materials found during public construction in the State;

cooperate with and help museums, institutions of higher education, and other scientific or historical institutions and organizations in preserving and protecting objects and materials of archaeological nature in their custody or control;
cooperate with similar units of other states in preserving archaeologically significant sites, objects, and materials; and
keep institutions or units of other states from exploiting archaeologically significant sites, objects, and materials in this State.

subsection.text: The Archaeology Office also shall:

paragraph.text: make available to museums, institutions of higher education, and other scientific or historical institutions and organizations objects and materials suitable for demonstrating the archaeological history of the State;
make available to public and private schools in the State exhibits on, and help to teach students about, the life of the early settlers and Native Americans of the State;
disseminate archaeological information by publishing reports of archaeological research and investigation; and
establish an educational program to train interested members of the public to identify, investigate, and register terrestrial archaeological historic property.

subsection.text: The Archaeology Office also shall:

paragraph.text: prepare a list of prioritized research goals and objectives to guide the Trust and the Department’s Division of Historical and Cultural Programs in choosing archaeological research projects to perform;

develop, in consultation with the Committee, a policy that specifies the circumstances under which the Trust may directly perform archaeological investigations to comply with State or federal law that the Trust or the State Historic Preservation Officer administers; and

provide to the Committee each year a copy of the part of the Trust’s annual report to the Governor, required by § 5A-318(c)(16) of this subtitle, that relates to the Trust’s archaeological activities.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an archaeologist who is not working for the Trust need not adhere to the archaeological research goals and objectives developed by the Archaeology Office under this section.

An archaeologist who performs a project governed by any State or federal law that the Trust or the State Historic Preservation Officer administers shall adhere to those goals and objectives to the extent required by law.

subsection.text: There is an Advisory Committee on Archaeology.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of seven members appointed by the Governor on recommendation of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

The Committee shall include representatives of reputable museums, institutions of higher education, other recognized scientific or historical institutions or organizations, and qualified private firms that provide archaeological services.

subsection.text: Each member of the Committee shall have skill and knowledge in archaeological matters.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Committee on October 1, 2005.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Committee shall elect a chair from among its members.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall meet at least four times a year at the times and places that the chair sets.
At every meeting at least one of the following officers shall attend:

subparagraph.text: the Chief Archaeologist;
the State Terrestrial Archaeologist; or
the State Underwater Archaeologist.

subsection.text: A member of the Committee:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation for duties performed as a member; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Committee shall:

paragraph.text: advise and assist the Archaeology Office on archaeological matters; and
review policies, plans, and regulations relating to archaeological matters.

section.text: A person who knows the location of an archaeological site in the State is encouraged to give the information to a reputable museum, an institution of higher education, another recognized scientific or historical institution or organization, or the Trust.
The costs of archaeological work incurred in a State project on a site of archaeological or historical significance shall be as stated in § 7-114.1 of this article.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section and elsewhere in this title, an object or material of historical or archaeological value or interest found on a submerged or terrestrial archaeological site on land that the State owns or controls:

paragraph.text: is the property of the State; and
shall be deposited for permanent preservation with a reputable museum, an institution of higher education, or another recognized scientific or historical institution or organization.

Subject to applicable federal law and paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Trust may transfer Native American or other human remains in its possession, custody, or control to an appropriate place of repose.

If the cultural affiliation of human remains and associated funerary objects in the possession, custody, or control of the Trust can be established, the Trust may transfer the human remains and associated funerary objects in the following order of priority to:

subparagraph.text: the descendants of the deceased; or
a group established as culturally affiliated with the deceased, including a Native American tribe, band, group, or clan.

paragraph.text: Except for human remains of Native Americans and associated funerary objects subject to subsection (b)(2) of this section, the Trust may transfer any human remains and associated funerary objects in its possession, custody, or control to a reputable museum, an institution of higher education, or another recognized scientific or historical institution or organization for study, if:

subparagraph.text: the study is an essential part of scientific research;
the outcome of the scientific research will benefit the State; and
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the study will be completed and the items returned to the Trust within 1 year after the date of the transfer.
If a transferee under this subsection makes a good faith effort but cannot complete a study within 1 year, the transferee may request an extension from the Trust.
The Trust may grant the extension only in accordance with its regulations.

paragraph.text: In consultation with the Commission on Indian Affairs, the Trust shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.
The regulations shall include:

subparagraph.text: procedures to determine the appropriate disposition of human remains for which descent or cultural affiliation cannot be established;
specific time frames and procedures to extend a study of human remains and associated funerary objects beyond 1 year; and

procedures to account for any human remains and associated funerary objects that temporarily are transferred for study to a reputable museum, an institution of higher education, or another recognized scientific or historical institution or organization.

subsection.text: Submerged archaeological historic property on or taken from underwater land over which the State has sovereign control is the property of the State.

The State may convey title to part or all of submerged archaeological historic property it owns in accordance with a permit, if the Board of Public Works approves the permit in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 3 of this article.

paragraph.text: The Trust and a holder of a permit under § 5A-341 of this subtitle may enter into an agreement to dispose of submerged archaeological historic property recovered by the holder.
The agreement may divide the recovered submerged archaeological historic property between the State and the holder.
Subject to approval of the Board of Public Works, the division may be in value or in kind.
The Trust shall be the arbiter of the division, acting in the best interest of the State and giving consideration to the fair treatment of the permit holder.
An agreement under this subsection shall provide reasonable compensation to the permit holder for any recovered submerged archaeological historic property claimed and turned over to the State.

subsection.text: The Trust shall:

paragraph.text: establish an educational program to train interested members of the public to identify and register submerged archaeological historic property; and
certify members of the public who successfully complete the educational program.
The Trust shall adopt regulations on issuing permits and disposing of and transferring submerged archaeological historic property under this subtitle.
The regulations shall be adopted:

subparagraph.text: with the approval of the Secretary; and

in consultation with the Federal Advisory Council on Historic Preservation and appropriate public and private sector groups in the State, including sport divers, professional dive operators, dive clubs, salvors, archaeologists, commercial fishermen, and historic preservationists.

subsection.text: Without a permit, a person may not excavate, remove, destroy, injure, deface, or disturb a submerged archaeological historic property on land over which the State has sovereign control.

A person does not need a permit to inspect, study, explore, photograph, measure, record, or otherwise use and enjoy submerged archaeological historic property on land over which the State has sovereign control if the use or activity does not:

paragraph.text: involve the excavation, removal, destruction, injury, or disturbance of the submerged archaeological historic property or its immediate environment;
endanger other persons or property; or
violate any law.

Regulations under § 5A-340(e) of this subtitle shall provide that an individual does not need a permit to collect from submerged archaeological historic property a limited number of objects or materials recoverable by hand or with the use of screwdrivers, wrenches, or pliers.
The State is not liable for injury or loss sustained by an individual engaged in activity authorized in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Trust does not need a permit to do anything for which a permit is required under this section, but shall obtain approval for the undertaking from the Board of Public Works.

The Trust shall establish a program for issuing and administering permits for activity that involves the removal, excavation, destruction, injury, or disturbance of submerged archaeological historic property on land over which the State has sovereign control.

Subject to subsection (g) of this section, the Trust may issue to any person a permit granting an exclusive right to remove, excavate, destroy, injure, or disturb submerged archaeological historic property on land over which the State has sovereign control for the term and under the conditions that the Trust considers appropriate if:

paragraph.text: the Trust and the applicant for the permit have entered into an agreement under § 5A-340(c) of this subtitle; and

the Trust determines that issuing the permit is in the best interest of the State and that the applicant for the permit has submitted a research plan that meets standards established by the Trust for:

subparagraph.text: professional qualifications of the applicant and persons working under the permit;
techniques and methodology for the recovery and dissemination of data; and
proper conservation of information and materials.

subsection.text: The Trust may not issue a permit to a person that seeks title to part or all of submerged archaeological historic property, or to a person that seeks to use submerged archaeological historic property for commercial salvage or another income-producing purpose, unless:

paragraph.text: the applicant has provided the Trust with assurance acceptable to the Trust that the project will be carried out and completed in accordance with a research plan under subsection (f)(2) of this section; and
the Trust finds that:

subparagraph.text: the submerged archaeological historic property is threatened with imminent destruction or substantial damage by natural or human factors unrelated to the proposed commercial excavation or disturbance;
the submerged archaeological historic property is not of major scientific, archaeological, anthropological, historical, recreational, or other public value;

the proposed excavation or disturbance will be minor and will produce information relevant to the statewide comprehensive historic preservation plan prepared by the Trust under § 5A-318(c)(4) of this subtitle; or
the submerged archaeological historic property will not be excavated or disturbed by any other person in the foreseeable future and will remain submerged until it is excavated or disturbed.

subsection.text: The Trust may charge a reasonable fee to issue a permit and may require an applicant or permit holder to pay for the cost of the Trust’s review, administration, and supervision of the permit.
The Director or the Director’s designee may enforce this section and may:

paragraph.text: issue a summons for a violation of this section or of a permit issued under this section;

seize objects or materials removed from a submerged archaeological historic property, if the removal took place without a permit on or after July 1, 1988, or if the removal was contrary to the terms of a permit; and
revoke a permit on a finding that the permit was issued improperly or the terms of the permit have been violated.

subsection.text: Without a permit, a person may not excavate, remove, destroy, injure, deface, or disturb a terrestrial archaeological site on land that the State owns or controls.
The Trust does not need a permit to do anything for which a permit is required under this section.

The Trust may issue a permit to excavate a terrestrial archaeological site on land the State owns or controls to any person that the Trust determines is qualified to conduct an excavation to collect objects and materials of historical or archaeological value or interest.

A terrestrial archaeological excavation may be conducted only to benefit a reputable museum, an institution of higher education, or another recognized scientific or historical institution or organization, so as to increase knowledge and appreciation of historical and archaeological objects and materials.
The Trust may adopt regulations to ensure that objects and materials collected in a terrestrial archaeological excavation are properly safeguarded and preserved.

The Director or the Director’s designee may enforce the provisions of this subtitle relating to terrestrial archaeological historic property in the same manner as provided in § 5A-341(i) of this subtitle for submerged archaeological historic property.

paragraph.text: This section applies to all archaeological, prehistoric, and historic features found in any cave, including:

subparagraph.text: all or any part of any burial grounds, historic or prehistoric ruins, and archaeological sites; and
relics, inscriptions, saltpeter workings, fossils, bones, and remains of historical human activity.

paragraph.text: Without a permit issued under this section, a person may not excavate, remove, destroy, injure, deface, or disturb features found in a cave.

subsection.text: In accordance with §§ 5A-341 and 5A-342 of this subtitle, an individual trained in archaeology may apply for and be issued a permit to excavate or remove features described in subsection (a) of this section from or in a cave on land that the State owns or controls by rights under a lease, option contract, or purchase contract.

paragraph.text: An individual may apply for a permit to excavate or remove archaeological, prehistoric, and historic features from a cave on privately owned land.
An applicant for a permit shall:

subparagraph.text: be trained in archaeology;
give the Trust a detailed statement of the purposes and objectives of the proposed excavation or removal;
agree to provide the Trust with information from and results of any excavation, study, or collection in accordance with the terms of the permit;
obtain the prior written consent of the owner of the land on which the excavation or removal will be conducted; and
agree to carry the permit while conducting the excavation or removal authorized by the permit.

paragraph.text: A permit may be issued for a maximum term of 2 years and may be renewed.
A permit is not transferable, but a person working under the direct supervision of the permit holder need not obtain a separate permit.

subsection.text: Any object or material of archaeological, prehistoric, or historic value or interest found in a cave on privately owned land is the property of the owner of the land.

If a person uses a cave for recreational or scientific purposes with the prior consent of and without a charge by the owner and sustains an injury, the owner and an authorized agent of the owner acting within the scope of the agent’s authority are not liable for the injury.

The Director and the Director’s designee may enforce the provisions of this part relating to archaeological historic property found in caves in the same manner as provided in § 5A-341(i) of this subtitle for submerged archaeological historic property.

If the Director or the Director’s designee takes any enforcement action under this subtitle against a permit holder, the permit holder shall be given an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
Subject to subsection (c) of this section, notice shall be given and the hearing shall be held in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Director or the Director’s designee shall provide notice that a hearing will be held within 30 days after the enforcement action, unless a different period is agreed to by the parties.

The provisions of this subtitle that protect property on land under State control if it is submerged archaeological historic property, terrestrial archaeological historic property, or archaeological historic property in a cave may apply to similar historic property on privately owned land if:

paragraph.text: the owner asks the Trust in writing to apply the provisions to the property; and
the Trust determines that the property is eligible for the Maryland Register of Historic Properties and deserves protection.

subsection.text: Unless the State controls privately owned land by rights under a lease, option contract, or purchase contract, this subtitle does not:

paragraph.text: limit the use of the land by the owner or the owner’s guest; or
require the owner or guest to hold a permit before conducting any activity on the land.

A person who violates § 5A-339, § 5A-341, § 5A-342, or § 5A-343 of this subtitle, or a regulation adopted under any of those sections is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
If a person is found guilty of a violation under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the court:

subparagraph.text: may impose costs against the person; and
on request by the Trust, may revoke any permit issued to the person under § 5A-340, § 5A-341, § 5A-342, or § 5A-343 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Each day on which a violation occurs is a separate violation.

A person who violates any term of a permit issued under § 5A-341 of this subtitle for use of a submerged archaeological historic property for commercial salvage or other income-producing purpose is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $10,000 or both.
If a person is found guilty of a violation under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the court:

subparagraph.text: may impose costs against the person; and
on request by the Trust, may revoke the person’s permit.

paragraph.text: Each day on which a violation occurs is a separate violation.

subsection.text: Materials and recorded information obtained in violation of § 5A-339, § 5A-341, § 5A-342, or § 5A-343 of this subtitle are subject to appropriation by the State and will be managed, cared for, and administered by the Trust.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Operating support” means money for necessary administrative, technical, or professional services, and related expenses.
“Panel” means the Museum Assistance Review Panel.
“Program” means the Historical and Cultural Museum Assistance Program.

section.text: This part applies to a museum in the State that:

paragraph.text: is organized on a nonprofit basis for essentially educational or preservation purposes;
cares for tangible inanimate objects that the museum owns or uses;
exhibits those objects to the public on a regular schedule; and
interprets the State’s cultural heritage, history, natural history, or history of science and technology.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: museums present, interpret, and preserve unusual and significant objects of the State’s heritage for the benefit, enjoyment, and education of the residents of the State;
museums are unique and beneficial resources that supplement the State’s educational system;
museums are repositories and caretakers of irreplaceable cultural objects for the benefit of today’s generation and generations yet to come;
museums, including those located in small communities, play an important and cost-effective role in the State’s leisure time and tourism industry;
it is not feasible or desirable to display the entire history and heritage of the State in a single facility at one location;

the history and heritage of the State should be displayed and interpreted to the public where the history happened and the heritage arose, so that centers of community pride may be created and tourist activity may be dispersed throughout the State; and
the public interest is served by helping museums to become more accessible and by helping residents of the State and visitors to understand the State’s diverse heritage.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that the public interest is served by establishing a program of financial assistance to support the upgrade, care, research, interpretation, documentation, and display of the State’s irreplaceable museum collections.

section.text: There is a Historical and Cultural Museum Assistance Program of the Trust.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Program is to provide political subdivisions and nonprofit organizations with financial assistance for museums.
The Program shall make grants from the MHT Grant Fund under § 5A-328 of this subtitle to political subdivisions and nonprofit organizations for use by museums for:

paragraph.text: research related to collections, exhibits, or other educational activities;
the care, conservation, interpretation, and documentation of collections;
the planning, design, and construction of exhibits;
educational programs and projects;
the development of master plans for museums, including activities required to achieve accreditation by the American Association of Museums or another appropriate entity;
minor structural modifications to existing museum facilities;
the development of plans and specifications and the provision of architectural, engineering, or other special services directly related to the construction or rehabilitation of museum facilities; or
operating support for any museum-related activity, including activities described in items (1) through (7) of this subsection.

subsection.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Trust shall report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the financial status and the activities of the Program for the preceding fiscal year.
There is a Museum Assistance Review Panel in the Program.

paragraph.text: The Panel shall include as members:

subparagraph.text: the President of the Senate or the President’s designee; and
the Speaker of the House of Delegates or the Speaker’s designee.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall appoint the other members of the Panel.
Of the members that the Secretary appoints:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a representative of the Executive Branch with functions related to the purposes of the Program; and
the others shall fairly represent museums eligible for assistance under this part.

paragraph.text: The Panel shall:

subparagraph.text: advise the Secretary and the staff of the Trust regarding Program policies and activities;
review applications for grants under the Program and recommend approval or disapproval to the Secretary; and
seek the advice and recommendations of the State Archivist in reviewing grant applications that relate in any part to the care and preservation of, or access to, archival material.

paragraph.text: The Panel shall recommend approval of a grant only after a competitive selection process.

subsection.text: The Trust shall administer the Program and coordinate the Program with federal, State, and private programs that complement or facilitate carrying out the Program.
The Trust shall:

paragraph.text: survey the locations, resources, and needs of museums in the State;
provide technical and general advisory assistance to museums that qualify or seek to qualify for grants under the Program; and

encourage museums to develop long-range plans and to achieve accreditation by the American Association of Museums or another appropriate entity that accredits museums and helps them to meet professional standards.

section.text: The Trust may not make a grant to a museum that:

paragraph.text: currently is receiving operating support from the Maryland State Arts Council;
is operated wholly or partly by the State; or
has not existed as a nonprofit organization for at least 3 years before applying for the grant.

section.text: In any fiscal year, the Secretary may reserve up to 20% of the money available in the MHT Grant Fund under § 5A-328 of this subtitle for unanticipated projects eligible for assistance under § 5A-353 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the Program, including:

paragraph.text: application and review procedures;
procedures for adequate public notice of assistance available under the Program; and
selection standards that the Panel shall consider in reviewing applications for grants.

subsection.text: Selection standards under subsection (a)(3) of this section include:

paragraph.text: the relative merits of the project or activities within identified statewide needs;
the extent to which the appropriate political subdivision contributes to support the project;
the potential for the project to stimulate increased tourism, museum attendance, or museum self-sufficiency; and
other relevant factors, such as the extent to which the project helps achieve equal geographic distribution of grant assistance throughout the State.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a material misstatement of fact in a statement or report in or regarding an application for a grant or affecting a grant already made.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Committee” means the Maryland Advisory Committee on Historic Agricultural Structure Preservation.
“Fund” means the Maryland Barn Preservation Fund.
There is a Maryland Advisory Committee on Historic Agricultural Structure Preservation.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 10 members.
The ex officio members are:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary of Agriculture, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Planning, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust; and
the Director of the Maryland Cooperative Extension.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the other five members, of whom:

subparagraph.text: one shall be from a list of at least two nominees representing the Maryland State Grange;
one shall be from a list of at least two nominees representing the Maryland Farm Bureau;
two shall be individuals actively engaged in agriculture; and
one shall be a member of the Maryland Environmental Trust.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Planning serves as chair.
The term of an appointed member is 4 years.
A member of the Committee:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: There is a Barn Preservation Fund in the Department of Planning.
The Fund shall be used to make grants to preserve historic barns and agricultural structures in the State.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: To apply for a grant, an applicant shall submit to the Committee an application in the form that the Committee requires.
On a recommendation from the Committee, the Board of Public Works shall approve expenditures from the Fund in the form of grants to preserve historic barns and agricultural structures.
In recommending grants under this subtitle, the Committee shall consider:

paragraph.text: any historic building features;
important examples of historic agricultural building types;
the productive long-term use of the property;
important local landmarks;
structures that are located on designated scenic and cultural byways; and
structures that accept a preservation easement.

subsection.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Committee shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the financial status and the activities of the Fund for the preceding fiscal year.

section.text: The Department of Planning shall adopt any regulations necessary to implement this subtitle.

If a recipient of a grant under this subtitle or subsequent owner of a property that was assisted by a grant under this subtitle takes any action within 10 years of the grant award with respect to the assisted building or structure, such as dismantlement, removal, or substantial alteration, which causes it to no longer be eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places, within 1 year from the date of loss of eligibility, the preservation grant shall be repaid in full to the Fund.
Receipt of a grant award under this subtitle and conditions of the award shall be recorded in the land records for the county in which the historic barn or agricultural structure is located.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of Revenue Estimates.
“Bureau” means the Bureau of Revenue Estimates.
“Chief” means the Chief of the Bureau.
There is a Board of Revenue Estimates.
The Board consists of the following 3 ex officio members:

paragraph.text: the Comptroller;
the Treasurer; and
the Secretary of Budget and Management.

subsection.text: The Treasurer may appoint, as the Treasurer’s designee, a deputy treasurer to serve on the Board.
The Chief is the executive secretary of the Board.
There is a Bureau of Revenue Estimates in the Office of the Comptroller.

paragraph.text: The head of the Bureau is the Chief.
Subject to the supervision of the Comptroller, the Chief has administrative control of the Bureau.

Unless the Comptroller, with the approval of the Board, determines that an alternative structure is appropriate, the Chief shall be subject to the supervision of the Deputy Comptroller with responsibility for tax administration.
Except as otherwise provided by law, subject to the approval of the Board, the Comptroller shall appoint the Chief.
The Chief may be removed only by a majority of the Board for incompetence or other good cause.
The Chief shall appoint other employees of the Bureau in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
After the end of each fiscal year, the Bureau shall submit to the Board a report that:

subparagraph.text: contains an itemized statement of the State revenues from all sources for that fiscal year; and
includes any recommendations of the Bureau.

paragraph.text: In December, March, and September of each year, the Bureau shall submit to the Board a report that contains an itemized statement of the estimated State revenues from all sources for the fiscal year following the fiscal year in which the report is made.
The Bureau shall provide to the Board any other information that the Board requests.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the reports required under paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection shall include an itemized statement of:

subparagraph.text: revenues or estimated revenues distributed to the Transportation Trust Fund, including the motor fuel taxes imposed under Title 9, Subtitle 3 of the Tax – General Article and motor vehicle titling taxes imposed under Title 13, Subtitle 8 of the Transportation Article; and
revenues from the State transfer tax imposed under Title 13, Subtitle 2 of the Tax – Property Article.

subsection.text: In addition to these reports, the Bureau shall continually conduct studies of State revenue sources to:

paragraph.text: determine the amount of revenue produced; and
devise and recommend new methods and sources for improved efficiency, equity, and economy in production, collection, and estimation of revenue.

On or before December 1, 2008, and December 1 of every third year thereafter, the Bureau shall submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly a tax incidence study measuring the burden of all the major taxes imposed by the State and how that burden is shared among taxpayers of different income levels.
The Bureau shall prepare and submit the statistics of income report required under § 10–223 of the Tax – General Article.

subsection.text: In this section, “Group” means the Consensus Revenue Monitoring and Forecasting Group established under this section.
There is a Consensus Revenue Monitoring and Forecasting Group.
The Group consists of:

paragraph.text: the Chief and staff of the Bureau as designated by the Chief;
the Deputy Comptroller with responsibility for tax administration and staff as designated by the Deputy Comptroller with responsibility for tax administration;
staff of the Office of the Treasurer as designated by the Treasurer;
staff of the Department of Budget and Management as designated by the Secretary of Budget and Management;
staff of the Department of Transportation as designated by the Secretary of Transportation; and
staff of the Office of Policy Analysis of the Department of Legislative Services as designated by the Director of the Office.

subsection.text: The Chief shall chair the Group.
The Group and its constituent units shall:

paragraph.text: review and analyze attainment of revenues on a monthly basis; and
advise and collaborate with the Bureau:

subparagraph.text: in the development of revenue forecasts and any necessary revisions to those forecasts; and
in the performance of any pertinent studies or analyses as requested by the Chief or as directed by the Board.

subsection.text: To assist the Group in performing its function, the Comptroller and the Bureau shall:

paragraph.text: within 7 calendar days after the end of each month, provide to members of the Group detailed data on revenue collections; and
before any document relating to the work of the Bureau is published, provide a draft of the document to the members of the Group for review and comment.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: study the information that the Bureau provides; and
consider the recommendations of the Bureau.
In December, March, and September of each year, the Board shall submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly, a report that:

subparagraph.text: contains an itemized statement of the estimated State revenues from all sources for the fiscal year following the fiscal year in which the report is made; and
includes any recommendations of the Board.

Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the Governor shall state the most recent estimates of revenues reported by the Board in the proposed budget and any supplemental budget submitted to the General Assembly.

If the Governor uses different estimates of revenues in the formulation of the proposed budget and any supplemental budget submitted to the General Assembly than those reported by the Board, a statement providing an explanation as to the differences shall be included together with those submissions.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Banking institution” means an institution that is incorporated under the laws of the State as a State bank, trust company, or savings bank.
“Collateral” means collateral that is listed under § 6-202 of this subtitle.
“Deposit insurance” means insurance by:

paragraph.text: the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; or
the Resolution Trust Corporation created under § 21A of the Federal Home Loan Bank Act (12 U.S.C. § 1441a.).

subsection.text: “Financial institution” means:

paragraph.text: any banking institution;
any national banking association;
an institution that is incorporated under the laws of any other state as a bank; and
an institution that is incorporated under the laws of this State or of the United States as a savings and loan association.

subsection.text: “National banking association” means an institution that is incorporated under federal law as a bank.

“State money” for purposes of §§ 6-209 and 6-210 of this subtitle includes moneys in a bank account maintained under the control of an employee or official of the clerk of the court or register of wills.

section.text: Collateral that may be used under this subtitle shall be:

paragraph.text: an obligation of the United States or any of its agencies;
an obligation guaranteed by the United States or by any of its agencies;
an obligation insured by the United States;
an obligation of the State or any of its units or instrumentalities;
an obligation of a county of the State or any of its agencies;
an obligation of a municipal corporation in the State or any of its agencies;
an obligation of any other governmental authority in the State;
an obligation of the Inter–America Development Bank;
an obligation of the World Bank;
an obligation of the following government–sponsored enterprises:

subparagraph.text: the Federal Home Loan Banks;
the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation;
the Federal National Mortgage Association;
the Farm Credit System;
the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation; and
the Student Loan Marketing Association;

paragraph.text: a surety bond if:

subparagraph.text: subject to the terms and conditions of the bond, it is irrevocable and absolute;
the surety bond is issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this State;

the issuer of the surety bonds does not provide surety bonds for any one financial institution in an amount that exceeds 10% of the surety bond insurer’s policyholders’ surplus and contingency reserve, net of reinsurance; and

the claims–paying ability of the authorized insurance company is rated, at all relevant times, in the highest category by at least two nationally recognized rating agencies acceptable to the Treasurer;

paragraph.text: an obligation or security of, or other interest in, any open–end or closed–end management type investment company or investment trust registered under the provisions of the federal Investment Company Act of 1940, 15 U.S.C. § 80a–1 et seq., if:

subparagraph.text: the portfolio of the open–end or closed–end management type investment company or investment trust is limited to direct obligations of the United States government and to repurchase agreements fully collateralized by United States government obligations; and
the open–end or closed–end management type investment company or investment trust takes delivery of that collateral, either directly or through an authorized custodian; or

paragraph.text: a letter of credit issued by a Federal Home Loan Bank if the letter of credit meets the conditions under the guidelines issued by the State Treasurer’s office.

subsection.text: The Treasurer shall give 15% of the weight of the decision to the standards established in this section in deciding whether to:

paragraph.text: designate a financial institution as a depositary for State money under § 6-205 of this subtitle; and
make an agreement with a financial institution for a banking service under § 6-229 of this subtitle.

The Treasurer shall consider whether the financial institution received a rating of “needs improvement” or “substantial noncompliance” in its most recent examination under the federal Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, P.L. Number 95-128.

If a financial institution operates in a state other than Maryland, the Treasurer shall consider Maryland-specific information that is provided within the assessment area section of the Community Reinvestment Act report.

The Treasurer shall consider whether, during the previous 5 years, a court in Maryland has found, in a final adjudication, that a financial institution has violated any antidiscrimination statute or regulation.

The Treasurer may consider whether, during the previous 5 years, a court outside Maryland has found, in a final adjudication, that a financial institution has violated any antidiscrimination statute or regulation.
The Treasurer may determine how to assess a violation under paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection if the violation was committed by:

subparagraph.text: an affiliate of the financial institution; or
an entity acquired by the financial institution.

subsection.text: The Treasurer shall consider whether the financial institution has demonstrated that during the previous 5 years, the financial institution has:

paragraph.text: successfully made loans in Maryland through State or federal lending programs designed to assist small and minority-owned businesses;
had an active outreach program to assist small and minority-owned businesses through which the financial institution has made efforts in Maryland; and
established strategic partnerships in Maryland with entities whose mission is to provide technical assistance to small and minority-owned businesses.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this subtitle and in any other law, the Treasurer may designate any financial institution as a depositary for State money.

The Treasurer may designate foreign banks and similar institutions as depositaries for the purpose of conducting State government activities outside the United States. The deposits in such institutions may not exceed the amount appropriated in the budget for conducting State government activities outside the United States.

section.text: The Treasurer may not designate a financial institution or a foreign institution as a depositary unless the Governor approves the designation.

subsection.text: State money on deposit with a financial institution shall be secured by:

paragraph.text: deposit insurance; or
collateral as required by this section.
The collateral for State money on deposit with a financial institution:

subparagraph.text: must have, at all times, a market value that equals or exceeds the State money that is on deposit with the financial institution and is not covered by deposit insurance; and
must be approved by the Treasurer.

paragraph.text: If the collateral is a surety bond under § 6-202 of this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: the surety bond shall be in a form and amount acceptable to the Treasurer as determined by the Treasurer from time to time; and

the financial institution that provides the surety bond as collateral shall immediately notify the Treasurer if the rating assigned to the issuing insurance company by any rating agency, found acceptable to the Treasurer under § 6-202 of this subtitle, is withdrawn or downgraded, in which event the financial institution shall immediately provide the Treasurer with substitute collateral permitted under § 6-202 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Subject to the requirements of this subsection, a financial institution may change its collateral from time to time.
A custodian shall hold the collateral under this section for the benefit of the State.
A financial institution may use as a custodian:

subparagraph.text: any banking institution that is approved by the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to conduct commercial banking business in the State;
a federal reserve bank; or
any national banking association that is approved by the Comptroller of the Currency to conduct banking business in the State.

paragraph.text: A financial institution may not be approved as custodian for the collateral of a depositary unless the assets of the financial institution equal or exceed 200% of the value of the collateral to be held for the depositary.
On request of the Treasurer, a depositary for State money shall submit to the Treasurer or a designee of the Treasurer a report that states:

subparagraph.text: the total amount of State money on deposit with the depositary;
the total amount of collateral and deposit insurance for the money; and
the market value of the collateral for the money.

paragraph.text: Each national banking association that is a depositary for State money shall submit to the Comptroller of the Currency each report for which the Comptroller asks.
Each banking institution that is a depositary for State money shall submit to the Commissioner of Financial Regulation each report for which the Commissioner asks.

Each other bank that is a depositary for State money shall submit to the banking authority for the state where the bank has its principal office each report for which the banking authority of that state asks.

subsection.text: On request of the Treasurer a custodian shall submit to the Treasurer or a designee of the Treasurer a report that states the total amount of collateral that a depositary has with the custodian.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2021 PER CHAPTER 396 OF 2006 AND CHAPTER 740 OF 2009 //

paragraph.text: There is a Linked Deposit Program in the Department of Housing and Community Development.

The purpose of the Linked Deposit Program is to stimulate opportunities for minority business enterprises to have access to credit by assisting these businesses in obtaining loans at lower than market interest rates.

subsection.text: A loan qualifies under the Linked Deposit Program if the loan:

paragraph.text: satisfies the financial institution’s lending criteria;
has a term not exceeding 10 years;
is made to a minority business enterprise certified under Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article;
has an interest rate that is 2 percentage points below the interest rate the financial institution would charge for a loan for a similar purpose and a similar term; and
has points or fees charged at loan closing not exceeding 1 percent of the loan amount.

subsection.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development shall:

paragraph.text: confirm with the certification agency designated under Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article that each loan under the Linked Deposit Program is made to a business that is certified as a minority business enterprise;

establish procedures for notification by the certification agency designated under Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article if a business that has an outstanding balance of a loan under the Linked Deposit Program is no longer certified;
require minority business enterprises and lenders to notify the Department concerning final loan disposition; and
report annually to the Governor, the Treasurer, and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on overall performance of the Linked Deposit Program.

subsection.text: The Treasurer may establish the Linked Deposit Program for investment of deposits in any financial institution that:

paragraph.text: the Treasurer has designated as a depository for State money; and
makes a loan in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.
The Treasurer may make one or more interest bearing deposits that are equal to:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the loan made by the financial institution in accordance with subsection (b) of this section; or
the aggregate amount of two or more loans made by one or more financial institutions in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: In making an interest bearing deposit under this subsection, the Treasurer may accept a rate that is 2 percentage points below current market rates or an index selected by the Treasurer.
The Treasurer may use up to $50,000,000 to make interest bearing deposits in an amount equivalent to the amount financial institutions loan to certified minority business enterprises.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, on notification by the Department of Housing and Community Development that a minority business enterprise participating in the Linked Deposit Program is no longer certified under Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article, the Treasurer shall reduce the amount of the interest bearing deposit with the participating financial institution by the outstanding balance of the loan made under this section to the decertified minority business enterprise.
A minority business enterprise that loses its certification due to revenue or employee growth may not be considered decertified for purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection.
A loan assisted by a linked deposit is not a debt of the State or a pledge of the credit of the State.
The Treasurer and the State are not liable to any financial institution for payment of the principal or interest on a loan assisted by a linked deposit.

subsection.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development and the Treasurer may adopt regulations to carry out this section.

paragraph.text: There is a Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses in the Department of Housing and Community Development.

The purpose of the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses is to stimulate opportunities for small businesses to have access to credit by assisting these businesses in obtaining loans at lower than market interest rates.

subsection.text: A loan qualifies under the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses if the loan:

paragraph.text: satisfies the lending criteria of the financial institution;
has a term not exceeding 10 years;
is made to a small business qualified under Title 14, Subtitle 5 of this article;
has an interest rate that is 2 percentage points below the interest rate the financial institution would charge for a loan for a similar purpose and a similar term; and
has points or fees charged at loan closing not exceeding 1 percent of the loan amount.

subsection.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development shall:

paragraph.text: confirm with the Department of General Services that each loan under the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses is made to a business that qualifies as a small business;

establish procedures for notification by the Department of General Services if a business that has an outstanding balance of a loan under the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses no longer qualifies as a small business;
require small businesses and lenders to notify the Department of Housing and Community Development concerning final loan disposition; and

report annually to the Governor, the Treasurer, and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on overall performance of the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses.

subsection.text: The Treasurer may establish the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses for investment of deposits in any financial institution that:

paragraph.text: the Treasurer has designated as a depository for State money; and
makes a loan in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.
The Treasurer may make one or more interest bearing deposits that are equal to:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the loan made by the financial institution in accordance with subsection (b) of this section; or
the aggregate amount of two or more loans made by one or more financial institutions in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: In making an interest bearing deposit under this subsection, the Treasurer may accept a rate that is 2 percentage points below current market rates or an index selected by the Treasurer.
The Treasurer may use up to $50,000,000 to make interest bearing deposits in an amount equivalent to the amount financial institutions loan to qualified small businesses.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, on notification by the Department of Housing and Community Development that a small business participating in the Linked Deposit Program for Small Businesses no longer qualifies as a small business under Title 14, Subtitle 5 of this article, the Treasurer shall reduce the amount of the interest bearing deposit with the participating financial institution by the outstanding balance of the loan made under this section to the small business that no longer qualifies under Title 14, Subtitle 5 of this article.
A small business that loses its qualification due to revenue or employee growth may not be considered unqualified for purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection.
A loan assisted by a linked deposit is not a debt of the State or a pledge of the credit of the State.
The Treasurer and the State are not liable to any financial institution for payment of the principal or interest on a loan assisted by a linked deposit.

subsection.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development and the Treasurer may adopt regulations to carry out this section.
Except as otherwise provided by law, in accordance with regulations and policies adopted by the Treasurer and the Comptroller, each unit of the State government shall:

paragraph.text: pay into depositaries designated by the Treasurer for the account of the State Treasury all collections, fees, income, and other revenues that are received by the unit; and
account to the Comptroller for those revenues.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall credit the revenues that a unit pays into depositaries designated by the Treasurer for the account of the State Treasury:

paragraph.text: to the account that the law specifies; or
if the law does not specify an account, to an account that the Comptroller designates for the use of the unit.
With the approval of the Governor, the Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: shall exempt revenues from the requirements of subsection (a) of this section if the Comptroller determines that the exemption would be in the public interest; and
may rescind an exemption.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall keep a record that shows each exemption and the reasons for it.
The records shall be kept in the Office of the Comptroller and shall be open to public inspection.
In this subsection, “State institution” includes a hospital or center that the State operates.
The Treasurer may exclude from the State Treasury the personal funds that a State institution holds for its residents or clients.
A State institution shall use, as a depositary for these funds, a financial institution that the Treasurer approves.
The Treasurer may require the submission of a proposed agreement between the State institution and the financial institution and may approve or disapprove the agreement.
The accounts established by a State institution shall be interest bearing accounts.
All interest on money of a resident or client of a State institution shall be credited to the resident or client.
A State institution shall:

subparagraph.text: keep records of all transactions that involve money of a resident or client; and
provide the resident or client with a statement of those transactions at least each 6 months and on discharge.

section.text: Each person who collects or receives money for the State and who is not subject to § 6-213(a) of this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: pay the money into the State Treasury as provided by law; and
account to the Comptroller for the money:

subparagraph.text: at the times and in the manner that the law specifies; or
if the law does not specify the time and manner, as the Comptroller considers necessary.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may not allow a warrant for payment of money into the State Treasury to be issued until a record is made in the Office of the Comptroller.
