buying or otherwise obtaining supplies, services, construction, construction related services, architectural services, engineering services, or services provided under an energy performance contract.

paragraph.text: “Procurement” includes the solicitation and award of procurement contracts and all phases of procurement contract administration.
“Procurement contract” means an agreement in any form entered into by a unit for procurement.
“Procurement contract” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a collective bargaining agreement with an employee organization;
an agreement with a contractual employee, as defined in § 1-101(d) of the State Personnel and Pensions Article;
a Medicaid, Judicare, or similar reimbursement contract for which law sets:

sub-subparagraph.text: user or recipient eligibility; and
price payable by the State; or

subparagraph.text: a Medicaid contract with a managed care organization, as defined in § 15-101(e) of the Health - General Article as to which regulations adopted by the Department establish:

sub-subparagraph.text: recipient eligibility;
minimum qualifications for managed care organizations; and
criteria for enrolling recipients in managed care organizations.

subsection.text: “Procurement officer” means an individual authorized by a unit to:

paragraph.text: enter into a procurement contract;
administer a procurement contract; or
make determinations and findings with respect to a procurement contract.

subsection.text: “Proposal” means a response to any solicitation other than an invitation for bids.
“Request for proposals” means any document used for soliciting proposals.
“Responsible bidder or offeror” means a person who:

paragraph.text: has the capability in all respects to perform fully the requirements for a procurement contract; and
possesses the integrity and reliability that will ensure good faith performance.

subsection.text: “Responsive bid” means a bid that:

paragraph.text: is submitted under § 13-103 of this article; and
conforms in all material respects to the invitation for bids.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, “services” means:

subparagraph.text: the labor, time, or effort of a contractor; and
any product or report necessarily associated with the rendering of a service.

paragraph.text: “Services” includes services provided by attorneys, accountants, physicians, consultants, and other professionals who are independent contractors.
“Services” does not include:

subparagraph.text: construction related services;
architectural services;
engineering services; or
energy performance contract services.

subsection.text: “State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

“State correctional facilities” means correctional institutions, and all places of correctional confinement, that are located within the State of Maryland and are primarily operated by the Maryland State government.
“State correctional facilities” includes Patuxent Institution.
“Supplies” means:

subparagraph.text: insurance;
tangible personal property;
printing; and
services necessarily associated with insurance or tangible personal property.

paragraph.text: “Supplies” does not include:

subparagraph.text: an interest in real property; or
tangible personal property acquired or used in connection with an energy performance contract.

paragraph.text: “Unit” means an officer or other entity that is in the Executive Branch of the State government and is authorized by law to enter into a procurement contract.
“Unit” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a bistate, multistate, bicounty, or multicounty governmental agency; or
a special tax district, sanitary district, drainage district, soil conservation district, water supply district, or other political subdivision of the State.

subsection.text: The purposes and policies of this Division II include:

paragraph.text: providing for increased confidence in State procurement;
ensuring fair and equitable treatment of all persons who deal with the State procurement system;
providing safeguards for maintaining a State procurement system of quality and integrity;
fostering effective broad–based competition in the State through support of the free enterprise system;
promoting increased long–term economic efficiency and responsibility in the State by encouraging the use of recycled materials;
providing increased economy in the State procurement system;
getting the maximum benefit from the purchasing power of the State;
simplifying, clarifying, and modernizing the law that governs State procurement;
allowing the continued development of procurement regulations, policies, and practices in the State; and
promoting development of uniform State procurement procedures to the extent possible.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise indicated, this Division II shall be construed liberally and applied to promote the purposes and policies enumerated in subsection (a) of this section.

If a provision of this Division II is inconsistent with a federal law, regulation, or grant agreement or other federal requirement that governs procurement or a procurement contract or with the terms of a gift, as defined in Article 1, § 22 of the Code, the federal requirement or the terms of the gift control the procurement or procurement contract.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “bundle” means the consolidation of two or more procurement requirements for supplies or services previously provided or performed under separate contracts into a single solicitation seeking offers for a single contract that is unlikely to be accessible for award to a small business or minority business enterprise.
This subsection does not apply if a unit bundles a procurement for the purpose of participating in the Small Business Reserve Program in accordance with Title 14, Subtitle 5 of this article.

For the purpose of precluding or limiting participation by a minority business enterprise as defined under Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article or a small business as defined under Title 14, Subtitle 2 of this article, a unit subject to this Division II may not:

subparagraph.text: bundle a procurement;
limit the number of competitive bidders or offerors; or
limit participation to a predetermined group of bidders or offerors.

section.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided by law, this Division II applies to:

paragraph.text: each expenditure by a unit under a procurement contract;
each procurement by a unit on behalf of another unit, governmental agency, or other entity; and

each procurement by a unit, even if a resulting procurement contract will involve no expenditure by the State and will produce revenue for the State, for services that are to be provided for the benefit of:

subparagraph.text: State officials, State employees, or students at a State facility, including a school, hospital, institution, or recreational facility;
clients or patients at a State hospital or State institution;
the public at a State recreational facility; or
the public at a State transportation facility or State higher education facility, as required by the Board.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, this Division II does not apply to:

paragraph.text: procurement by:

subparagraph.text: the Blind Industries and Services of Maryland;
the Maryland State Arts Council, for the support of the arts;
the Maryland Health and Higher Educational Facilities Authority, if no State money is to be spent on a procurement contract;

the Maryland Industrial Training Program or the Partnership for Workforce Quality Program in the Department of Business and Economic Development, for training services or programs for new or expanding businesses or industries or businesses or industries in transition;
the Maryland Food Center Authority, to the extent the Authority is exempt under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the Economic Development Article;
the Maryland Public Broadcasting Commission:

sub-subparagraph.text: for services of artists for educational and cultural television productions; or
when planning for or fulfilling the obligations of grants or cooperative agreements that support the educational and cultural activities of the Commission;

subparagraph.text: public institutions of higher education, for cultural, entertainment, and intercollegiate athletic procurement contracts;
the Maryland State Planning Council on Developmental Disabilities, for services to support demonstration, pilot, and training programs;
the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund;
the Maryland Historical Trust for:

sub-subparagraph.text: surveying and evaluating architecturally, archeologically, historically, or culturally significant properties; and
other than as to architectural services, preparing historic preservation planning documents and educational material;

subparagraph.text: the University of Maryland, for University College Overseas Programs, if the University adopts regulations that:

sub-subparagraph.text: establish policies and procedures governing procurement for University College Overseas Programs; and
promote the purposes stated in § 11–201(a) of this subtitle;

subparagraph.text: the Department of Business and Economic Development, for negotiating and entering into private sector cooperative marketing projects that directly enhance promotion of Maryland and the tourism industry where there will be a private sector contribution to the project of not less than 50% of the total cost of the project, if the project is reviewed by the Attorney General and approved by the Secretary of Business and Economic Development or the Secretary’s designee;
the Rural Maryland Council;

the Maryland State Lottery Agency, for negotiating and entering into private sector cooperative marketing projects that directly enhance promotion of the Maryland State Lottery and its products, if the cooperative marketing project:

sub-subparagraph.text: provides a substantive promotional or marketing value that the lottery determines acceptable in exchange for advertising or other promotional activities provided by the lottery;
does not involve the advertising or other promotion of alcohol or tobacco products; and
is reviewed by the Attorney General and approved by the Maryland Lottery Director or the Director’s designee;

subparagraph.text: the Maryland Health Insurance Plan established under Title 14, Subtitle 5 of the Insurance Article;

the Maryland Energy Administration, when negotiating or entering into grants or cooperative agreements with private entities to meet federal specifications or solicitation requirements related to energy conservation, energy efficiency, or renewable energy projects that benefit the State;

the Maryland Developmental Disabilities Administration of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene for family and individual support services, and individual family care services, as those terms are defined by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene in regulation;
the Department of General Services for the renovation of a structure that:

sub-subparagraph.text: was built during the 18th or 19th century; and
is listed in or eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places; and

subparagraph.text: the Department of Natural Resources, for negotiating or entering into grants, agreements, or partnerships with nonprofit entities related to conservation service opportunities;

paragraph.text: procurement by a unit from:

subparagraph.text: another unit;
a political subdivision of the State;
an agency of a political subdivision of the State;
a government, including the government of another state, of the United States, or of another country;
an agency or political subdivision of a government; or
a bistate, multistate, bicounty, or multicounty governmental agency; or

paragraph.text: procurement in support of enterprise activities for the purpose of:

subparagraph.text: direct resale; or
remanufacture and subsequent resale.

paragraph.text: The following provisions of this Division II apply to each procurement enumerated in subsection (a) of this section:

subparagraph.text: § 11–205 of this subtitle (“Collusion”);
§ 10–204 of this article (“Approval for designated contracts”);
Title 12, Subtitle 2 of this article (“Supervision of Capital Expenditures and Real Property Leases”);
§ 13–219 of this article (“Required clauses – Nondiscrimination clause”);
§ 13–221 of this article (“Disclosures to Secretary of State”);
Title 12, Subtitle 4 of this article (“Policies and Procedures for Exempt Units”);
Title 16 of this article (“Suspension and Debarment of Contractors”); and
Title 17 of this article (“Special Provisions – State and Local Subdivisions”).

paragraph.text: Except for procurement under subsection (a)(1)(i) and (xi) and (2)(i) and (vi) of this section, the provisions of Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article (“Minority Business Participation”) shall apply to each procurement enumerated in subsection (a) of this section.
A procurement by an entity listed in subsection (a)(1)(i) through (xiii) and (xvii) of this section shall be made under procedures that promote the purposes stated in § 11–201(a) of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: A unit that procures human, social, or educational services from an entity enumerated in subsection (a)(2) of this section shall publish in eMaryland Marketplace notice of a procurement contract or an extension or renewal of a procurement contract if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the procurement contract, extension, or renewal costs more than $25,000; and
the procurement is made for 3rd party clients described in § 13–106 of this article.

subparagraph.text: The notice required under this paragraph shall be published not more than 30 days after the execution and approval of the procurement contract or the extension or renewal of the procurement contract.

paragraph.text: The purchase of advisory services from the General Selection Board or the Transportation Selection Board under § 13–305 of this article shall be governed by the Maryland Architectural and Engineering Services Act.

subsection.text: Except as provided in Title 12, Subtitle 4 and Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article, this Division II does not apply to the Maryland Stadium Authority.
Except as provided in Title 12, Subtitle 4 and Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article, this Division II does not apply to the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System for:

paragraph.text: services of managers to invest the assets of the State Retirement and Pension System, including real and personal property;
expenditures to manage, maintain, and enhance the value of the assets of the State Retirement and Pension System in accordance with investment guidelines adopted by the Board of Trustees;
services related to the administration of the optional retirement program under Title 30 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; and
services related to the administration of the Postretirement Health Benefits Trust Fund.
In this subsection, “University” means the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, or St. Mary’s College of Maryland.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, this Division II does not apply to the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, or St. Mary’s College of Maryland.

subparagraph.text: A procurement by a University shall comply with the policies and procedures developed by the University and approved by the Board of Public Works and the Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review Committee of the General Assembly in accordance with § 12–112 of the Education Article for the University System of Maryland, § 14–109 of the Education Article for Morgan State University, or § 14–405(f) of the Education Article for St. Mary’s College of Maryland.

sub-subparagraph.text: The review and approval of the Board of Public Works shall be required for the following types of contracts with a value that exceeds $1,000,000:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: capital improvements;
services; and
dispositions of personal property subject to § 10–305 of this article, except for dispositions of personal property that was purchased with the proceeds of a general obligation loan.

sub-subparagraph.text: In its review of a contract for services or capital improvements with a value that exceeds $1,000,000, the Board of Public Works may request the comments of the appropriate agencies, including the Department of Budget and Management and the Department of General Services.

paragraph.text: A University’s policies shall:

subparagraph.text: to the maximum extent practicable, require the purchasing of supplies and services in accordance with Title 14, Subtitle 1 of this article; and
promote the purposes of the regulations adopted by the Department of General Services governing the procurement of architectural and engineering services.
Except as provided in paragraph (7) of this subsection, the following provisions of Division II of this article apply to a University:

sub-subparagraph.text: § 11–205 of this subtitle (“Collusion”);
§ 11–205.1 of this subtitle (“Falsification, concealment, etc., of material facts”);
§ 13–219 of this article (“Required clauses – Nondiscrimination clause”);
§ 13–225 of this article (“Retainage”);
Title 14, Subtitle 3 of this article (“Minority Business Participation”);
Title 15, Subtitle 1 of this article (“Procurement Contract Administration”);

sub-subparagraph.text: for services of artists for educational and cultural television productions; or

the Rural Maryland Council;

the Maryland Developmental Disabilities Administration of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene for family and individual support services, and individual family care services, as those terms are defined by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene in regulation;

sub-subparagraph.text: was built during the 18th or 19th century; and

subparagraph.text: A unit that procures human, social, or educational services from an entity enumerated in subsection (a)(2) of this section shall publish in eMaryland Marketplace notice of a procurement contract or an extension or renewal of a procurement contract if:

subparagraph.text: The notice required under this paragraph shall be published not more than 30 days after the execution and approval of the procurement contract or the extension or renewal of the procurement contract.

sub-subparagraph.text: The review and approval of the Board of Public Works shall be required for the following types of contracts with a value that exceeds $1,000,000:

services; and

sub-subparagraph.text: In its review of a contract for services or capital improvements with a value that exceeds $1,000,000, the Board of Public Works may request the comments of the appropriate agencies, including the Department of Budget and Management and the Department of General Services.

subsection.text: This Division II does not apply to a contract or grant awarded by a unit of State government to the Chesapeake Bay Trust for a project involving the restoration or protection of the Chesapeake Bay and other aquatic and land resources of the State.
A unit may not enter into a procurement contract except as allowed under this Division II.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this Division II, if a procurement violates this Division II, the procurement contract is void.

Whenever a procurement contract is void under this subsection, the contractor shall be awarded compensation for actual expenses reasonably incurred under the procurement contract, plus a reasonable profit, if the contractor:

subparagraph.text: acted in good faith;
did not directly contribute to a violation of this Division II; and
had no knowledge of the violation before the procurement contract was awarded.

paragraph.text: Whenever a procurement violates this Division II, the Board may determine that the procurement contract is voidable, rather than void, if the Board determines that:

subparagraph.text: all parties acted in good faith;
ratification of the procurement contract would not undermine the purposes of this Division II; and
the violation or series of violations was insignificant or otherwise did not prevent substantial compliance with this Division II.

paragraph.text: Whenever a procurement contract is voidable under this subsection and the contractor has not acted in violation of this Division II, the unit may:

subparagraph.text: ratify the procurement contract if the unit determines that ratification is in the best interests of the State; or
void the procurement contract and award the contractor compensation for actual expenses reasonably incurred under the contract, plus a reasonable profit.

paragraph.text: Whenever a procurement contract is voidable under this subsection and the contractor has acted in violation of this Division II, the unit:

subparagraph.text: may void the procurement contract; or
without prejudice to the State’s right to appropriate damages, may ratify the procurement contract if the unit determines that ratification is in the best interests of the State.

subsection.text: This section is broadly applicable to all procurements by the State.

A person who, for the purpose of defrauding the State, acts in collusion with another person in connection with the procurement process is liable for damages equal to 3 times the value of the loss to the State that is attributable to the collusion.

paragraph.text: A procurement officer who has reason to believe that collusion has occurred in connection with the procurement process shall send to the Office of the Attorney General written notice that states the belief and its basis.
The Attorney General may begin an action in the appropriate court for damages under subsection (b) of this section.

If there is reason to believe that collusion has occurred in connection with the procurement process, all relevant documents shall be kept until the Attorney General gives notice that they may be destroyed.
On request by the Office of the Attorney General, relevant documents shall be made available immediately.

subsection.text: In connection with a procurement contract a person may not willfully:

paragraph.text: falsify, conceal, or suppress a material fact by any scheme or device;
make a false or fraudulent statement or representation of a material fact; or
use a false writing or document that contains a false or fraudulent statement or entry of a material fact.

subsection.text: A person may not aid or conspire with another person to commit an act under subsection (a) of this section.
A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $20,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.
Unless otherwise indicated in the regulation, a regulation adopted under this Division II applies to a procurement contract if:

paragraph.text: the regulation is in effect on the day that the parties execute the procurement contract; and
the procurement contract is governed by this Division II.

subsection.text: A regulation adopted under this Division II does not affect the rights of a unit or contractor under a procurement contract that was entered into before the effective date of the regulation.

A requirement of law that a procurement contract contain a particular provision is satisfied if the procurement contract includes notice of the provision, including the subject matter of the provision.

section.text: Each determination required under this Division II shall be:

paragraph.text: in writing;
based on written findings of the public official or employee who makes the determination; and
kept, for at least 3 years, in an official procurement contract file.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Employee” means any individual who performs services for, or under the control and direction of, an employer for wages or other remuneration.
“Employee” does not include an employee as defined in § 1-501(c)(1) of the Health Occupations Article.

“Employer” means a person engaged in a business, industry, profession, trade, or other enterprise that enters a procurement contract with a unit to provide supplies or services under this Division II.
“Employer” includes agents, contractors, and subcontractors of an employer.
“Employer” does not include a unit of State government subject to the provisions of Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article or the Judicial Branch of State government.

section.text: An employer subject to this subtitle shall provide employees with written notice of the protections and remedies provided by this subtitle.
An employer may not take or refuse to take any personnel action as a reprisal against an employee because the employee:

paragraph.text: discloses information that the employee reasonably believes evidences:

subparagraph.text: an abuse of authority, gross mismanagement, or gross waste of money;
a substantial and specific danger to public health or safety; or
a violation of law;

paragraph.text: objects to or refuses to participate in any activity, policy, or practice in violation of law; or
following a disclosure under item (1) of this section, seeks a remedy provided under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Any employee who is subject to a personnel action in violation of § 11-303 of this subtitle may institute a civil action in the county where:

paragraph.text: the alleged violation occurred;
the employee resides; or
the employer maintains its principal office in the State.

subsection.text: The action shall be brought within 1 year after the alleged violation of § 11-303 of this subtitle occurred or within 1 year after the employee first became aware of the alleged violation of § 11-303 of this subtitle.

section.text: In any action brought under this subtitle, a court may:

paragraph.text: issue an injunction to restrain continued violation of § 11-303 of this subtitle;
reinstate the employee to the same or an equivalent position held before the violation of § 11-303 of this subtitle;
remove any adverse personnel record entries based on or related to the violation of § 11-303 of this subtitle;
reinstate full fringe benefits and seniority rights;
require compensation for lost wages, benefits, and other remuneration;
award costs of litigation and reasonable attorney’s fees to the prevailing employee; and
award any other appropriate damages and relief.

section.text: In any action brought under this subtitle, it is a defense that the personnel action was based on grounds other than the employee’s exercise of any rights protected under this subtitle.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to capital expenditures by the Department of Transportation or the Maryland Transportation Authority, in connection with State roads, bridges, or highways, as provided in § 12-202 of this title.

paragraph.text: The Board may control procurement by units.
To implement the provisions of this Division II, the Board may:

subparagraph.text: set policy;
adopt regulations, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article; and
establish internal operational procedures consistent with this Division II.

paragraph.text: The Board shall ensure that the regulations of the primary procurement units provide for procedures that are consistent with this Division II and Title 13, Subtitle 4 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article and, to the extent the circumstances of a particular type of procurement or a particular unit do not require otherwise, are substantially the same.
The Board may delegate any of its authority that it determines to be appropriate for delegation and may require prior Board approval for specified procurement actions.

Except as limited by the Maryland Constitution, the Board may exercise any control authority conferred on a primary procurement unit by this Division II and, to the extent that its action conflicts with the action of the primary procurement unit, the action of the Board shall prevail.
The Board, with the assistance of the Department of Budget and Management, shall compile comprehensive statistics on the procurement system by agency, amount, and type of procurement.

The Board shall develop and submit to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, an annual report on the procurement system that includes information on actions necessary to improve effective broad–based competition in procurement.
The Board shall appoint a Procurement Advisor, who serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Procurement Advisor shall:

subparagraph.text: ensure that the State’s procurement system is utilizing the most advanced procurement methods and management techniques;

effect and enhance communication between State units on procurement matters, with an emphasis on disseminating information on current developments and advances in the management of the State procurement system;

examine all procurements that are subject to review by the Board and make recommendations to the Board as to the appropriateness of each procurement, with an emphasis on whether the proposed procurement:

sub-subparagraph.text: has been competitively conducted; and
conforms to provisions of procurement law, procurement regulations, and best management practices;

subparagraph.text: prevent and detect fraud, waste, and abuse and foster competition in the expenditure of State funds in the procurement of supplies, services, or construction;
conduct investigations into procurement policies, practices, and procedures, as appropriate;
investigate complaints made by State employees concerning fraud, waste, and abuse in the procurement process and any alleged violation of the procurement law or regulations;

investigate complaints, other than formal bid protests filed under Title 15, Subtitle 2 of this article, made by contractors and other interested parties concerning fraud, waste, and abuse in the procurement process and any alleged violation of the procurement law or regulations;

if apparent criminal violations are found in the course of an investigation, report findings to the Board of Public Works, Office of the Attorney General, United States Attorney, and State or local prosecutors, as appropriate;

if other apparent violations of law or regulation are found in the course of an investigation, report findings to the Board of Public Works, the appropriate agency head, and any other appropriate body for administrative action;

produce and submit to the Board of Public Works and the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, an annual report of the activities of the Procurement Advisor, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: all findings and recommendations for improvements to the procurement system; and
the identification of barriers to effective broad-based competition in State procurement and recommendations for the elimination of these barriers;

subparagraph.text: assist agencies and the public with questions regarding procurement policy;

establish policies for the effective training of State procurement officials to ensure that the State’s procurement system is utilizing the most advanced procurement methods and management techniques;
coordinate activities with other entities performing similar functions;
review internal audit reports and comment as appropriate;
be the principal staff to the Procurement Advisory Council; and
notify the Legislative Auditor when the Procurement Advisor undertakes an investigation under item (vi) or (vii) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: The Procurement Advisor shall:

subparagraph.text: have access to all books, accounts, records, reports, any material related to contracts and procurement, and all other papers and equipment necessary to carry out its responsibilities; and
have direct and prompt access to all heads of agencies involved in the expenditure of public funds.
The Board shall appoint a General Counsel, who serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The General Counsel shall be an attorney in this State.

paragraph.text: The General Counsel shall:

subparagraph.text: provide independent legal advice to the Board;

examine all procurements that are subject to review by the Board and make recommendations to the Board as to the legal sufficiency of the procurements, with an emphasis on whether the proposed procurement has been competitively conducted;
assist the Procurement Advisor in investigations undertaken by the Procurement Advisor;

assist the Procurement Advisor in responding to complaints made by State employees, contractors, and other interested parties concerning fraud, waste, and abuse in the procurement process or any alleged violation of the procurement law and regulations;

compile information for distribution to State procurement officials relating to recent decisions of the Maryland State Board of Contract Appeals and State and federal courts concerning procurement, including any policy or legal guidance to the procurement officials based on these decisions; and
review regulations proposed by the Board for legality and approve them for proposal and adoption.

paragraph.text: The General Counsel shall:

subparagraph.text: have access to all books, accounts, records, any material related to contracts and procurement, and all other papers and equipment necessary to carry out its responsibilities; and
have direct and prompt access to all heads of agencies involved in the expenditure of public funds.

subsection.text: In accordance with the State budget, the Board may appoint any additional staff necessary to carry out its responsibilities under this Division II.

This section does not apply to capital expenditures by the Department of Transportation or the Maryland Transportation Authority, in connection with State roads, bridges, or highways, as provided in § 12-202 of this title.
Notwithstanding any delegation of authority under § 12-101 of this subtitle, the Board retains full authority to engage in procurement of services and supplies for itself.

By resolution, the Board may authorize a Board member or a unit to exercise all or any part of the authority of the Board for a specific Board procurement or for a particular class of Board procurements.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Board may modify or waive any requirement under this Division II for a procurement contract or a class of procurement contracts that is to be performed entirely outside the United States, or any lease of real property outside this State, to the extent that:

paragraph.text: the purposes stated in § 11–201(a) of this article are fostered;
the circumstances require the modification or waiver; and
foreign or out–of–state contractors are expected to be involved in the procurement.

subsection.text: The Board may not modify or waive the following requirements:

paragraph.text: § 14–404 of this article (“Coal in heating systems”);
Title 16, Subtitle 2 of this article (“Offenses Subject to Debarment”); and
Title 17 of this article (“Special Provisions –– State and Local Subdivisions”).

subsection.text: In this section, “Council” means the Procurement Advisory Council.
There is a Procurement Advisory Council.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of the following ten members:

subparagraph.text: the State Treasurer;
the Chancellor of the University System of Maryland;
the Secretary of Budget and Management;
the Secretary of General Services;
the Secretary of Transportation;
the Secretary of the Board;
the Special Secretary for the Office of Minority Affairs;
a representative of local government who has expertise in local procurement matters, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate; and
two members of the general public, at least one of whom has expertise in State procurement matters, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
If the State Treasurer is unable to attend a meeting of the Procurement Advisory Council, the Treasurer may designate the Deputy Treasurer to attend the meeting.

If a member of the Council listed in paragraph (1) (ii) through (v) of this subsection is unable to attend a meeting of the Procurement Advisory Council, the member may designate the Chief Procurement Officer of the agency to attend the meeting.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Board is Chairman of the Council.
The Council shall meet at least quarterly each year.
The Procurement Advisor is the principal staff of the Council and the Council shall have any additional staff that the Board authorizes in accordance with the State budget.
The Council shall:

paragraph.text: ensure that the State’s procurement system is utilizing the most advanced procurement methods and management techniques;
effect and enhance communication between State units on procurement matters, with an emphasis on disseminating information on current developments and advances in procurement methods and management;
provide a forum for the discussion of specific procurement issues and problems that arise;
advise the Board on problems in the procurement process and make recommendations for improvement of the process; and
review existing procurement regulations to:

subparagraph.text: determine whether they fulfill the intent and purpose of the law, especially as it relates to fostering broad-based competition; and
make recommendations on the regulations, if revising and restructuring them will result in easier understanding and use.

section.text: The Board may establish other advisory bodies.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to capital expenditures by the Department of Transportation or the Maryland Transportation Authority, in connection with State roads, bridges, or highways, as provided in § 12-202 of this title.
Subject to the authority of the Board, jurisdiction over procurement is as follows:

paragraph.text: the State Treasurer may engage in or control procurement of banking and financial services, insurance, and insurance services, as provided in Division I of this article and Article VI, § 3 of the Maryland Constitution;
the Department of Budget and Management may control procurement of:

subparagraph.text: services by a unit, subject to any limitation in this Division II; and
leases of motor vehicles, as provided in Title 3, Subtitle 5 of this article;

paragraph.text: the Department of General Services may engage in or control procurement of:

subparagraph.text: leases of real property, including leases under Title 4, Subtitle 3 of this article;
supplies, including supplies under Title 4, Subtitle 3 of this article, but excluding insurance, information processing equipment, and motor vehicle leases;
construction, including construction under Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article;
construction related services, including those under Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article; and
architectural or engineering services under Title 13, Subtitle 3 of this article;

paragraph.text: the Department of Transportation and the Maryland Transportation Authority, without the approval of any of the other primary procurement units, may engage in the procurement of:

subparagraph.text: construction that is related to transportation, as provided in the Transportation Article;
construction related services that are related to transportation, as provided in the Transportation Article;
architectural or engineering services that are related to transportation, under Title 13, Subtitle 3 of this article;
rolling stock and other property peculiar to the operation of a transit system, as provided in § 7–403 of the Transportation Article;
supplies for aeronautics related activities, including motor vehicles and information processing supplies, but excluding:

sub-subparagraph.text: supplies funded by the proceeds from State general obligation bonds; and
insurance; and

subparagraph.text: services for aeronautics related activities, including information processing services, but excluding banking and financial services under the authority of the State Treasurer under item (1) of this subsection;

paragraph.text: the Maryland Port Commission, without the approval of any of the other primary procurement units, may engage in the procurement of:

subparagraph.text: supplies for port related activities, including motor vehicles and information processing supplies, but excluding:

sub-subparagraph.text: supplies funded by the proceeds from State general obligation bonds; and
insurance;

subparagraph.text: services for port related activities, including information processing services, but excluding banking and financial services under the authority of the State Treasurer under item (1) of this subsection;
construction and construction related services for a port facility as defined in § 6–101(e) of the Transportation Article;
port related architectural and engineering services under Title 13, Subtitle 3 of this article; and
leases of real property for port related activities unless the lease payments are from the General Fund of the State;

paragraph.text: the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services may, without the approval of any of the other primary procurement units:

subparagraph.text: engage in the procurement of construction and construction related services for State correctional facilities; and

engage in the procurement of supplies, materials, and equipment in support of construction and construction related services for State correctional facilities in accordance with this Division II and Title 2 and Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the Correctional Services Article; and

paragraph.text: the Department of Information Technology may control procurement of:

subparagraph.text: information processing equipment and associated services, as provided in Title 3A, Subtitle 3 of this article; and
telecommunication equipment, systems, or services, as provided in Title 3A, Subtitle 4 of this article.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to capital expenditures by the Department of Transportation or the Maryland Transportation Authority, in connection with State roads, bridges, or highways, as provided in § 12-202 of this title.
Subject to the approval of the Board and under the coordination of the Governor, each of the primary procurement units shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out this Division II;
send to the Board a copy of each proposed regulation under item (1) of this subsection; and
send to the Board a copy of each internal operating procedure that the primary procurement unit adopts.

section.text: If authorized by the principal executive or legislative authority of the local government in accordance with local ordinance, a local health department may use either the State procurement system or the procurement system of the county in which the health department is located.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Council” means the Council for the Procurement of Health, Educational, and Social Services.
“Health, educational, and social services” means services procured to provide or assist in providing:

subparagraph.text: support, care, or shelter to third–party clients under a contract; or
training to third–party clients under a contract.

paragraph.text: “Task Force Report” means the report entitled “Task Force Report to the Governor and the General Assembly on Procurement of Health, Education and Social Services by State Agencies” that was issued on November 30, 2011, by the Task Force to Study the Procurement of Health, Education, and Social Services by State Agencies.

subsection.text: There is a Council for the Procurement of Health, Educational, and Social Services.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of the following members:

subparagraph.text: the State Treasurer;
the Attorney General;
the Procurement Advisor;
the State Superintendent of Schools;
the Secretary of Budget and Management;
the Secretary of Juvenile Services;
the Secretary of Human Resources;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Director of the Governor’s Grants Office;
the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office of Crime Control and Prevention;
the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office for Children;
the Special Secretary for the Office of Minority Affairs;
four representatives of private organizations with experience providing human services funded by contracts through State units, appointed by the Governor;
a member of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
a member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.
If the State Treasurer is unable to attend a meeting of the Council, the Treasurer may designate a Deputy Treasurer to attend the meeting.

If a member of the Council listed in paragraph (1)(ii) through (xii) of this subsection is unable to attend a meeting of the Council, the member may designate the Chief Procurement Officer or another senior management staff member of the agency or organization to attend the meeting.

subsection.text: The Procurement Advisor is the Chair of the Council.
The Council shall meet at least twice each year.
The staffing responsibilities of the Council shall be shared by:

paragraph.text: the agencies represented on the Council; and
additional staff that the Board authorizes in accordance with the State budget.

subsection.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Board on specific steps necessary to implement the recommendations of the Task Force Report;
monitor and report to the Board the progress of implementation of the recommendations in the Task Force Report;
establish subcommittees or working committees consisting of members of the Council and interested parties to address or study specific issues;
with regard to the procurement of health, educational, and social services:

subparagraph.text: effect and enhance communication between State units on procurement matters, with an emphasis on disseminating information on current developments and advances in procurement methods and management;
provide a forum for the discussion of specific procurement issues and problems that arise;
advise the Board on problems in the procurement process and make recommendations for improvement to the procurement process; and

review existing procurement regulations to determine whether they fulfill the intent and purpose of the law, especially as the law relates to fostering broad–based competition and making effective use of State funds for the delivery of health, educational, and social services; and

paragraph.text: on or before December 31 of each year, report to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, on the Council’s activities and recommendations regarding the procurement of health, educational, and social services by State agencies.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Public employer” means:

subparagraph.text: a unit;
a county;
a municipality;
a county board of education; or
a special taxing district.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, “services” has the meaning stated in § 11–101(t) of this article.
“Services” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: construction–related services;
architectural services;
engineering services; or
energy performance contract services.

subsection.text: This section applies to a procurement contract with an estimated value of $2,000,000 or more.
In response to a solicitation for a procurement contract issued by a public employer, a bidder shall disclose to the public employer the following:

paragraph.text: whether the bidder or any contractor that the bidder will subcontract with to perform the contract has plans, at the time the bid is submitted, to perform any services required under the contract outside the United States; and
if services required under the contract are anticipated to be performed outside the United States:

subparagraph.text: where the services will be performed; and
the reasons why it is necessary or advantageous to perform the services outside the United States.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a public employer may not knowingly contract for the following services unless the services are to be provided in the United States:

subparagraph.text: architectural services;
construction services;
engineering services; or
energy performance contract services.

paragraph.text: A public employer may contract for services listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection that are provided outside the United States, if:

subparagraph.text: the services are not available in the United States;
the price of the services in the United States exceeds by an unreasonable amount the price of services provided outside the United States; or
the quality of the services in the United States is substantially less than the quality of comparably priced services provided outside the United States.

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt regulations defining the following terms for the purposes of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: “unreasonable amount”; and
“substantially less”.

section.text: This subtitle is broadly applicable to all procurements by the State.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to capital expenditures by the Department of Transportation or the Maryland Transportation Authority, in connection with State roads, bridges, or highways.

Before execution, a contract for a capital expenditure other than in connection with a State correctional facility, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, Morgan State University, or the University System of Maryland shall be:

paragraph.text: reviewed by the Secretary of General Services; and
except as provided in § 12-203 of this subtitle and § 13-108 of this article, after that review, approved by the Board.

subsection.text: Before execution, a contract for a capital expenditure in connection with a State correctional facility shall be:

paragraph.text: reviewed by the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services; and
except as provided in § 12-203 of this subtitle, after that review, approved by the Board.

subsection.text: Before execution, a contract for a capital expenditure in connection with the University System of Maryland shall be:

paragraph.text: subject to the provisions of Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article;
approved by the Board of Regents of the University System of Maryland; and
approved by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: Before execution, a contract for a capital expenditure in connection with St. Mary’s College of Maryland shall be:

paragraph.text: subject to the provisions of Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article;
approved by the Board of Trustees of St. Mary’s College of Maryland; and
approved by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: Before execution, a contract for a capital expenditure in connection with Morgan State University shall be:

paragraph.text: subject to the provisions of Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article;
approved by the Board of Regents of Morgan State University; and
approved by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: The Board shall supervise the expenditure of any money that the General Assembly appropriates for:

paragraph.text: buildings;
equipment;
new construction; or
any other capital expenditure.
The Board may adopt regulations that allow a unit of the State government to enter into a contract or make a change order related to a capital project without approval.
These regulations shall:

subparagraph.text: comply with this section; and
be subject to the approval of the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.

paragraph.text: Regulations adopted under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: establish an expenditure or use classification to determine which contracts or change orders may be made without Board approval;

set an amount for each classification and require a unit of the State government to obtain approval of the Board if the annual dollar value of a contract and its change orders exceeds that amount; and
require a unit of the State government to establish a reporting system approved by the Board to inform the Board about contracts or change orders entered into without Board approval.

paragraph.text: The amount established by the Board under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection shall be an amount that:

subparagraph.text: frees the Board from direct review of relatively insignificant items; but
does not impair the strong public policy favoring direct review by the Board for items that have a substantial fiscal impact.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a lease entered into on or before May 31, 1967, unless the lease is renewed after that date.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section and § 13–108 of this article, before a unit executes or renews a lease of land, buildings, or office space, the Board shall approve the lease or lease renewal.
After review by the Secretary of General Services, the Board may designate the location of any unit.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board may adopt regulations, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, that allow a unit to execute or renew a lease without Board approval.
These regulations are subject to the approval of:

subparagraph.text: the General Assembly; or
while the General Assembly is not in session, the Legislative Policy Committee.

paragraph.text: Regulations adopted under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: establish an expenditure or use classification to determine which leases or lease renewals may be entered into without Board approval;
set an amount for each classification and require a unit to obtain approval if a lease or lease renewal exceeds that amount; and
require a unit to establish a reporting system approved by the Board to inform the Board about leases or lease renewals entered into without Board approval.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board may not approve a lease that:

subparagraph.text: transfers ownership of the property to the lessee on or before the termination of the lease;
allows the lessee to purchase the property below fair market value or for a fixed amount;
is for a term that is 75% or more of the estimated useful economic life of the property; or
has payments with a present value that is 90% or more of the fair market value of the property.

paragraph.text: The Board may approve a lease described in paragraph (1) of this subsection if:

subparagraph.text: the Capital Debt Affordability Committee has certified to the Governor and the General Assembly that the total amount of new State debt to be incurred by the lease may prudently be authorized; or
the General Assembly has approved the lease in the budget for the requesting unit.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a lease entered into on or before May 31, 1967, unless the lease is renewed after that date.

An appropriation may not be obligated or spent for the lease of a building or part of a building to be occupied by the State or a unit of the State government for a State purpose at an annual rent that exceeds 15% of the fair market value of the leased premises on the date of the lease.

paragraph.text: Before issuing a request for proposals for an energy performance contract, a primary procurement unit shall consult with the Maryland Energy Administration.

The Maryland Energy Administration shall review the proposed request to ensure that it meets with the State energy standards, preserves the State’s flexibility to investigate and use economically justifiable new technologies, and is in conformance with the unit’s energy conservation plan that has been developed in accordance with § 4–806 of this article.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law and subject to the approval and control of the Board of Public Works, a primary procurement unit of State government is authorized to enter into energy performance contracts of up to 15 years duration.
The Treasurer may enter into a capital lease to finance energy performance contracts as provided in Title 8, Subtitle 4 of this article.

The payments and the total contract amount due under an energy performance contract or, in the case of a capital lease used to finance energy performance contracts, the capital lease payments may not exceed the actual energy savings realized as a result of the contract’s performance.

subparagraph.text: Before approval of an energy performance contract, the Board:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall ensure that the projected annual energy savings attributable to the project will exceed the projected annual capital lease payments or payments to the contractor under the contract; and
based on the review of the Maryland Energy Administration, shall determine whether the proposed energy technology is appropriate for the time period provided in the contract.

subparagraph.text: The Board may:

sub-subparagraph.text: authorize the use of incentive contracts, including contracts that guarantee energy savings performance; and
require prospective contractors to furnish appropriate guarantees to ensure that projected savings are realized.

subparagraph.text: Any guarantees required under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph may include a requirement that the contractor furnish a bond or other assurance to the State in an appropriate amount to guarantee projected performance and that the bond or other assurance be structured so that a failure to meet guaranteed performance savings will forfeit a portion of the bond or other assurance to match the shortfall in energy savings.

section.text: The Maryland Energy Administration shall be responsible for monitoring the status of active energy performance contracts and reporting that status to the Board annually.

The Board may modify or waive any authorization, source selection, solicitation, or contract requirement under this Division II for an energy performance contract or a class of energy performance contracts to the extent that:

paragraph.text: the purposes stated in § 11-201(a) of this article are fostered; and
the circumstances of energy performance contracting require the modification or waiver.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each unit with an exemption from any provision of Division II of this article shall have written policies and procedures for the exempted unit’s procurements.
This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: § 11–203(a)(1)(iii) of this article;
§ 11–203(a)(2) of this article;
§ 11–203(e) of this article; or
§ 11–203(g) of this article.

subsection.text: Written policies and procedures shall include:

paragraph.text: the types of procurement exempted from Division II of this article;
the methods of procurement to be used for procurements provided under item (1) of this subsection;
the advertising requirements for each type of procurement provided under item (1) of this subsection;
procurement goals, including minority business enterprise participation, for each type of procurement provided under item (1) of this subsection; and
the approval process for each type of procurement provided under item (1) of this subsection.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, at the beginning of each fiscal year, each unit shall submit written policies and procedures to the Board for review as required by subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

Units that are governed by their own board, commission, council, or authority shall submit their policies and procedures as required by subsections (a) and (b) of this section to their board, commission, council, or authority for approval.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Direct involvement in the deportation of victims” means ownership or operation of the trains on which individuals were transported to extermination camps, death camps, or any facility used to transition individuals to extermination camps or death camps, during the period beginning on September 1, 1939, and ending on September 2, 1945.
“Entity” means:

paragraph.text: a corporation, affiliate, or other similar organization or a successor in interest of the corporation, affiliate, or similar organization that controls, or is controlled or owned or partially owned by or under common control with, a corporation that had direct involvement in the deportation of victims; or
a member of a partnership or a consortium that includes an entity that certifies that it had direct involvement in the deportation of victims.

subsection.text: “MARC” means the Maryland Area Regional Commuter.

paragraph.text: “Property” means any personal belongings owned or controlled by victims.
“Property” includes:

subparagraph.text: jewelry;
books;
artifacts;
precious metals; and
currency.

subsection.text: “Process of assembling the records” means to:

paragraph.text: organize, digitize, and make records available to the public in an Internet accessible, electronic format that is searchable and analyzable; and
prepare to submit the information described in § 12–507 of this subtitle to the State Archivist.
“Records” means material relating to the deportation of victims.
“Records” includes:

subparagraph.text: documents;
correspondence;
memoranda;
receipts;
invoices;
presentations;
audits; and
any other materials related to items (i) through (vii) of this paragraph.

subsection.text: “Victim” means an individual who was on an entity’s train for the purpose of being transported to an extermination camp, death camp, or a facility used to transition individuals to extermination camps or death camps during the period beginning on September 1, 1939 and ending on September 2, 1945.

section.text: For the purposes of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: two or more entities shall be considered as the same entity if:

subparagraph.text: one entity is a wholly owned subsidiary of the other; or

one entity owns or directly or indirectly controls more than 50% of the voting securities of the other entity, regardless of whether the equity interest in that other entity is owned by a foreign government; and

paragraph.text: if an equity interest in an entity is or was owned by a foreign government, that equity interest shall be attributed to the entity.

section.text: This subtitle applies to an entity that:

paragraph.text: had direct involvement in the deportation of victims; and
submits a bid or offer to a unit of State or local government on a procurement contract to provide MARC service that is funded in whole or in part with public funds.

section.text: An entity may not be considered a responsible bidder or offeror for a procurement contract to provide MARC service unless the entity complies with the requirements of §§ 12–505 through 12–507 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In conjunction with the submission of a bid or offer on a procurement contract to a unit of State or local government to provide MARC service, an entity shall submit to the unit:

paragraph.text: a statement that the entity had direct involvement in the deportation of victims; and
an estimated date for completing the process of assembling the records and providing information to the State Archivist in accordance with §§ 12–506 and 12–507 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The entity shall notify the unit of any change in the estimated date that was submitted to the unit in accordance with subsection (a) of this section.

Before a unit of State or local government may award a procurement contract to provide MARC service to an entity subject to this subtitle, the entity shall comply with the provisions of this section for the process of assembling the records related to the deportation of victims.

paragraph.text: An entity shall contract with an archivist and a historian to conduct an initial analysis of the records.
The archivist and historian that conduct the initial analysis shall:

subparagraph.text: be approved by the State Archivist;
be independent of the entity; and
conduct the analysis in accordance with the standards of the Society of American Archivists and the Council of State Archivists.

paragraph.text: The initial analysis shall include:

subparagraph.text: an inspection of each location in which the entity maintains records that may be related to the deportation of victims; and
a report submitted to the State Archivist.

paragraph.text: The initial report submitted to the State Archivist shall include:

subparagraph.text: a list of each location inspected and an assessment of whether the location maintains any records;
an outline and assessment of the quality of the records;
a timeline for the process to assemble the records; and
an estimated cost to assemble the records.

paragraph.text: After the initial analysis is concluded and the State Archivist has approved the initial report in accordance with § 12–508(a)(2)(i) of this subtitle, the entity shall contract with an archivist and a historian to ensure that the process of assembling the records is completed in a manner consistent with:

subparagraph.text: the initial report; and
the standards of the Society of American Archivists and the Council of State Archivists.

paragraph.text: The archivist and historian contracted with to carry out paragraph (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall be approved by the State Archivist; and
may be the archivist and historian that conducted the initial analysis or another archivist and historian approved by the State Archivist.

subsection.text: After the process of assembling the records is complete, the entity shall provide the information required under § 12–507 of this subtitle to the State Archivist.

section.text: Before a unit of State or local government may award a procurement contract to provide MARC service to an entity subject to this subtitle, the entity shall provide the State Archivist with the following information as it relates to the deportation of victims:

paragraph.text: a written statement providing:

subparagraph.text: whether the entity possesses, has custody of, or controls records relating to the the deportation of victims;
each location where the records are maintained; and
the contents and addresses of each archive or other facility where the entity maintains records;

paragraph.text: a detailed index of the records, including:

subparagraph.text: the location of the records and a list of any money received for each deportation, delineated by individual convoys and persons; and
an accounting of each piece of property taken or confiscated from each victim;

paragraph.text: if the entity no longer has in its custody or control any or all of the property taken or confiscated from each victim, a written description of:

subparagraph.text: the time and manner in which the entity disposed of or converted the property;
any property currently owned or operated by the entity that was exchanged for the expropriated property;
any expropriated property currently owned by the entity or any other property derived from the expropriated property; and
any other derivative or traceable property that remains in the entity’s possession, custody, or control as a result of its deportations activity; and

paragraph.text: a written statement concerning whether the entity has provided restitution or reparations to all identifiable victims of the deportations and, if so stated, a detailed description on how the restitution or reparations apply specifically to the deportation of each victim.

subsection.text: The State Archivist shall:

paragraph.text: approve an archivist and historian to conduct the initial analysis required under § 12–506(b) of this subtitle;
within 14 days after receiving the initial report submitted in accordance with § 12–506(b) of this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: review the report and determine whether, in the professional opinion of the State Archivist, the report is consistent with the standards of the Society of American Archivists and the Council of State Archivists; and
approve an archivist and historian that will ensure that the process of assembling the records is completed in a manner consistent with:

sub-subparagraph.text: the initial report; and
the standards of the Society of American Archivists and the Council of State Archivists;

paragraph.text: as needed, provide guidance for and oversight of the process of assembling the records;
after receiving from an entity the information required under § 12–507 of this subtitle, determine whether, in the professional opinion of the State Archivist:

subparagraph.text: the process of assembling the records is complete;
the process of assembling the records was completed in a manner consistent with:

sub-subparagraph.text: the initial report submitted in accordance with § 12–506(b) of this subtitle; and
the standards of the Society of American Archivists and the Council of State Archivists; and

subparagraph.text: the information submitted under § 12–507 of this subtitle is as complete and accurate as possible; and

paragraph.text: provide written notice of the determination made under item (4) of this subsection to:

subparagraph.text: the entity; and

if the State Archivist determines that the entity met the requirements set forth in item (4)(i), (ii), and (iii) of this subsection, to the unit of State or local government awarding the procurement contract to provide MARC service.

subsection.text: The State Archivist may use a designee to carry out any provision of this section.

At least 30 days before awarding a procurement contract on which an entity subject to this subtitle submitted a bid or offer, a unit of State or local government shall publish notice of its intent to award the procurement contract.
A unit of State or local government may not award a procurement contract to provide MARC service to an entity that does not comply with §§ 12–505 through 12–507 of this subtitle.

A unit of State or local government may award a procurement contract to provide MARC service to an entity only after the unit receives the notice from the State Archivist in accordance with § 12–508(a)(5) of this subtitle.

Notwithstanding the requirements of this subtitle, a unit of State or local government may award a procurement contract to provide MARC service to a bidder or offeror that is not an entity subject to the requirements of this subtitle.

section.text: An entity awarded a procurement contract to provide MARC service in accordance with § 12–509(c) of this subtitle is considered to have satisfied the requirements of §§ 12–505 through 12–507 of this subtitle for all future procurement contracts to provide MARC service.
The entity or any other bidder or offeror for a procurement contract to provide MARC service may not submit a protest under § 15–217 of this article relating to the requirements of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“eMaryland Marketplace” means the Internet-based procurement system managed by the Department of General Services.
“Evaluated bid price” means the price of a bid after adjustment in accordance with objective measurable criteria.

paragraph.text: “Objective measurable criteria” means standards that enable the State to compare the economy, effectiveness, or value of the subject of the bids.
“Objective measurable criteria” includes standards of reliability, operational costs, maintainability, useful life, and residual value.

subsection.text: Except as provided in Subtitle 3 and Subtitle 4 of this title, all procurement by units shall be by competitive sealed bids unless one of the following methods specifically is authorized:

paragraph.text: competitive sealed proposals under § 13–104 or § 13–105 of this subtitle;
noncompetitive negotiation under § 13–106 of this subtitle;
sole source procurement under § 13–107 of this subtitle;
emergency or expedited procurement under § 13–108 of this subtitle;
small procurement under § 13–109 of this subtitle;
an intergovernmental cooperative purchasing agreement under § 13–110 of this subtitle;
auction bids under § 13–111 of this subtitle; or
an unsolicited proposal under § 13–107.1 of this subtitle.
In awarding a procurement contract for human, social, cultural, or educational service, the preferred method is by competitive sealed proposals under § 13–104 of this subtitle.
In awarding a procurement contract for a lease of real property, the preferred method is by competitive sealed proposals under § 13–105 of this subtitle.

Procurement under an intergovernmental cooperative purchasing agreement is appropriate in situations where the State is expected to achieve a better price as the result of economies of scale or to otherwise benefit by purchasing in cooperation with another governmental entity.

subsection.text: Except as provided in Subtitle 3 and Subtitle 4 of this title, all procurement by units shall be by competitive sealed bids unless one of the following methods specifically is authorized:

paragraph.text: competitive sealed proposals under § 13–104 or § 13–105 of this subtitle;
noncompetitive negotiation under § 13–106 of this subtitle;
sole source procurement under § 13–107 of this subtitle;
emergency or expedited procurement under § 13–108 of this subtitle;
small procurement under § 13–109 of this subtitle;
an intergovernmental cooperative purchasing agreement under § 13–110 of this subtitle; or
auction bids under § 13–111 of this subtitle.
In awarding a procurement contract for human, social, cultural, or educational service, the preferred method is by competitive sealed proposals under § 13–104 of this subtitle.
In awarding a procurement contract for a lease of real property, the preferred method is by competitive sealed proposals under § 13–105 of this subtitle.

Procurement under an intergovernmental cooperative purchasing agreement is appropriate in situations where the State is expected to achieve a better price as the result of economies of scale or to otherwise benefit by purchasing in cooperation with another governmental entity.

subsection.text: A unit may not charge a fee to access eMaryland Marketplace.

paragraph.text: The Department of Budget and Management may establish fees for the use of eMaryland Marketplace by an entity that publishes a notice of a procurement, conducts a procurement, or publishes a notice of award.
The Department of Budget and Management may not charge a unit, as defined in § 11–101(x) of this article, a fee under this subsection.
Whenever procurement is based on competitive sealed bids, a procurement officer shall seek bids by issuing an invitation for bids.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, an invitation for bids shall include:

subparagraph.text: the specifications of the procurement contract, including the expected degree of minority business enterprise participation, as provided in § 14–303(b) of this article;

whether the procurement contract will be awarded based on the lowest bid price, the lowest evaluated bid price or, if the procurement is subject to § 11–202(3) of this article, the bid most favorable to the State;
if the procurement contract will be based on evaluated bid price, the objective measurable criteria by which the lowest evaluated bid price will be determined; and
if the Secretary of General Services, the Secretary of Transportation, or the Chancellor of the University System of Maryland has so designated, the small business preference.

paragraph.text: Whenever a procurement officer determines that an initial preparation of specifications for price bids is impracticable, the invitation for bids may:

subparagraph.text: include a request for unpriced technical offers or samples; and
direct bidders to submit price bids:

sub-subparagraph.text: with the unpriced technical offers or samples; or
after the unit evaluates the technical offers or samples and finds that they are acceptable under the criteria set forth in the invitation for bids.

paragraph.text: A unit shall consider the prices submitted by bidders whose technical offers or samples have been found acceptable.
Price bids may not be opened until after the unit has completed evaluation of the technical offers or samples.

subparagraph.text: A price bid may not be opened at any time if the bid is submitted by a bidder whose technical offer or sample has been evaluated as unacceptable to the unit.
A procurement officer shall return an unopened price bid submitted by a bidder whose technical offer or sample has been evaluated as unacceptable.

paragraph.text: A unit shall give public notice of an invitation for bids before bid opening in accordance with this subsection.
A unit shall give reasonable notice that shall be at least 10 days before bid opening.
Until July 1, 2006, the unit shall publish notice in the Contract Weekly, Contract Weekly Online, and eMaryland Marketplace at least 20 days before bid opening if:

subparagraph.text: the procurement officer reasonably expects bid prices to exceed $25,000 or a lower amount set by the Board by regulation in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article; and
at least part of the procurement contract is to be performed in this State or the District of Columbia.

paragraph.text: On and after July 1, 2006, the unit shall publish the notice required under paragraph (3) of this subsection in eMaryland Marketplace.
In addition to any notice required under this subsection, a unit may publish notice of an invitation for bids:

subparagraph.text: on a bid board or eMaryland Marketplace; or
in a newspaper, periodical, or trade journal.

paragraph.text: A procurement officer shall:

subparagraph.text: open bids in public at the time and place designated in the invitation for bids; and
announce, record, and post:

sub-subparagraph.text: the name of each bidder; and
the amount of each bid.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a bid is irrevocable, after bid opening, for the period specified in the invitation for bids.
A procurement officer may allow a bidder to correct or withdraw a bid if correction or withdrawal is:

subparagraph.text: allowed under regulations adopted under this Division II; and
approved in writing by the Office of the Attorney General.

paragraph.text: After obtaining any approval required by law, the procurement officer shall award the procurement contract to the responsible bidder who submits the responsive bid that:

subparagraph.text: is the lowest bid price;
if the invitation for bids so provides, is the lowest evaluated bid price; or
for procurement subject to § 11–202(3) of this article, is the bid most favorable to the State.

paragraph.text: If, after competitive sealed bids have been opened, a procurement officer determines that only 1 responsible bidder has submitted a responsive bid, the unit may negotiate the procurement contract with that 1 bidder under the procedure for sole source procurement.

subparagraph.text: After competitive sealed bids have been opened, a procurement officer may award a procurement contract on the basis of revised bids if:

sub-subparagraph.text: all bids are rejected under § 13–206(b) of this title;
all bid prices exceed the funds available for the procurement; or

with the approval of the head of the unit or a designee, the procurement officer determines that all bids are unreasonable as to at least 1 requirement and the delay that would result from issuing a new invitation for bids with revised specifications or quantities would be fiscally disadvantageous or otherwise not in the best interests of the State.
