paragraph.text: If the Attorney General reasonably believes that a person may have information or may be in possession, custody, or control of any original or copy of any book, record, report, memorandum, paper communication, tabulation, map, chart, photograph, mechanical transcription, or other tangible document or recording, wherever situated, which the Attorney General believes is relevant to, or may lead to the discovery of, evidence relevant to the subject matter of an investigation of a possible basis for debarment under this title, the Attorney General, before initiating debarment proceedings or recommending suspension as provided for in this title, may serve on the person a written investigative demand which requires the person to perform any one or more of the following:

subparagraph.text: to be examined under oath;
to answer written interrogatories; or
to produce documentary material and permit inspection and copying of such material.

paragraph.text: The demand of the Attorney General shall:

subparagraph.text: state the grounds for debarment under investigation;
describe the class of documentary material to be produced under the demand with sufficient specificity to indicate fairly the material demanded;
contain a copy of the written interrogatories;

prescribe a reasonable time of not less than 3 days after the demand is served at which time the person must appear to testify, within which time the person must answer the written interrogatories, and within which time the documentary materials must be produced;
specify the place for the taking of testimony and for the production of documentary materials; and
identify the member of the Office of the Attorney General who will:

sub-subparagraph.text: take testimony;
receive the answers to the written interrogatories; and
review the documentary material to be made available for inspection and copying.

paragraph.text: A petition to extend the time for compliance or to modify or set aside a demand issued under this subsection may be filed at any time before the date specified in the demand in the circuit court of the county of the petitioner’s residence or principal place of business.

subsection.text: The Board shall notify a person that the person is debarred under § 16-202(a) of this title, and shall give reasonable opportunity for that person to be heard on whether the stated basis for debarment exists.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may institute proceedings to debar a person under § 16-202(b) or § 16-203 of this title by filing an administrative complaint with the Board.
The Board shall notify the person that debarment proceedings have been initiated and that the person has a right to a hearing.

subsection.text: Before being debarred, a person subject to debarment under § 16-202(b) or § 16-203 of this title is entitled to a hearing before the Board. The Board shall conduct the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
When a unit contracting for a public body is notified that a person who has applied for a contract is subject to debarment under this title, the unit shall notify the person in writing that:

paragraph.text: the application may be disqualified; and
the person has a right to a hearing before the Board.

subsection.text: Unless a person notified by the Board pursuant to this section submits a request to the Board for a hearing within 30 days after receiving such notice, the person:

paragraph.text: waives the right to a hearing; and
is debarred.

subsection.text: While a final decision on a debarment is pending, the Board may suspend a person from:

paragraph.text: being considered for the award of, being awarded, or performing a contract with a public body, if the debarment proceedings are instituted under § 16-202(b) of this title; or
being considered for the award of, being awarded, or performing a contract with the State, if the debarment proceedings are instituted under § 16-203 of this title.

subsection.text: A business is suspended to the same extent that a person is suspended under this section if:

paragraph.text: the suspended person’s debarment would cause the debarment of the business under § 16-307 of this subtitle; and
the Board notifies the business in writing of its suspension under this subsection.
A person or business suspended under this section may petition the Board to modify or terminate the suspension.
In its discretion, the Board may conduct, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article, a hearing concerning a petition received under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

In considering a petition received under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board shall conclude whether the integrity of the contracting process and the best interests of the State would be served by continuing, modifying, or terminating the suspension.
The Board shall give the person or business petitioning for modification or termination of a suspension written notice of the Board’s decision.

subsection.text: In making a determination whether a person should be debarred under § 16-202(b) or § 16-203 of this title, the Board shall conclude whether the integrity of the contracting process and the best interests of the State would be served by debarring the person from entering into contracts with the applicable public bodies. In making its determination, the Board shall consider relevant factors, including:

paragraph.text: the nature and seriousness of the act that caused the person to be subject to debarment;
the time the act occurred;
whether and to what extent the person cooperated with authorities in their investigation of the matters;
the conditions under which the person cooperated; and
the conduct of the person since the act occurred.

subsection.text: Upon making its determination under subsection (a) of this section, the Board shall notify the person subject to debarment in writing either that:

paragraph.text: the person is debarred and the period of debarment; or
the person is no longer subject to debarment for the act which was the subject of the hearing and determination.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 16-310 of this subtitle, this section does not apply to a person debarred under § 16-202(a) of this title.
A business is debarred from entering into a contract with a public body if the Board debars:

paragraph.text: an officer, director, controlling shareholder, or partner; or
an employee directly involved in the process of obtaining contracts with public bodies.

subsection.text: The business is debarred under subsection (a) of this section to the same extent as the person debarred by the Board.
A business shall remain debarred under this section:

paragraph.text: as long as the debarred person remains with the business in any capacity described in subsection (a) of this section; or
until the debarment is removed under § 16-310 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall notify in writing any business that it is debarred under this section.
The Board shall keep a roster of all persons and businesses suspended or debarred under this title.
The roster is a public record.

If a person or business is debarred or suspended based on an offense listed in § 16-202 of this title, the person or business may not be considered for the award of, be awarded, or perform, directly or indirectly, a contract with a public body during the time period of debarment or suspension.

If a person or business is debarred or suspended based on an offense listed in § 16-203 of this title, the person or business may not be considered for the award of, be awarded, or perform, directly or indirectly, a contract with the State during the time period of debarment or suspension.

paragraph.text: If the conviction that is the basis for a debarment or suspension is reversed or otherwise rendered void, the debarment or suspension terminates automatically.

If the federal debarment that is the basis for a State debarment is reversed or otherwise rendered void, the debarment terminates automatically if the person debarred provides to the Board sufficient legal documentation that the federal debarment has been reversed or otherwise rendered void.
Any person debarred under § 16-202 of this title may, after a period of 5 years from the date of the debarment, petition the Board for removal of the debarment.
Any person debarred under § 16-203(a), (b), or (d) of this title may petition the Board for removal of the debarment, after the expiration of:

subparagraph.text: one-half of the period of debarment; or
5 years.

paragraph.text: The Board shall consider all petitions received under subsection (b) of this section.

Within 90 days after receiving a petition under subsection (b) of this section, the Board shall determine in its discretion whether to conduct a hearing regarding the petition. If the Board decides to conduct a hearing, it shall conduct the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall notify the person of its decision whether it will conduct a hearing regarding the petition.

subsection.text: In making its determination whether the debarment should be removed, the Board shall conclude whether the integrity of the contracting process and the best interests of the State would be served by continuing the debarment. In making its determination, the Board shall consider relevant factors including those listed in § 16-306(a) of this subtitle.
Upon making its determination, the Board shall give written notice to the petitioner that the debarment is removed or continued.
The time for any hearing or determination by the Board under this section may be extended by the Board upon a showing of good cause.

Every person, upon submitting a bid proposal or other application for a contract with a public body, shall submit an affidavit stating to its best knowledge whether it or any of its officers, directors, or partners, or any of its employees who are directly involved in obtaining or performing contracts with any public bodies has:

paragraph.text: been convicted of bribery, attempted bribery, or conspiracy to bribe, under the laws of any state or of the federal government;
been convicted under a State or federal law or statute of any offense enumerated in § 16-203 of this title; or
been found civilly liable under a State or federal antitrust statute as provided in § 16-203 of this title.

subsection.text: The affidavit required by subsection (a) of this section shall also contain the person’s affirmation that it shall not knowingly enter into a contract with a public body under which a person or business debarred or suspended under this subtitle will provide, directly or indirectly, supplies, services, architectural services, construction related services, leases of real property, or construction.
The requirements of this section are satisfied if the affidavit:

paragraph.text: incorporates by reference the statements contained in an affidavit filed with the same public body within the previous year pursuant to the requirements of this section; and
states that those statements remain accurate.

subsection.text: Debarment proceedings under this subtitle against a person or business subject to debarment under this title may be instituted within 5 years after:

paragraph.text: a final judgment in a civil or criminal action that constitutes a cause for debarment;
an admission, in writing or under oath, of an act or omission that constitutes grounds for a criminal conviction or civil liability that may be a cause for debarment; or
the occurrence of any other event that constitutes a cause for debarment.

subsection.text: Debarment proceedings under this subtitle against a person or business subject to debarment under this title may be instituted after the period set forth in subsection (a) of this section, only if such proceedings are brought within 1 year of the time when the State discovered, or by the exercise of ordinary diligence should have discovered, the grounds for debarment under this title.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Payment security” means security to guarantee payment for labor and materials, including leased equipment, under a contract for construction.
“Performance security” means security to guarantee the performance of a contract for construction.
“Public body” means:

paragraph.text: the State;
a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision;
a public instrumentality; or
any governmental unit authorized to award a contract.
“Supplier” means a person who supplies labor or materials.
“Supplier” includes a lessor of equipment to the extent of the fair rental value of the equipment.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not limit the authority of a public body to require performance security in addition to, or in cases other than, those specified under §§ 17-103, 17-104, 17-106, and 17-107 of this subtitle.
This subtitle applies only to security for a construction contract.

paragraph.text: By ordinance, Baltimore City may provide for a program to satisfy the bonding requirements under §§ 17-103, 17-104, 17-106, and 17-107 of this subtitle with respect to any construction contract:

subparagraph.text: that does not exceed $200,000; and
for which State money is not used.

paragraph.text: The program shall provide for payment security of at least 50% of the total amount payable under the contract.
Before a public body awards a construction contract exceeding $100,000, the contractor shall provide payment security and performance security that meet the requirements of § 17-104 of this subtitle.
The security shall be:

subparagraph.text: for performance security, in an amount that the public body considers adequate for its protection; and
for payment security, at least 50% of the total amount payable under the contract.

subsection.text: A public body, other than the State or a unit of the State government, may require payment security or performance security for a construction contract if:

paragraph.text: the contract exceeds $25,000 but does not exceed $100,000; and
the amount of the security does not exceed 50% of the contract amount.

subsection.text: Payment security or performance security required under this subtitle shall be:

paragraph.text: a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State;
a bond executed by an individual surety that meets the requirements of this section;
cash in an amount equivalent to a bond; or
another form of security:

subparagraph.text: authorized by federal or State regulation; or
that is satisfactory to the public body awarding the contract.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, performance security may include the granting of a mortgage or deed of trust on real property located within the State if such security is satisfactory to the public body awarding the contract.
The face amount of a mortgage or deed of trust on real property granted as security under this subsection may not exceed 75% of the contractor’s equity interest in the property.

A mortgage or deed of trust accepted under this subsection shall be recorded by an official designated by the public body accepting the mortgage or deed of trust in the land records of the county where the real property is situated in accordance with § 3–103 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: A bond executed by an individual surety shall be acceptable as payment security or performance security under this subtitle if:

paragraph.text: the contractor has been denied corporate surety credit;
the individual surety only transacts business through an insurance agency licensed by the Maryland Insurance Administration;
the individual surety attaches an affidavit of individual surety in a format that the Board requires to the bid security;

the individual surety provides a UCC–1 filing security interest to the public body for one or more of the assets listed in item (5)(i) through (iv) and (vi) of this subsection at the time the bond is furnished; and
the individual surety pledges one or more assets in an amount equal to or greater than the aggregate penal amounts of the bonds required by the solicitation, including:

subparagraph.text: cash or certificates of deposit;

cash equivalents held with a federally insured financial institution, or assets that are evidenced by a security interest, including an irrevocable trust receipt issued by the financial institution or by an independent trustee in the name of the public body that:

sub-subparagraph.text: are issued in accordance with § 9–109 of the Commercial Law Article;
contain a payout clause in the event that default cannot be remedied; and
identify the solicitation or contract number for which the security interest is provided;

subparagraph.text: United States government securities at market value;
stocks and bonds that:

sub-subparagraph.text: are actively traded on a national United States security exchange;
are accompanied by certificates issued in the name of the individual surety; and
are pledged at 90% of their 52–week low, as reflected at the time of submission of the bond;

subparagraph.text: real property:

sub-subparagraph.text: that is owned by the contractor or individual surety in fee simple or with cotenants that all agree to act jointly;
that may include the granting of a mortgage or deed of trust on real property located within the State if satisfactory to the public body;

for which the face amount of the mortgage or deed of trust on the real property located within the State does not exceed 75% of the contractor’s or individual surety’s equity interest in the property; and

for which a mortgage or deed of trust accepted under this subsection is recorded by an official designated by the unit where the real property is situated in accordance with § 3–103 of the Real Property Article; or

subparagraph.text: irrevocable letters of credit that:

sub-subparagraph.text: are issued by a federally insured financial institution in the name of the contracting agency;
identify the agency and the solicitation or contract number for which the irrevocable letter of credit is provided; and
contain a payout clause if that default cannot be remedied.

subsection.text: Any asset listed under subsection (c)(5) of this section shall be pledged only for the intended security and may not be pledged for any other security or contract in or outside the State until the asset is released by the public body.
Payment security or performance security required under this subtitle shall be:

paragraph.text: a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State;
cash in an amount equivalent to a bond; or
other security that is satisfactory to the public body awarding the contract.

Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, performance security may include the granting of a mortgage or deed of trust on real property located within the State if such security is satisfactory to the public body awarding the contract.
The face amount of a mortgage or deed of trust on real property granted as security under this subsection may not exceed 75% of the contractor’s equity interest in the property.

A mortgage or deed of trust accepted under this subsection shall be recorded by an official designated by the public body accepting the mortgage or deed of trust in the land records of the county where the real property is situated in accordance with § 3–103 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: Security under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: if required by the State or a unit of the State government, shall be payable to “the State of Maryland”; or
if required by any other public body, shall be payable to that public body.

subsection.text: The form of payment security or performance security shall be approved:

paragraph.text: for the State or a unit of the State government, by the Attorney General; and
for any other public body, by its attorney.

subsection.text: The contractor shall file the security or evidence of a trust account established as security:

paragraph.text: if payable to the State under this section, in the Office of the Comptroller; or
if payable to any other public body, in the appropriate office of that public body.

section.text: Before a contractor receives a progress or final payment under a contract covered by payment security, the contractor shall certify in writing that, in accordance with contractual arrangements, suppliers:

paragraph.text: have been paid from the proceeds of previous progress payments; and
will be paid in a timely manner from the proceeds of the progress or final payment currently due.

section.text: A contractor who provides payment security under this subtitle in connection with a construction contract awarded by a public body need not execute a waiver of a mechanics’ lien to the public body.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a supplier may sue on payment security if the supplier:

paragraph.text: supplied labor or materials in the prosecution of work provided for in a contract subject to this subtitle; and
has not been paid in full for the labor or materials within 90 days after the day that the person last supplied labor or materials for which the claim is made.

A supplier who has a direct contractual relationship with a subcontractor or sub-subcontractor of a contractor who has provided payment security but no contractual relationship with the contractor may sue on the security if the supplier gives written notice to the contractor within 90 days after the labor or materials for which the claim is made were last supplied in prosecution of work covered by the security.
A notice under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall state with substantial accuracy the amount claimed and the person to whom the labor or material was supplied; and
shall be sent by certified mail to the contractor at the contractor’s residence or a place where the contractor has an office or does business.

paragraph.text: On request by a person who submits an affidavit verifying that the person has supplied labor or materials but has not been paid or is being sued under this section, the Comptroller or the officer in charge of the office where the payment security or evidence of security is required to be filed shall issue:

subparagraph.text: a certified copy of the payment bond; or
for other security, a certified statement of the security.

paragraph.text: The person requesting certification shall pay a reasonable fee, set by the Comptroller or other officer required to issue the certification, to cover the costs of preparation.
A certification under this section is prima facie evidence of the contents, execution, and delivery of payment security.

An executory contract between a supplier and a contractor or subcontractor that is related to a construction contract may not waive or require the supplier to waive the right to sue on payment security under this section.

A provision in an executory contract between a supplier and a contractor or subcontractor that is related to a construction contract and that conditions payment to the supplier on receipt of payment by the person from a public body or other third party, may not abrogate or waive the right of the supplier to sue on payment security under this subtitle.
A provision of a contract made in violation of this subsection is void as against the public policy of the State.

subsection.text: An action on a payment bond required by this subtitle shall be filed in the appropriate court of the county where:

paragraph.text: the contract was executed and performed; or
the contractor has its principal place of business.

subsection.text: An action on a payment bond required by this subtitle shall be filed within 1 year after the public body finally accepts the work performed under the contract.
An obligee named in a bond or a trustee for any other security is not liable for any costs in connection with an action on a payment bond required by this subtitle.
Subsections (b)(1), (2), and (3), (c), and (d) of this section do not apply to an entity that is required to comply with the provisions of § 13-225 of this article.

paragraph.text: If a contractor has furnished 100% payment security and 100% performance security in accordance with this subtitle under a contract for construction awarded by a public body, the percentage specified in the contract for retainage may not exceed 10% of the total amount for the first 50% of the contract.
Unless a public body demonstrates the need to retain more than 5% to protect the public interest, after 50% of the contract is completed, a public body may retain only 5% of the total amount.
In addition to retainage, a public body may withhold from payments otherwise due a contractor any amount that the public body reasonably believes necessary to protect the public body’s interest.
Except as provided in paragraph (5) of this subsection, within 120 days after satisfactory completion of a contract for construction, a public body shall release any retainage due to the contractor.

If there is a dispute or contract claim between the contractor and the public body concerning the satisfactory completion of a contract for construction, the public body shall release the retainage to the contractor within 120 days after the resolution of the dispute or contract claim.
A contractor may not retain a percentage of payments due a subcontractor that exceeds the percentage of payments retained by the public body.

Paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be construed to prohibit a contractor from withholding any amount in addition to retainage if the contractor determines that a subcontractor’s performance under the subcontract provides reasonable grounds for withholding the additional amount.
A subcontractor may not retain a percentage of payments due a lower tier subcontractor that exceeds the percentage of payments retained from the subcontractor.

Paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be construed to prohibit a subcontractor from withholding any amount in addition to retainage if the subcontractor determines that a lower tier subcontractor’s performance under the subcontract provides reasonable grounds for withholding the additional amount.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to limit the application of the remaining provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Little Miller Act”.

subsection.text: In this subtitle, unless the context indicates otherwise, the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Apprentice” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: is at least 16 years old;
has signed with an employer or employer’s agent, an association of employers, an organization of employees, or a joint committee from both, an agreement including a statement of:

subparagraph.text: the trade, craft, or occupation that the individual is learning; and
the beginning and ending dates of the apprenticeship; and

paragraph.text: is registered in a program of the Council or the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training of the United States Department of Labor.

subsection.text: “Commissioner” means:

paragraph.text: the Commissioner of Labor and Industry;
the Deputy Commissioner of Labor and Industry; or
an authorized representative of the Commissioner.

subsection.text: “Construction” includes all:

paragraph.text: building;
reconstructing;
improving;
enlarging;
painting and decorating;
altering;
maintaining; and
repairing.

subsection.text: “Council” means the Apprenticeship and Training Council.

paragraph.text: “Employee” means an apprentice or worker employed by a contractor or subcontractor under a public work contract.
“Employee” does not include an individual employed by a public body.
“Locality” means the county in which the work is to be performed.
If the public work is located within 2 or more counties, the locality includes all counties in which the public work is located.

subsection.text: “Prevailing wage rate” means the hourly rate of wages paid in the locality as determined by the Commissioner under § 17-208 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Public body” means:

subparagraph.text: the State;
except as provided in paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection, a unit of the State government or instrumentality of the State;
any political subdivision, agency, person, or entity with respect to the construction of any public work for which 50% or more of the money used for construction is State money; and
notwithstanding paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection, a political subdivision if its governing body:

sub-subparagraph.text: provides by ordinance or resolution that the political subdivision is covered by this subtitle; and
gives written notice of that ordinance or resolution to the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: “Public body” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a unit of the State government or instrumentality of the State funded wholly from a source other than the State; or
any political subdivision, agency, person, or entity with respect to the construction of any public work for which less than 50% of the money used for construction is State money.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, “public work” means a structure or work, including a bridge, building, ditch, road, alley, waterwork, or sewage disposal plant, that:

subparagraph.text: is constructed for public use or benefit; or
is paid for wholly or partly by public money.

paragraph.text: “Public work” does not include, unless let to contract, a structure or work whose construction is performed by a public service company under order of the Public Service Commission or other public authority regardless of:

subparagraph.text: public supervision or direction; or
payment wholly or partly from public money.

subsection.text: “Public work contract” means a contract for construction of a public work.
“Worker” means a laborer or mechanic.
This subtitle does not limit:

paragraph.text: the hours of work an employee may work in a particular period of time; or
the right of a contractor to pay an employee under a public work contract more than the prevailing wage rate.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a public work contract of less than $500,000; or

the part of a public work contract for which the federal government provides money if, as to that part, the contractor is required to pay the prevailing wage rate as determined by the United States Secretary of Labor.

subsection.text: If this subtitle and the federal Davis-Bacon Act apply and the federal act is suspended, the Governor may declare this subtitle suspended for the same period for:

paragraph.text: the part of that public work contract for which the United States Secretary of Labor would have been required to make a determination of a prevailing wage rate; or
that entire public work contract.

subsection.text: In this section, “Advisory Council” means the Advisory Council on Prevailing Wage Rates.
There is an Advisory Council on Prevailing Wage Rates in the Division of Labor and Industry.
The Advisory Council consists of the following 6 members:

paragraph.text: 2 individuals from management in the building and construction industry;
2 individuals from labor in the building and construction industry; and
2 individuals from the general public.
The Governor shall appoint each member with the advice of the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The 2 members from management shall be selected from a list submitted by management organizations in the building and construction industry.
The 2 members from labor shall be selected from a list submitted by labor organizations in the building and construction industry.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Advisory Council shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: From among the Advisory Council members, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.
The chairman of the Advisory Council:

subparagraph.text: shall serve for 1 year from the day of appointment; and
is not eligible for reappointment as chairman for the following year.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Advisory Council on October 1, 1988.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
If a vacancy occurs, the Governor shall appoint a new member with the advice of the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

paragraph.text: The Advisory Council shall advise and submit recommendations to the Commissioner on the Commissioner’s functions under this subtitle.

The Commissioner may ask other units of the State government or units of local governments to provide statistical data, reports, and other information to help the Advisory Council to carry out its duties.

subsection.text: The Advisory Council shall meet at least twice a year and on other days the Commissioner requests, at the times and places that it determines.
Each member of the Advisory Council is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this section shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2014.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations reasonably required to carry out this subtitle.
The regulations may include exemptions for minimum number of hours worked or workers employed.
Payroll records shall be kept in accordance with those regulations.

subsection.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Commissioner shall submit to the Governor and to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation an annual report that:

paragraph.text: describes the activities of the Commissioner under this subtitle during the preceding calendar year; and
includes:

subparagraph.text: each recommendation received from the Advisory Council on Prevailing Wage Rates during the preceding calendar year;
full information about the operation of this subtitle; and
other information about prevailing wage rates, as the Commissioner desires.

subsection.text: A contractor or subcontractor under a public work contract subject to this subtitle:

paragraph.text: shall employ only competent workers and apprentices who qualify under subsection (b) of this section;
may not employ any individual classified as a helper or trainee; and

may refuse to employ a worker who is a resident of another state if the Commissioner finds that the other state enforces a law that prohibits a resident of this State from employment as a worker under a public work contract in that state, unless:

subparagraph.text: the refusal is in conflict or otherwise inconsistent with a federal law applicable to the public work;
the federal government is to pay wholly or partly for the public work; and
the inconsistency with federal law jeopardizes the availability of federal funds for the public work.

subsection.text: An apprentice under a public work contract shall be part of and used in accordance with an apprenticeship program registered with the Council and approved by the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training of the United States Department of Labor.

paragraph.text: For each public work to which this subtitle applies, the Commissioner shall determine the prevailing wage rate for each classification of worker engaged in work of the same or a similar character.
The Commissioner shall determine the prevailing wage rates for both straight time and overtime.
These determinations shall be made in accordance with:

subparagraph.text: the applicable provisions of Title 10, Subtitles 1 through 3 of the State Government Article; and
to the extent not inconsistent with those provisions, the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the prevailing wage rate for straight time for a worker is the rate paid:

subparagraph.text: in the locality;
on projects similar to the proposed public work;
for work of the same or a similar character as that to be performed on the public work; and
to 50% or more of the workers in the worker’s occupational classification.

paragraph.text: The prevailing wage rate for overtime for a worker shall be at least time and a half the prevailing wage rate for straight time for that worker.
If fewer than 50% of the workers in the locality working in the same classification receive the same wage rate:

subparagraph.text: the prevailing wage rate shall be the rate paid to at least 40% of those workers; or
if fewer than 40% receive the same wage rate, the rate shall be a weighted average rate obtained by:

sub-subparagraph.text: adding the products obtained by multiplying each hourly rate paid to workers in the classification by the number of workers receiving that rate; and
dividing that sum by the total number of workers in the classification.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner determines that there is not a substantial number of competent workers engaged in similar work in the locality, the Commissioner shall determine the prevailing wage rate based on the nearest locality within the State that most closely approximates that locality in:

subparagraph.text: population;
degree of industrialization; and
skill of work force.

subsection.text: The calculation of the rate paid in the locality shall include the basic hourly rate of pay and either:

paragraph.text: if a contractor is not required by law to provide fringe benefits, the hourly rate of contribution irrevocably made by a contractor or subcontractor to a third person under a fund, plan, or program that provides:

subparagraph.text: medical, surgical, or hospital care;
retirement, disability, or death benefits, including a profit sharing plan that provides benefits on retirement;
unemployment, life, or accident insurance or compensation;
insurance or compensation for injury or illness resulting from occupational activity;
vacation and holiday pay;
subsidies to defray costs of apprenticeship or other similar programs; or
other bona fide fringe benefits; or

paragraph.text: the hourly rate of costs to the contractor or subcontractor that reasonably may be anticipated in providing the fringe benefits specified in item (1) of this subsection under an enforceable commitment to carry out a financially responsible plan or program that is communicated in writing to the workers.

subsection.text: An apprentice under a public work contract shall be paid at least the percentage, set by the Council, of the prevailing wage rate for a mechanic in the trade in which the apprentice is employed.
One time per year, the Commissioner shall determine the prevailing wage rate for a classification of worker in a locality by considering among other things:

paragraph.text: any other payroll information relevant to the determination; and
wage rates established by collective bargaining agreements.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall mail notice as provided in § 17-210(b)(2) of this subtitle at least 60 days before making a determination under this section.

paragraph.text: The determination, as issued under this section or modified in a proceeding under § 17-211 of this subtitle, is effective for 1 year from the date upon which the Commissioner issued the determination under this section.
The Commissioner shall show on the determination the date upon which it expires.
Upon expiration of the prevailing wage determination for a locality, the Commissioner shall issue a new determination for the locality.
A determination applies to a public work covered by this subtitle that is the subject of a call for bids or proposals published on or before the date upon which it expires.

subsection.text: Before a public body advertises for bids or proposals for a public work contract, it shall request the Commissioner to determine the prevailing wage rate for each classification of worker required to perform the public work contract.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall give notice of each prevailing wage rate determination for a public work contract under this subtitle.
On written request, the Commissioner shall mail to any representative of any classification, any employer, or any representative of any group of employers notice:

subparagraph.text: that a determination will be made, at least 60 days before making the determination; and
of the determination, after making the determination.

subsection.text: After a determination has been made, the public body shall include each prevailing wage rate for straight time and overtime:

paragraph.text: in any call for bids or proposals;
in the specifications for the public work contract; and
in the public work contract.

subsection.text: A determination of a prevailing wage rate issued under § 17-209 of this subtitle is subject to review when a public body publishes a call for bids or proposals in which the determination is used for the first time following its issuance under § 17-209 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Within 10 days after a public body publishes any call for bids or proposals, as described in subsection (a) of this section, a petition for review of a determination of a prevailing wage rate may be submitted to the Commissioner by:

subparagraph.text: the public body;
a prospective bidder or offeror or a representative of a prospective bidder or offeror;
a representative of a group of employers engaged in the type of construction for which the prevailing wage rate was determined; or
a representative of a classification of worker for which the prevailing wage rate was determined.

paragraph.text: A petition under this subsection shall be verified and shall set forth the facts on which it is based.

If a petition is not filed within the period set under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the determination is final and is the rate applicable in the locality for the remainder of the 1-year period for which it was issued under § 17-209 of this subtitle.
Within 2 days after a petition is submitted under this section, the petitioner shall send a copy to the public body.

On receipt of a copy of the petition, the public body shall extend the closing date for bids or proposals until 5 days after the Commissioner publishes the final determination under subsection (f) of this section.
Within 20 days after a petition is submitted, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: after giving the notice required under paragraph (3) of this subsection, conduct an investigation; and
hold a public hearing to review the petition.

paragraph.text: If more than 1 petition is submitted, the Commissioner may consolidate the hearings on any of the petitions.

The Commissioner shall notify the petitioner, public body, recognized collective bargaining representative for the classification for which a review is requested, and any other person entitled to receive notice under § 17-210(b)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: At the hearing:

paragraph.text: the Commissioner shall introduce as evidence the investigation conducted under subsection (d) of this section and the other facts that formed the basis of the Commissioner’s original determination; and
any interested party, including the Commissioner, may introduce other evidence material to the issue.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after the conclusion of a review hearing, the Commissioner shall send to the public body and each interested party, a determination of the prevailing wage rate. This determination is final and is the rate applicable in the locality for the remainder of the 1-year period for which it was issued under § 17-209 of this subtitle.

section.text: A member of a public body may not vote for the award of a public work contract or vote to disburse money for the construction of a public work unless:

paragraph.text: the public body has asked the Commissioner to determine the prevailing wage rates in the locality for each classification of worker required to perform the public work contract; and
the determination has been made part of the specifications and public work contract for the public work.

subsection.text: Before entering into a public work contract, a public body shall require that the public work contract include a clause for payment:

paragraph.text: to a worker, of at least the prevailing wage rate; and
to an apprentice, of at least the rate that the Council sets for an apprentice based on a percentage of the prevailing wage rate for a mechanic in that trade.

subsection.text: A public body shall require bonds on public work contracts to guarantee the faithful performance of the prevailing wage rate clause of the public work contract.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each contractor and subcontractor under a public work contract shall pay not less than the prevailing wage rate of straight time to an employee for each hour that the employee works.
A contractor and subcontractor shall pay an employee the prevailing wage rate of overtime for each hour that the employee works:

paragraph.text: in excess of 10 hours in any single calendar day;
in excess of 40 hours per each workweek; or
on Sunday or a legal holiday.

subsection.text: Each contractor and subcontractor subject to this subtitle shall pay each employee not less than the prevailing wage rate required under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: unconditionally;
without subsequent rebate; and
except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, without deductions for:

subparagraph.text: food;
sleeping accommodations;
transportation;
use of small tools; or
any other thing of any kind.

subsection.text: A contractor or subcontractor may make deductions that are:

paragraph.text: required by law;
required or allowed by a collective bargaining agreement between a bona fide labor organization and the contractor or subcontractor; or
contained in a written agreement between an employee and an employer undertaken at the beginning of employment, if the agreement:

subparagraph.text: concerns food, sleeping accommodations, or other similar items;
is submitted by the employer to the public body awarding the public work contract; and
is approved by the public body as fair and reasonable.

subsection.text: A laborer may perform any work that is not ordinarily performed by a mechanic or mechanic’s apprentice, but shall be paid the prevailing wage rate for the work performed.

paragraph.text: A laborer receiving the prevailing wage rate for laborers may not perform work ordinarily performed by a mechanic or mechanic’s apprentice.

If a laborer performs work ordinarily performed by any mechanic or mechanic’s apprentice, the contractor or subcontractor shall pay the laborer for the entire time of performance of that work at the prevailing wage rate for a mechanic.

subsection.text: Each contractor under a public work contract subject to this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: post a clearly legible statement of each prevailing wage rate to be paid under the public work contract; and
keep the statement posted during the full time that any employee is employed on the public work contract.

subsection.text: The statement of prevailing wage rates shall be posted in a prominent and easily accessible place at the site of the public work.
Subject to § 10-1001 of the State Government Article, the Commissioner may impose on a person that violates this section a civil penalty of up to $50 per violation.
Each contractor required to pay the prevailing wage rate shall:

paragraph.text: keep payroll records covering work performed directly at the work site in accordance with regulations adopted by the Commissioner; and
allow the Commissioner or the public body to inspect the records at any reasonable time and as often as necessary.

Each contractor shall submit a complete copy of the payroll records of the contractor and, for work performed at the work site, of the subcontractors in the form that the Commissioner specifies by regulation to:

subparagraph.text: the public body; and
the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner and the public body shall make payroll records available for public inspection during regular business hours.

subsection.text: Each copy of the payroll records shall be accompanied by a statement that is signed by the contractor or, for the subcontractor’s records, by the subcontractor and indicates that:

paragraph.text: the payroll records are correct;
the wage rates paid are not less than those established by the Commissioner as set forth in the public work contract;
the classification set forth for each employee conforms with the work performed by that employee; and
the contractor or subcontractor has complied with each requirement of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If a contractor is late in submitting copies of the payroll records required under subsection (b) of this section:

paragraph.text: the public body may postpone the processing of partial payment estimates under the public work contract pending receipt of the copies; and
the contractor shall be liable to the public body for liquidated damages of $10 for each calendar day the records are late.

subsection.text: Each public body that awards a public work contract shall:

paragraph.text: take cognizance of a complaint of a violation of this subtitle committed in the course of performance of the public work contract; and
when making payments to the contractor, withhold any amount that the contractor owes to its employees or the public body as a result of the violation.
The Commissioner shall institute an investigation as necessary to determine compliance with this subtitle and regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The Commissioner promptly shall investigate a complaint of a violation of this subtitle.
Any written or oral complaint or statement made by an employee is confidential and may not be disclosed to the employer without the consent of the employee.

subsection.text: A contractor or subcontractor subject to an investigation under this section shall allow the Commissioner to observe work being performed at the site of a public work project, to interview employees, and to review books and records, to determine:

paragraph.text: the correctness of each classification;
the ratio of apprentices to mechanics; and
payment of straight and overtime prevailing wage rates as required under the public work contract.

subsection.text: If, after investigation, the Commissioner determines that a provision of this subtitle may have been violated, the Commissioner immediately shall notify the public body.

paragraph.text: On notification, the public body shall withhold from payment due the contractor or subcontractor an amount sufficient to:

subparagraph.text: pay each employee of the contractor or subcontractor the full amount of wages due under this subtitle; and
satisfy a liability of a contractor for liquidated damages as provided in § 17-222(a) of this subtitle, pending a final determination.

paragraph.text: If a subcontractor is responsible for a violation of this subtitle, the contractor:

subparagraph.text: may withhold from payment to the subcontractor an amount equal to the amount withheld from the contractor under paragraph (1) of this subsection; or
if payment has been made to the subcontractor, may sue to recover that amount.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: issue an order for a hearing within 30 days after completing an investigation; and
expeditiously conduct the hearing.
At least 10 days before the hearing, the Commissioner shall serve, personally or by mail, written notice of the hearing on all interested persons, including the public body.
The notice shall include:

subparagraph.text: a statement of the facts disclosed in the investigation; and
the time and place of the hearing.

paragraph.text: In conducting an investigation or hearing under this section, the Commissioner is deemed to be acting in a quasi-judicial capacity and may:

subparagraph.text: issue subpoenas;
administer oaths; or
examine witnesses.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall grant each interested person an opportunity to speak at the hearing on matters relevant to the complaint.
After the conclusion of the hearing, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: file in the Commissioner’s office an order that states the Commissioner’s determination; and
serve, personally or by mail, the public body and parties to the hearing with a copy of the order and notice of its filing.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner finds a violation, the Commissioner shall determine the amount of liquidated damages and restitution to be assessed for the violation.
On the entry and service of a Commissioner’s order, the public body, from the money due the contractor or subcontractor, shall:

subparagraph.text: pay the affected employees the full amount of wages due them; and
satisfy the obligation of the contractor or subcontractor to pay liquidated damages as required under § 17-222 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A contractor under a public work contract is liable to the public body for liquidated damages of $20 for each laborer or other employee for each day for which:

paragraph.text: the laborer is paid less than the prevailing wage rate of a mechanic while performing a task required to be performed by a mechanic or mechanic’s apprentice; or
the employee is paid less than the prevailing wage rate.
If a contractor or subcontractor pays an employee less than the amount the employee is entitled to receive for the work performed, the contractor shall make restitution to the employee.
The contractor and the subcontractor shall be jointly and severally liable for restitution to the subcontractor’s employees.

subsection.text: If a public body does not comply with a provision of this subtitle, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: shall give written notice of the noncompliance to the public body;
may require compliance within a sufficient period as determined by the Commissioner; and
after the expiration of that period, may inform the Attorney General in writing that notice has been given and that the public body has not complied with the notice.

subsection.text: As soon as possible after being informed by the Commissioner, the Attorney General shall sue, in the name of the State, in the circuit court for the county where the public body is located to seek any remedies that the court may find appropriate to carry out the policies of this subtitle.
In the action, the State and the public body each shall have the right of appeal that is provided by law in an injunction proceeding.

paragraph.text: If an employee under a public work contract is paid less than the prevailing wage rate for that employee’s classification for the work performed, the employee may file a complaint with the Commissioner.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, a complaint filed under this section shall be subject to the provisions of § 17–221 of this subtitle.
If the Commissioner’s investigation determines that the employer violated provisions of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall try to resolve the issue informally.

subparagraph.text: If the Commissioner is unable to resolve the matter informally, the Commissioner shall issue an order for a hearing in accordance with § 17–221 of this subtitle.

If, at the conclusion of a hearing ordered under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the Commissioner determines that the employee is entitled to restitution under this subtitle, the Commissioner shall issue an order in accordance with § 17–221 of this subtitle.

If an employer of an employee found to be entitled to restitution under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph is no longer working under a contract with a public body, the Commissioner may order that restitution be paid directly by the employer to the employee within a reasonable period of time, as determined by the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: If an employer fails to comply with an order to pay restitution to an employee under paragraph (4)(iii) of this subsection, the Commissioner or the employee may bring a civil action to enforce the order in the circuit court in the county where the employee or employer is located.
An action under this section is considered to be a suit for wages.
A judgment in an action under this section shall have the same force and effect as any other judgment for wages.
An action brought under this section for a violation of this subtitle shall be filed within 3 years from the date the affected employee knew or should have known of the violation.
The failure of an employee to protest orally or in writing the payment of a wage that is less than the prevailing wage rate is not a bar to recovery in an action under this section.

A contract or other written document in which an employee states that the employee shall be paid less than the amount required by this subtitle does not bar the recovery of any remedy required under this subtitle.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, if the court in an action filed under this section finds that an employer paid an employee less than the requisite prevailing wage, the court shall award the affected employee the difference between the wage actually paid and the prevailing wage at the time that the services were rendered.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, unpaid fringe benefit contributions owed for an employee in accordance with this section shall be paid to the appropriate benefit fund, plan, or program.
In the absence of an appropriate benefit fund, plan, or program, the amount owed for fringe benefits for an employee shall be paid directly to the employee.

paragraph.text: The court may order the payment of double damages or treble damages under this section if the court finds that the employer withheld wages or fringe benefits willfully and knowingly or with deliberate ignorance or reckless disregard of the employer’s obligations under this subtitle.
In an action under this section, the court shall award a prevailing plaintiff reasonable counsel fees and costs.
If the court finds that an employee submitted a false or fraudulent claim in an action under this section, the court may order the employee to pay the employer reasonable counsel fees and costs.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, an action filed in accordance with this section may be brought by one or more employees on behalf of that employee or group of employees and on behalf of other employees similarly situated.

An employee may not be a party plaintiff to an action brought under this section unless that employee files written consent with the court in which the action is brought to become a party to the action.

A person found to have made a false or fraudulent representation or omission known to be false or made with deliberate ignorance or reckless disregard for its truth or falsity regarding a material fact in connection with any prevailing wage payroll record required by § 17–220 of this subtitle is liable for a civil penalty of $1,000 for each falsified record.
The penalty shall be recoverable in a civil action filed in accordance with this section and paid to the State General Fund.

subsection.text: An employer may not discharge, threaten, or otherwise retaliate or discriminate against an employee regarding compensation or other terms and conditions of employment because that employee or an organization or other person acting on behalf of that employee:

paragraph.text: reports or makes a complaint under this subtitle or otherwise asserts the worker’s rights under this section; or
participates in any investigation, hearing, or inquiry held by the Commissioner under § 17–221 of this subtitle.
A contractor or subcontractor may not retaliate or discriminate against an employee in violation of this section.

If a contractor or subcontractor retaliates or discriminates against an employee in violation of this section, the affected employee may file an action in any court of competent jurisdiction within 3 years from the employee’s knowledge of the action.
If the court finds in favor of the employee in an action brought under this subsection, the court shall order that the contractor or subcontractor:

subparagraph.text: reinstate the employee or provide the employee restitution, as appropriate;
pay the employee an amount equal to three times the amount of back wages and fringe benefits calculated from the date of the violation; and
pay reasonable counsel fees and other costs.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: violate the wage provisions of a public work contract;
allow or require an employee to work for less than the applicable prevailing wage rate;

except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, ask an employee or prospective employee to give anything of value to that person or any other person on a statement, representation, or understanding that failure to comply with the request or demand will prevent the employee from procuring or retaining employment; or
directly or indirectly, authorize a violation of this subtitle by any other person.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to any agent of a collective bargaining organization acting in collection of sums as allowed by the National Labor Relations Act.

paragraph.text: After investigation and entry of an order in accordance with § 17-221 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall file with the Secretary of State a list of the contractors and any subcontractors who persistently and willfully violate the provisions of this subtitle.
Filing under this subsection shall be notice to a public body and its representatives.

If the name of a contractor or any subcontractor appears on the list, that contractor or subcontractor shall be prohibited from entering into a contract for construction of a public work directly or indirectly for 2 years from the day on which the list is filed.
A public body may not award a contract for construction of a public work to a person who is prohibited from entering into a contract under this section.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“American steel product” means a product that is:

paragraph.text: produced from steel made in any state by the open hearth, basic oxygen, electric furnace, Bessemer, or other steel making process; and
rolled, forged, drawn, cast, extruded, or otherwise similarly processed.

subsection.text: “Public body” means:

paragraph.text: the State;
a unit of the State government; or
a county, municipal corporation, school or conservation district, or other governmental entity that, by State law, awards contracts for public construction or other public work.

section.text: The provisions of this subtitle do not apply if they conflict with a federal law or grant affecting a contract.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a public body shall require a contractor or subcontractor to use or supply only American steel products in the performance of a contract for:

paragraph.text: constructing or maintaining a public work; or
buying or manufacturing machinery or equipment that:

subparagraph.text: is composed of at least 10,000 pounds of steel products; and
is to be installed at a public work site.

subsection.text: This section does not apply if the head of a public body determines that:

paragraph.text: the price of American steel products is not reasonable, as provided in § 17-304 of this subtitle;
American steel products are not produced in sufficient quantity to meet the requirements of the contract; or
the purchase of American steel products would be inconsistent with the public interest.

subsection.text: The public body shall give notice of the requirement for American steel products in the invitation for bids or request for proposals.

section.text: The Board shall adopt regulations, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, stating that a bid or offered price of an American steel product shall be considered reasonable if it does not exceed the sum of the bid or offered price of a similar steel product of foreign origin, including duty, plus:

paragraph.text: 20% of that bid or offered price; or
30% of that bid or offered price if the steel product is produced in a “substantial labor surplus area” as defined by the United States Department of Labor.

subsection.text: Unless a public body is satisfied that a person has completed the work in full compliance with §§ 17-303 and 17-304 of this subtitle, the public body may not pay or authorize a payment for work subject to §§ 17-303 and 17-304 of this subtitle to a person under a contract.

If a person receives a payment that should not have been made under subsection (a) of this section, the Attorney General may recover the portion of the payment that is attributable to work that does not comply with §§ 17-303 and 17-304 of this subtitle directly from the person who did not comply with §§ 17-303 and 17-304 of this subtitle by filing a complaint in the circuit court for the county where the contract was executed or performed.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Buy American Steel Act”.
In this subtitle, “contribution” has the meaning stated in § 1-101 of the Election Law Article.

Each State or local government procurement contract shall include a clause covering the obligation of a contractor to comply with the political contribution reporting requirements under Title 14 of the Election Law Article to which the contractor may be subject.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“eMaryland Marketplace” has the meaning stated in § 13–101 of this article.
“Procurement” means procurement by competitive sealed bidding, competitive sealed proposals, or noncompetitive negotiation.

In addition to any other provision of law, the following persons shall use eMaryland Marketplace to publish notice of a procurement or publish a notice of award of a procurement that is at the same amount or exceeds the amount required by the Board for a State contract to be published in eMaryland Marketplace:

paragraph.text: a unit of State government;
a county;
a municipality;
a bicounty or multicounty governmental agency;
a special tax district, sanitary district, drainage district, soil conservation district, and water supply district;
a public institution of higher education;
a public school; and
except for the Maryland Health and Higher Educational Facilities Authority, an entity exempt from the provisions of this Division II in accordance with § 11–203 of this article.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to prohibit a person listed in subsection (a) of this section from publishing notice of a procurement or publishing a notice of award in accordance with any other law or policy.
An unintentional violation of this section may not constitute grounds to challenge or appeal:

paragraph.text: the award of a procurement; or
the process through which a procurement was conducted.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Apprenticeship training program” means an apprenticeship training program that is registered with, and approved by, the Apprenticeship and Training Council or the U.S. Department of Labor.
“Covered craft” means a classification of workers listed in the prevailing wage determination applicable to the covered project.
“Covered project” means a project for the construction of a public work, as defined under § 17–201 of this title, that is valued at $500,000 or more.
“Department” means the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Fund” means the State Apprenticeship Training Fund established under § 17–602 of this subtitle.

“Participates in an apprenticeship training program” means that a contractor or subcontractor makes regular financial contributions for each covered craft to apprenticeship training programs for covered crafts during the term of the covered project that are at least equal to the hourly fringe benefit contribution rates required for apprenticeship training by the applicable prevailing wage determination for the project, as specified by the Secretary.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
There is a State Apprenticeship Training Fund in the Department.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: payments made by contractors or subcontractors in accordance with this subtitle; and
penalties collected as a result of violations of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of this article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Secretary shall use money in the Fund to:

paragraph.text: promote preapprenticeship programs and other workforce development programs in the State’s public secondary schools and community colleges that assist students in preparing for and entering apprenticeship training programs; and
pay any costs associated with carrying out the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A contractor that is awarded a procurement contract for a covered project shall provide to a unit, as a condition of receiving the contract, written verification that:

paragraph.text: the contractor participates in an apprenticeship training program for each covered craft in which it will employ persons for the covered project;
the contractor will make payments to the Fund; or

the contractor will make payments in amounts determined under § 17–605 of this subtitle to a registered apprenticeship program or to an organization that has registered apprenticeship programs for the purpose of supporting these programs.

subsection.text: The written verification required under subsection (a) of this section shall be provided by a contractor to the unit responsible for the project before the contractor commences performance under the procurement contract.

Organizations that have registered apprenticeship programs and receive funds from contractors under subsection (a)(3) of this section shall certify to the Secretary that all funds received are used solely for the purpose of improving or expanding apprenticeship training in the State.

The Secretary shall adopt regulations to establish a process for auditing organizations that provide registered apprenticeship programs to ensure that all funds received under subsection (a)(3) of this section are used solely to improve and expand apprenticeship programs in the State.
A subcontractor that performs work valued at $100,000 or more for a covered project shall provide to a unit written verification that:

paragraph.text: the subcontractor participates in an apprenticeship training program for each covered craft in which it will employ persons for the covered project;
the subcontractor will make payments to the Fund; or

the subcontractor will make payments in amounts determined under § 17–605 of this subtitle to a registered apprenticeship program or to an organization that has registered apprenticeship programs for the purpose of supporting these programs.

subsection.text: The written verification required under subsection (a) of this section shall be provided by a subcontractor to the unit responsible for the project before the subcontractor commences performance under the procurement contract.

Organizations that have registered apprenticeship programs and receive funds from contractors under subsection (a)(3) of this section shall certify to the Secretary that all funds received are used solely for the purpose of improving or expanding apprenticeship training in the State.

The Secretary shall adopt regulations to establish a process for auditing organizations that provide registered apprenticeship programs to ensure that all funds received under subsection (a)(3) of this section are used solely to improve and expand apprenticeship programs in the State.

paragraph.text: A contractor or subcontractor that elects to make payments to the Fund in accordance with this subtitle shall make payments, as determined by the Secretary, not to exceed 25 cents per hour for each employee in each covered craft who is employed by the contractor or subcontractor on the covered project.

If the prevailing wage determination for a covered craft includes a fringe benefit contribution for apprenticeship programs that exceeds 25 cents, the contractor or subcontractor shall pay the difference to the employees in the covered craft in wages.

Payments made under this section fulfill any obligations of the contractor or subcontractor regarding contributions for apprenticeship programs included in the prevailing wage determination under § 17–208 of this title.
Payments made under paragraph (1) of this section are permissible deductions under § 17–215(b) of this title.
Payments made to the Fund in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be made on a monthly basis.

If the Secretary determines that a contractor or subcontractor for a covered project has made contributions to an apprenticeship training program at rates lower than those required by this subtitle, the contractor or subcontractor shall make payments to the Fund for the difference between its contribution and the contribution rate required by this subtitle.
Payments made to the Fund in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be made on a monthly basis.

subsection.text: A contractor shall report all apprenticeship payments made under this subtitle on prevailing wage payroll records required by § 17–220 of this title.

paragraph.text: A contractor or subcontractor that makes contributions to the Fund, a registered apprenticeship program, or an organization that has registered apprenticeship programs may request that its contributions be directed to a specific preapprenticeship or workforce development program.
The Secretary shall make a good–faith effort to accommodate requests received in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A contractor or subcontractor that fails to meet the requirements of this subtitle shall be liable for an amount equal to twice the amount of unpaid apprenticeship training contributions required by this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “willfully” means representations or omissions known to be false or made with deliberate ignorance or reckless disregard for their truth or falsity.

Any person, firm, or corporation that is found to have made willfully a false or fraudulent representation or omission regarding a material fact in connection with prevailing wage records required by this section shall be liable for a civil penalty in an amount of up to $1,000 for each employee and each falsified record.
Penalties shall be recoverable in civil actions and paid to the State.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to establish administrative procedures for the collection of payments under this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: The Secretary may file suit to enforce this section in any court of competent jurisdiction.

In an action filed under this subsection, the court shall require the contractor or subcontractor to pay the amount required by subsection (a) of this section, including interest, reasonable counsel fees, and court costs.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** CONTINGENCY – IN EFFECT – CHAPTERS 446 AND 447 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Energy sector of Iran” means activities to develop petroleum or natural gas resources or nuclear power in Iran.
“Financial institution” has the meaning stated in Section 14 of the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996 (Public Law 104–172).
“Iran” includes the government of Iran and any agency or instrumentality of Iran.
“Person” includes:

paragraph.text: a natural person, corporation, company, limited liability company, business association, partnership, society, trust, or any other nongovernmental entity, organization, or group;

a governmental entity or instrumentality of a government, including a multilateral development institution, as defined by the federal International Financial Institutions Act, 22 U.S.C. 262r(c)(3); or
any parent, successor, subunit, direct or indirect subsidiary of, or any entity under common ownership or control with, an entity described in item (1) or (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: “Public body” means:

paragraph.text: the State;
a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision;
a public instrumentality; or
any governmental unit authorized to award a contract.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** CONTINGENCY – IN EFFECT – CHAPTERS 446 AND 447 OF 2012 **
For purposes of this subtitle, a person engages in investment activities in Iran if:

paragraph.text: the person provides goods or services of $20,000,000 or more in the energy sector of Iran, including a person that provides oil or liquefied natural gas tankers or products used to construct or maintain pipelines used to transport oil or liquefied natural gas for the energy sector of Iran; or
the person is a financial institution that extends $20,000,000 or more in credit to another person for 45 days or more if the person to whom the credit is extended:

subparagraph.text: will use the credit to provide goods or services in the energy sector of Iran as described in item (1) of this section; and
is, at the time of the extension of credit, identified on a list created under § 17–704 of this subtitle as a person engaging in investment activities in Iran.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** CONTINGENCY – IN EFFECT – CHAPTERS 446 AND 447 OF 2012 **

A person that, at the time of bid or proposal for a new contract or renewal of an existing contract, is identified on a list created by the Board under § 17–704 of this subtitle as a person engaging in investment activities in Iran is ineligible to, and may not bid on, submit a proposal for, or enter into or renew a contract with a public body for goods or services.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** CONTINGENCY – IN EFFECT – CHAPTERS 446 AND 447 OF 2012 **

paragraph.text: On or before December 31, 2012, the Board shall use credible information available to the public to create a list of persons that the Board determines to be engaged in investment activities in Iran as described in § 17–702 of this subtitle.
The Board shall update the list at least every 180 days.
Before the Board includes a person on the list, the Board shall provide the person with 90 days’ written notice that:

subparagraph.text: the Board intends to include the person on the list; and
inclusion on the list would make the person ineligible to bid on, submit a proposal for, or enter into or renew a contract with a public body for goods or services.
